THE FOUND FESTIVAL
The Common Ground Arts Society’s First-Ever SITE-SPECIFIC PERFORMING ARTS FESTIVAL
ART + ADVENTURE + SUNSCREEN
NEWS (June 2, 2012)
Our Website is available.   www.commongroundarts.ca
NEW VIDEO - Showcasing some of the artists from the festival.

Less than 2 weeks left to donate!

*******

WHO WE ARE:

Common Ground Arts Society — or CGAS— is a not-for-profit organization dedicated to the promotion, development and advocacy of emerging Edmonton artists. We represent artists from a wide variety of genres, including dance, theatre, music, and visual arts.
After a big shift last January, our management team now consists of:

MOLLY GISELA STALEY (Executive Director)
ELENA BELYEA (Artistic Director)
ANDREW RITCHIE (Operations Director)
VICTORIA MORRISON (Festival Coordinator)
THE FOUND FESTIVAL:

This summer, we are organizing and hosting Edmonton’s first-ever Found Festival, an interdisciplinary performing arts event taking place in the Old Strathcona District June 29-July 1, 2012. After our out-all-night, glam-jam, party-party-party Opening Gala, 50 emerging artists across numerous disciplines will showcase their work in various unconventional site-specific— or “found”— spaces. Each event will happen ONE-TIME ONLY and has been uniquely hand-tailored to the urban landscape of Edmonton. Think plays in garages, roving Shakespeare and dance pieces on rooftops!

Our artists have been working for months to create exciting, dynamic pieces that will have you running, laughing, and tearing your way through one of Edmonton’s most beloved arts’ districts. In order to make this possible, however, WE NEED YOUR HELP!

This is the first time Common Ground has ever produced a festival of this size. At this time, we have not secured any government funding, meaning we are relying on individual donations, as well as proceeds generated from Bottle Drives.

Many costs are associated with creating a festival of this magnitude, however— ALL DONATIONS MADE THROUGH OUR INDIEGOGO CAMPAIGN GO DIRECTLY TOWARDS PAYING OUR FESTIVAL ARTISTS! We believe artists deserve to get paid for their work, no exceptions. However, in order to make that, as well as the festival happen, we need outside support. Every donation really does help and even small gifts add up fast!

WHO CAN YOU EXPECT TO SEE THIS SUMMER?

Check out some of the exciting local talent who are creating &
column2:
/or starring in the pieces that make our festival go:

Elena Belyea, Brett Dahl, Alyson Dicey, Andrea May Foht, Sophie Gareau-Brennan, Katie Hudson, Paula Humby, Neil Kuefler, Sarah Jackson, Lianna Makuch, Will Mitchell, Zachary Polis, Andrew Ritchie, Justin Romero, Richelle Schandech, Nathan Schmidt, Molly Gisela Staley, Benjamin Stevens, Brendan Thompson, Gianna Vacirca, Mark Vetsch, Marlee Yule

column1: We’re also offering a number of perks related to make your festival experience the best it can be, as a thank you to anyone who donates!
IF YOU CAN’T DONATE BUT ARE STILL INTERESTED IN HELPING OUT, HERE ARE A FEW THINGS YOU CAN DO!
<ul>
• Like our page on Facebook
• Promote our Indiegogo page by posting a link to it on your Facebook or Twitter
• Promote the Common Ground Arts Society’s Facebook Group page so more people can find out Found while it’s actually going on, as well as other upcoming CGAS events!
• Donate to our Found Festival Bottle Drive, happening April 6th and 7th 2012! If you’re interested in donating, check out the Facebook event.
• Come check out the festival when it’s going on!
***** If you know of a business that you think would be interested in donating us their bottles, please contact Andrew Ritchie at operationsdirector@commongroundarts.ca or (780)-695-6301!  ********

5k Donations:

To make a donation, please press the Contribute Now button and please remember to write the name of the runner you are supporting in the comments box. This is how we keep track of each runner's progress. Thank you for your help in this important project!
Who is 67 Sueños?
67 Sueños is a migrant youth collective born out of the need to raise our own voices and participate in legislative decisions that affect our future.
As a group, our objective is to strengthen the voices of underpriviledged migrant youth and broaden the legislative possibilities for immigration reform.
Our goal:

The goal of the 67 Sueños ""Health and Art with Migrant Womyn"" Campaign is to create a mural to be unveiled on August 26th, 2012 in the Fruitvale District of Oakland, California. The mural aims to bring light to the health challenges that migrant womyn face on a daily basis. It will highlight the 12 womyn's struggle to be heard and be healthy.

In our creative process for this mural we have interviewed womyn who have made the difficult choice of having to leave their own families and communities in search of a better life in the U.S. and in an effort to provide a better future to their children. We have interviewed young womyn who came to this country as children and are also struggling to remain healthy, to go to college, to secure a decent job and to become successful. In total we will interview 12 womyn young, adult and elderly and use these interviews to inform our mural vision. Professional artists and our youth will translate these stories into a large piece of public art that educates and encourages dialogue. The more we humanize the stories the more people will come to know that ""No Human is Illegal"".
What We Need:

To achieve this mural we need $5,000 and over 50 volunteers. The money will be split between artist fees and youth stipends. All of the artists involved are local East Oakland Artists. We want this local mural to create paid opportunities for local artists and local migrant youth. We have already raised funds for materials and with your help are ready and willing to grace the Fruitvale community with a vibrant, beautiful and important mural.
<div>

This will be our second mural. Last summer 67 Sueños successfully painted a mural in San Francisco that portrayed what migrants leave behind when they come to the U.S. and what they encounter upon arrival. The mural also portrays some of the stories of members of the 67 Sueños group. The Project struck a chord with the community and gained extensive media attention. Univision 14 made a three part series on the mural. It also garnered front page status in the San Francisco Chronicle.
With your donations...
In donating to the cause, you would be supporting the mission of 67 Sueños which is to inform our community and share migrant stories through art.
If you donate $200 or more you are a big donor! We will invite you to sit in on one or more of our brainstorm sessions for the mural vision and we will give you an actual thank you on the wall.
If you donate $100 or more you are a key partner in making this mural happen. We would name you as a key partner on our website and on the video production describing the Mural making process.

If you donate $50 we will send you an official 67 Sueños T-shirt with the words, “I am Anastacio” written across the front. (Anastacio was a Migrant father killed on the border by 18 border patrol agents in the year 2010 and we support a campign to bring justice to his family.)
Donations, be they small or large, are immensely appreciated. Everyone of you is invited to our Painting Party, which we will plan for the first week of August after we have reached our funding goal.
The Impact

Art is a  creative, non-violent and highly cultural and accessible form of communication. We believe in creating a culture united around a concern for change.   For that reason, today we want to bring art to the Fruitvale that exposes injustice and humanizes the womyn who live and struggle in this community. It is currently one of the most segregated and low-income communities in the Bay Area making this project transformative. Our Mural will be part of the cultural shift that engenders the statement, ""No Human Being is Illegal!""
<div>
Other Ways You Can Help
Everyone is invited to our Painting Party where we will collaborate and paint the mural. The exact date in early August of the painting will be decided when we have the necessary funds to move ahead.

We are also organizing a Health Fair in concert with our Mural Unveiling on August 26th and need volunteers to make this day a success.  Please contact us @ 67suenos@gmail.rog to get involved.

Please also spread the word to your friends and family regarding the 67 Sueños Project so that together we can rise up in solidarity through art.

CAMPAIGN:

Over the years, I've had many requests from fans that prints be made available to purchase of various paintings and other artwork.  Until now, two problems usually prevented me from pursuing these requests:  1.The venture required significant financial investment and risk, and/or 2. the end cost to the buyer would be too high to make it accessible to most fans.

Through financial backing from fans through indiegogo, I will be able to purchase my own giclée printer.  By producing the prints myself, I can print on demand, which in turn allows me to sell a wide variety of my artwork in a way that would both be profitable for me and at a very reasonable price for my fans.  In producing the prints myself, I can ensure that each print meets my high standards:
<ul>
• The print quality is nearly identical to the original artwork.
• The sizing will match when possible (the majority of my artwork will reproduce at a 1:1 ratio).
• The paper and ink is archival quality.
• All prints signed and numbered.
• All prints will have a 1"" white border (approx).
The initial print collection will include iconic and notorious paintings from Deadworld and Cannibal Corpse as well as some paintings and pen and ink drawings from my personal and art gallery works.
BIO:

Vince Locke: Artist and Illustrator

Vince Locke is an accomplished artist who began his art career in 1986 illustrating Deadworld, a zombie horror comic that soon became an underground hit. Since then, his illustrative talents in comics have included The Sandman, American Freak, Batman, Witchcraft: Le Terreur, The Spectre, A History of Violence, (which was later made into a movie directed by David Cronenberg and starring Viggo Mortensen), and most recently, The Unwritten. Locke has also gained notoriety by creating ultra-violent watercolor paintings used as album covers for the death metal band Cannibal Corpse, and by providing illustrations for the dark-fantasy author Caitlín R. Kiernan. His paintings have been featured in numerous galleries around the world.  He lives with his wife and three sons in Michigan, where he continues to draw and paint many things.
HOW YOU CAN HELP:

In making a donation, you are essentially pre-ordering a fine art print.  Don't see a particular print you'd like to have?  Contact me and let me know what you are looking for.  Can't afford anything right now?  No worries, you can still help me out by spreading the word.  Indiegogo has sharing tools.
PERKS:

column2: >$30 One print of your choosing from the following: Blind, Untitled Aug 2010, Lady Res., Untitled Aug 2009--

>$50 One print of your choosing from the following: Torture, Kill, Deadworld #1, Deadworld Classics Compilation #2 (King Zombie), New Deadworld #2, Graveyard, Untitled (Exploding Arm), Butchered at Birth
>$75 Set of prints - Untitled Aug 2010, Lady Res, Untitled Aug 2009
>$150 Set of prints - Deadworld #1, Deadworld Classics Compilation #2 (King Zombie), New Deadworld #2, and a signed copy of the original print run of Deadworld #1 (limit of 5)
>$200 Set of prints - Butchered at Birth, Torture, Kill and a signed limited edition Torture figurine and cd set (limit of 5)

Please add $10 for shipping.

Hey, you!

Who am I? Hi, I am a senior at Columbia College Chicago studying photojournalism and continuing my studies in Florence, Italy for my fall semester (4 months)! I will be attending Florence University of the Arts (FUA)

My trip will not only include high-resolution photos of the landscape of Europe but also the people that live there (no tourists)! My mission is to take my camera to the streets of Italy and everywhere I travel. I will also be updating my ""Follow Me to Florence"" blog regularly so you can ""follow"" me as if you were right behind me!
column5:
>By contributing to my campaign you are helping me achieve a dream doing what I love most! Traveling and photographing will hopefully be my career one day so these are my first few steps towards my future!

  • Please check out my Website
column8:
to see what I'm about!


What I Need...

column1: <li>
Your donation is going towards expenses for my trip abroad and more importantly towards my photo equipment to continue taking high quality photographs for YOU!
<li>

The perks I have offered are centered around my photo portfolio in Europe and what I will be learning at FUA! I am so excited to produce the work for everyone to see and be able to come back to Chicago with international experience.

The Impact

    This past year of college has been transformative for me as an artist. I have taken challenging classes that tested my creative skill. My advanced education in photography has not only been technical but has enhanced my communication skills. I have learned that communicating with others is half the job. Since most people are camera shy (including me), as a photographer, I strive to create a positive atmosphere so my subject is comfortable opening up to me and the camera. I get the best result when that happens. 

    This trip is the true test to what I have learned in the past 3 years in college and gives me opportunities to grow as photographer and a person.
• Please share this campaign with anyone and everyone you know so I can reach my goal!
• Don't forget to use the share buttons so all the social media outlets are being used!

THANK YOU ALL!

Between
the time when the oceans drank Atlantis, and
the rise of humanity’s Martian colonies, there was an age undreamed of…
Actually, there were many ages, and worlds, and fearsome creatures, and bold heroes to inhabit them. And in the
tenebrous depths of a small Eastern-European country, they all vied for
supremacy within the head of a young artist.
Horned daemons clawed against the chromed exoskeletons of
blaster-wielding space soldiers among a twirling void of stars, and fierce orcs
rode their warthogs into battle against spandex-clad superheroes at the base of
fiery volcanos
column2: and all of them were desperately trying to breach out of the

column1: realm of imagination and escape onto the white paper (or tablet screen, or what
have you).
So the artist drew and painted, struggling to keep up with the onslaught
of Fantasia. A quick sketch here, a digital painting there, a fantastic beast
in all of its 3D-imentional glory during lunch time, because who needs food
anyway ... He put all his strength and skill to it, and a considerable amount
of sleepless nights too, but it was never enough.
Finally, he sat down exhausted, his hand trembling with the effort and
the coffee overdose, and though: “Wait a goddamned minute!<span>  Why am I doing all of this by myself?
Wouldn’t it be smarter if I actually get some help for this?”
So he grabbed his iHorn of Summoning and his brethren in art heeded the
call! From all around the country they came: wizened mages that bend the laws
of perspective to their will and summon otherworldly colours to do their bidding
hardened warriors that yield their Z-shaped brushes with unparalleled skill
nimble rangers, whose unerring stylos could speedpaint a creature in the blink
of an eye…
And so the heroes rallied, and one of them asked the artist:
“What’s up, man?”
And the artist spoke. At length, he exposed his plan and the task at
hand: to deliver the fabled worlds of Fantasia and grant them a life in our
world, for all to see them, touch them, or smell them, if you’re into that sort
of thing.
What his friends answered is lost to the mists of time, but the general
consensus is it was something along the lines of:
“Dude, this will be awesome! Let’s do it!”
And so it began…

This deluxe album contains a great collection of art pieces and ideas from the author, the concept artist Miroslav Petrov. It presents different art styles, subjects and fellow artists that were invited to draw something for the book on a specific topic.

•     The book is a hardcover edition with 176 pages, A4 size (8.5x11), with mostly art and only a few pages of text. It contains several chapters, dedicated to the various subjects and settings Miro has explored through the years. The last chapter will be dedicated to the art of some of the most famous bulgarian concept designers, illustrators and 3d artists..

•     Your name will also be included in the credits page of the book for pledges of $40 and above. Depending on your pledge, you can receive additional goodies that will come with the book, including a personal dedication, exclusive 16 pages sketchbook, custom sketches, concept art and full color illustrations.
•     I’ve set my initial goal at 5000$. This sum will be enough for the printing and distribution of 500 hardcover copies of the book. The album will only be made available in hardcover.
•     If I reach my goal I expect to release the book and send the copies in  October 2014.
Don't forget to put the extra 20 Dollars for the International shipping.

The Creation of Miro

Somewhere between socialism and something else, in the very begining of the upcoming long and cold winter of 1985, Miroslav was born, with a marvellous for the time almost 5 kilograms weight.
Untill the age of 9, it was his teacher conviction that he was a natural born art prodigy.  Years passed, though, and he proved them all wrong by not evolving at all (one of his biggest regrets in retrospect) artistically. Rumor has it, it might’ve been due to the onset of computer games, and/or to the unprecedented ease  of access to pictures of girls in various stages of undress …
Miro put his drawing on hiatus until the  age of 17 when all that time he’d sunk into playing computer games finally paid off in an unexpected way. One day, he booted up Warcraft 3, and there he found his inspiration in Blizzard’s art team incredible artwork. There was no turning back. Going back to the pencil and ink, Miro spent countless night at improving and refining his skills, before finally deciding to make the jump to digital art.
  All the hard work was not for naught: in 2006, he was hired as a concept and texture artist at the game developer Masthead Studios, where he spent the next 6 years giving freedom to his fantasy, and bringing fantastic creatures and landscapes to life. In 2012 Miro left the company to pursue  his own business and to branch out in more diverse creative directions.

Summary
column2:
>My name is Joshua Dunlop, I'm a freelance artist living in Kingston, London. I’ve worked in film and games for the last 6 years, creating monsters and rich story lines for them and even got to get in front to the camera a couple of times. 

Ever since I got my first gameboy as a child Ive been hooked on Pokemon. It builds upon some of the fundamental elements of the imagination, blending science fiction and fantasy. A world filled with fantastical creatures with amazing abilities living alongside humans. Technology far advanced than our own and legends and a world that marvel against our own. With all of this and a collecting element to the game, they created something that would capture the hearts and minds of millions. However, as I’ve grown, Pokemon hasn’t grown with me. Its still aimed at a young audience, and rightly so, but what about their older fans? One day, I thought to myself, why isn't there an older form of Pokemon for a generation that grew up loving it, so thats where I came up with the idea, of ‘The World of Pokemon’.

column1: The Idea
My plan is to build a fully interactive site with huge amounts of artwork and detailed information on the Pokemon world.
'The World of Pokemon' is a non profit website that shows Pokemon in a realistic way.
The website includes:
Biology
Biological studies of the Pokemon. Types and how their abilities work, how evolving works, their habitats, diets, training techniques and much, much more!
<div>
The World in which the Pokemon live in. Looking at the Cities, Towns, forests and wilds, each with detailed maps and histories surrounding them. Also looking at Gyms etc.
<div>
History
A long and detailed look at the History of their world such as lost civilisations, world wars and religion. Plus a look into the natural evolution of Pokemon.
Technology
<div>
The Technology of the their world and how it works, such as Pokeball's, Pokemon storage etc.
<div>
The Pokemon League
The League and the different tournaments it provides like Pokemon Battles, Beauty contests, Breeding contests etc.
<div>
Extras

The website will also be full of fun extras, such as online comics, fan fiction, areas for fans to talk and share their ideas (which will help shape the website) and possibly even mini games and videos! Other possible extras are:
<div><b><b><ul>
• Fully animated graphic transitions on the site such as buttons, page shifts and mini animations
• A cinematic score created by Gabriel Ryfer Cohen and his team
• Actual SFX of the Pokemon calls and roars.
• 3D models of each Pokemon created by our incredibly talented 3D design team. First as realistic pictures but hopefully we can develop and rig them into animated models.
• The site could be translated into many other languages such as French, Italian, German and Japanese.

• Bring on game designers to create free mini games. A few Ideas are - 'The Pokemon Academy' where you learn about Pokemon and solve tests and puzzles to find out what kind of Trainer you will be and a 'League simulator' where you manage a team (similar to football manager) through the league right up to the World championships.
• A full 'Pokemon Youtube Channel' that collaborates with many other Pokemon channels bringing you the latest news.

column2: >If you fund the project you will not only be kept up to date as it goes on, you will even get to help shape what we create. The more funding we receive, the more time we can spend on it as a team, making it as in depth as possible using all the resources at our disposal.

column1: We are a FAN SITE. The website wont charge its members a membership fee and will be purely funded by advertisements and donations.

There will be no 'official' artwork from Pokemon displayed on the website, only original artwork and writing. This would be similar to how many fan or art websites work. We will also happily direct people to the Official Pokemon site to see the latest on game, tv and film news.

A few of you expressed concerns on the last crowd funding attempt about copyright infringement on the site, and I understand not all of you want to read the information below, plus its not on the video, so heres some stuff the hopefully help you understand:
Hundreds of fan sites use the name Pokemon, however we might end up changing the site name in the long run like serrabi.net or bulbapedia.com did so not to detract from Pokemon's Official site.
All the money raised is to fund a private fan art project that won't charge the fans for the content on the site, just a celebration of Pokemon in a new way.
We will advertise Pokemon for free on the site as to not let Pokemon feel like we're stealing their traffic... if anything were aiding them
Finally heres a video for you guys to watch about copyright laws and fan art: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xKBsTUjd910

What We Need!

We want to create a full interactive fan site of a high quality, the money will go towards:
• Paying a skilled web designer to create and maintain the site.
<li><i style=""line-height: 1.45em
<li><i style=""line-height: 1.45em
column2: >Pay for advertisement space around the net to get the project noticed.

column1: • A personal server
• Merchandise
• and Hosting

We have asked for quotes from a number of web designers and most have said (for the original size, scale and complexity that were after) - £15'000- £25'000. However as we can't get that much were planning on aiming a little smaller to originally get noticed and hopefully raise more funds from advertising on the site and generous donations to build the site up to our original dream.

If we don't make the full £10'000 we will use whatever we have to create the best possible website we can, not a penny wasted. We all care about this project and through a previous attempt at crowd funding we've found that the fans want it too.
The Team
Joshua Dunlop

column2: >Graphic Artist/ Illustrator and writer living in London.
>He's worked in game and television for nearly 6 years now doing freelance work and also studied BA Hons acting for stage and media at the University of West London.

column1: Robbie Tarrant

column2: >Robbie has worked in the film and television industry for the last 4 years working on films such as Tim Burton's 'Dark Shadows'.

>'I first got involved on this project after seeing Josh's art on Deviant Art. With my Film background I could see a huge cinematic potential in the market for reinventing Pokemon and bringing it back to its original fans. Imagine a Transformers meets Jurassic park concept that could be explored in so many avenues, the website is just the beginning...'.

column1: Roman O'Toole-Howes

column2: >Role: Filming behind the scenes, Video Blogs, Film Editor
>Roman O’Toole-Howes is a freelance filmmaker / cinematographer and trainee stuntman from southwest London .

>'I remember when the first red and blue games came out and the impact it had in the late 90’s on our generation. I feel that this project has huge potential to reignite the sense of adventure Pokémon gave us as kids. I will be providing video content updating you with the development of the World of Pokémon and keeping you involved in the shaping of the world.'

column1: Mark Underwood

column2: >Mark Underwood studied a degree in Acting for stage and media and is currently writing plays for Concatenate Theatre Company.
>'I'm looking forward to the chance to learn more about the Pokemon World. Creating a rich, vibrant and adult version to match Josh's artwork.'

column1: Henry Collie

column2: >Henry Collie is an Acting student from Dublin, Ireland. Having a strong educational grounding in Classical history, Chemistry and Biology mixed with his passion for writing and literature he will bring a number of assets to the “World of Pokemon” team. Studying in the third year of his degree he is also writing a play set around World War 1 due to tour in February 2014. As a child Henry was obsessed with the Pokemon world, often writing stories set within it. As he grew however, he also found the Pokemon world became less and less relatable. With your support he hopes to help create a Pokemon world which is still relevant to those who grew up with it by expanding upon the little explored notions of the current Pokemon universe. He will be specialising in the Pokemon world’s history.

column1: Richard Elderfield

column2: >Richard works as a mechatronic engineer at Heathrow Airport. He has experience in technical drawing and experience in CAD.
>'I'm excited to be the tech geek in the World of Pokémon!'

column1: Lucy Rose- Wyatt - Got a first in biology from Queen Mary (it's in the Russell group), and starting a masters in ecology &
column2: evolutionary biology at the same university this autumn. She works part time as a research assistant to a professor of genetics.

column1: Emma Hernejärvi - A biology student (5th year)
Bradon Burgess - Has a degree in zoology with marine zoology
3D modelling and rendering:
Matt Williams – 3D Artist, studied at the Arts institute in San Francisco (Is also building a team of artists from the same Institute) www.mattwilliams3d.com
Eric Twelkemeyer- 3D Artist, studied at SAE institute in Hamburg, Germany
Ben Pierson – 3D Artist - www.benjaminpierson.com
Music and Sound:
Gabriel Ryfer Cohen - Is a Film Scoring student at Berklee College of Music in Boston and is assembling a team of talented composers and sound designers (for Pokemon sounds) from the same Institute.
What can you get out of donating?
Newsletter
In the monthly newsletter you will be shown behind the scenes content and videos talking to the people who make the site.
It will have a polling station on certain things when we need your help, for example: Is Psyduck a Bird or a Platypus? Your answers help build the world.
Sneaky peeks at work in progress artwork etc.
And any other exciting news.
Package Deal
If you donate over £100 you will be sent this very special care package which includes:
Pokemon League acceptance letter:
A Pokemon Academy Bookmark:
Selection of Pokemon badges:
Pokemon Training certificate:
and a signed Poster (frame not included):
<div>

Within a year of receiving the funding we will have a screening of the website to which only the 'Beta Testers' will all be allowed to see. We will have a message board open for one week where you can state your likes and dislikes about the site. We will then go away and fix any bugs and change anything that you guys didn't like.
The site will then launch to the general public with the first lot of content. This will probably include a large amount of Pokemon, a detailed look at Pallet and much much more.

Finally we will begin to give monthly updates with new and exciting things like new Pokemon, Gyms, Tech etc Also possible videos with presenters giving you all the latest news on everything Pokemon (if budget allows).

We will work on a region at a time, very much how you work your way through the games but including information from every source, up until the latest release. This means you will get content out faster and you will be constantly updated with new and exciting things!

Eventually I want to be able to invite artists and writers from all over the world to contribute and offer areas for fans to post fan art and fan fiction. I also have ideas in the far future to involve 3D artists from around the world to create a 'National Geographic' style web series, but this can only be done with backing and community support
<div>
<span style=""color: rgb(0, 0, 0)
If you can't donate, thats ok. Please share our link and use the Indiegogo share tool to get the word out!

The Team
Joshua Dunlop
Graphic Artist/ Illustrator and writer living in London.
Role: Editor and Artistic Director
He's worked in game and television for nearly 6 years now doing freelance work and also studied BA Hons acting for stage and media at the University of West London.
Robbie Tarrant
Producer, Locations Manager, Unit Manager
Role: Director and Business administrator
Robbie has worked in the film and television industry for the last 4 years working on films such as Tim Burton's 'Dark Shadows'.

'I first got involved on this project after seeing Josh's art on Deviant Art. With my Film background I could see a huge cinematic potential in the market for reinventing Pokemon and bringing it back to its original fans. Imagine a Transformers meets Jurassic park concept that could be explored in so many avenues, the website is just the beginning...'.
Roman O'Toole-Howes
Director, Cinematographer, Film editor, Stuntman
Role: Filming behind the scenes, Video Blogs, Film Editor
Roman O’Toole-Howes is a freelance filmmaker / cinematographer and trainee stuntman from southwest London .

'I remember when the first red and blue games came out and the impact it had in the late 90’s on our generation. I feel that this project has huge potential to reignite the sense of adventure Pokémon gave us as kids. I will be providing video content updating you with the development of the World of Pokémon and keeping you involved in the shaping of the world.'
Mark Underwood
Writer / Actor
Role: Writer / Researcher
Mark Underwood studied a degree in Acting for stage and media and is currently writing plays for Concatenate Theatre Company.
'I'm looking forward to the chance to learn more about the Pokemon World. Creating a rich, vibrant and adult version to match Josh's artwork.'
Henry Collie
Writer / Actor
Role: Writer / Researcher

Henry Collie is an Acting student from Dublin, Ireland. Having a strong educational grounding in Classical history, Chemistry and Biology mixed with his passion for writing and literature he will bring a number of assets to the “World of Pokemon” team. Studying in the third year of his degree he is also writing a play set around World War 1 due to tour in February 2014. With your support he hopes to help create a Pokemon world which is still relevant to those who grew up with it by expanding upon the little explored notions of the current Pokemon universe. He will be specialising in the Pokemon world’s history.
Richard Elderfield
Engineer for British Airways
Role: Technical Artist / Technology advisor
Richard works as a mechatronic engineer at Heathrow Airport. He has experience in technical drawing and experience in CAD.
'I'm excited to be the tech geek in the World of Pokémon!'

column2:
>The Story of SPARKcon 

This year SPARKcon turns 10-- hence the X! SPARKcon is an interdisciplinary creativity, art &
column3:
design festival produced by the non-profit creativity incubator, Visual Art Exchange, in Raleigh NC. SPARKcon 2015 will be the tenth annual event and will be held Sept. 17-20 in downtown Raleigh, come join the fun!

September 2015 will be our tenth annual SPARKcon!! Each year we activate an open-invitation group of volunteers. SPARKcon is open to any passionate individual or group who wants to get involved. We’re grass roots—our money comes from our pockets and the pockets of others excited to support local creativity. The ideas and showcases come from inspired people who have the ingenuity to say “What if…?” and the motivation to then help make it happen.

SPARKcon’s “creative potluck” of SPARKs or creative themes such as art, music, film, fashion, geek, circus, etc.  is put together by passionate individuals who volunteer their expertise and are deeply embedded in a specific local scene. Using a combination of networking and open calls for participants, organizers create diverse and representative events to show off local talent and connect disparate creative scenes. 

This year, we have over 80 organizers, hundreds of local talents will be showcased, hundreds of volunteers will helping behind the scenes and thousands of attendees. All of these people equal SPARKcon.

column1: <h2 style=""text-align: center

column2: >SPARKconX has to have a limited edition T-Shirt, right? For a $40 or higher pledge, you get one of 'em. Check it out!

column5:
>Why We Gogo 

As SPARKcon grows, so does the budget (funny how that works, huh?). This year, we anticipate budgetary needs to be upwards of $200k: $100k in in-kind donations (meaning totally awesome people and organizations donating their time or their stuffs) AND $100k+ of cold hard cash to make it happen. All this money goes to the production and logistics of the events. Most of the organizers, the visionaries and talent are passionate volunteers.

Indiegogo is such a beautiful representation of a community-based funding process, that we have to embrace it! Our goal is to realize at least 10% of our cash budget needs through this Indiegogo campaign.

Each year, we ask for our community to engage with SPARKcon and help make it happen through awesome contributions of time, talent, know-how and, yes, money. 

Your support helps make it happen! The budget goes towards:

• Creating a super festival featuring 2,000+ local creatives in 200+ events!

• Allowing SPARKcon to be free and open to everyone!

• Paying sound techs, stage and lighting techs and other production talents

• Renting equipment like video screens and projectors and buying supplies

SPARKcon keeps the Triangle creative. By helping artists plan their own showcases and grow their professional skill sets and networks, this festival helps build careers and create leaders. And educate everyone about the next big thing! 

What happens if we don't meet our goal?
We will always have SPARKcon! Our artists always find a way! That said, your support is needed to help us purchase supplies, pay artists, build new audiences and inspire more people.
column6:
>This year is so SPARKly!

SPARKcon grows every time a new person gets involved with a SPARK category, creating their own event, or joining in to help an existing one. It’s an open-source, “for the people, by the people” approach with an intentionally dynamic focus and will feature 2,000 artists in 200+ events. Each segment of the creative community plans their own ""SPARKs"" to showcase their talent.
column14: >Many many many artists of all ages are involved with artSPARK. There are a host of installations, exhibitions, workshops AND chalk art covering three entire city block lengths of Fayetteville
column15: > St! See how the local artist community expresses creativity!
column21:
>bazaarSPARK

Enjoy a city block worth of local artisans, brands, food, fashion and friends as an outdoor shopping experience. What if the mall was cool and celebrated local goods? It would be bazaarSPARK.
column27:
>circusSPARK

Be ready for serious fun with a big talented local community of circus performers! Acrobatics, hoops, fire dancers, a bit of magic and, of course, the banana dance!
column33:
>comedySPARK

Quick!  Tell us a joke!  Not a problem for these folks.  From buses to bathrooms, it's laugh out loud fun!
column39:
>danceSPARK

The SPARKcon main stage will be chock full of expressions of dance. Be ready to see the great variety and talent of our local dance community.
column45:
>designSPARK

Showcasing the local talents of our design community - architecture, interior design, graphic design, product design, motion design, etc - they're all here and they're all awesome.
column51:
>fashionSPARK

The fashionSPARK fashion show is the largest and most popular annual fashion event in the Triangle! This year, also enjoy jewelrySPARK, a trunk show featuring work by the area’s most talented jewelry designers.
column57:
>filmSPARK

Experience a showcase of local independent films and shorts in drama, comedy, thriller, documentary, animation, experimental &
column58: effects, and music video—all on a giant downtown screen!
column64:
>geekSPARK

Be wowed by the latest new and interactive media and technologies. Whether it's a large video game studio, or a solitary multi-disciplinary genius, geekSPARK showcases an awesome blend of art, technology and creativity.
column70:
>ideaSPARK

Get into it with fast-action presentations of 20 slides / 20 seconds per slide. Each year ideaSPARK influences the area, including the design of Raleigh City Plaza and the inclusion of local designers in city proposal requests.
column76:
>musicSPARK

Find lots of different types of music - the awesomeness you might not have even known was here - and celebrate it in clubs and on stages throughout downtown Raleigh.
column82:
>theatreSPARK 

It's all an act - seriously. Enjoy a variety of styles and talents in theatre productions and excerpts designed to celebrate and promote our local community of actors.
column83:
>There are Perks!

A cool, limited edition T-shirt, primo event seats, behind-the-scenes access, love, gratitude, high fives—and most importantly, the great feeling that comes with supporting your local community and helping creative people do amazing things.
column91:
>Other Ways You Can Help

Volunteer! It takes a lot of people to make this work!

Share this campaign. There are easy Indiegogo share tools!

More about SPARKcon:

SPARKcon is a showcase of creativity, talent and ideas of “The Creative Hub of the South,” the Triangle of NC.

SPARKcon was founded in 2006 by Beth and Aly Khalifa and Designbox to showcase, celebrate and influence the creative momentum of the Triangle region of North Carolina. SPARKcon uses an open-source organizational approach to empower diverse creative thinkers to be inspiring community leaders.

SPARKcon is a program of Visual Art Exchange, a Raleigh non-profit whose mission is to support emerging artists and connect the community to the arts.

SPARKcon’s name comes from being a conference to “spark” the local art community and brand the Triangle as the creative hub of the South. SPARKcon uses an innovative event structure to connect and showcase the growing creative community in the Triangle. Each category is called a “SPARK” (musicSPARK, fashionSPARK, etc.) and is organized by volunteers who create programming that best represents their art form, whether a performance, an exhibition, showcase or interactive digital game.

Visit SPARKcon.com to get detailed information. The schedule of events will be online as well when we get closer to the dates. And please join us in downtown Raleigh for SPARKcon on September 17-20 2015!

Short Summary

My grandmother passed away in October 2015 at 94 years old and she had dementia in her last years , she didn't know who I was but we still shared some happy moments. The times that i saw her happy was when she was childlike. Her face would light up for chocolate and wine! She is my inspiration and the reason I want to create colouring books for senior citizens.

What We Need &
column2:
What You Get

I am a single mother who lives paycheck to paycheck I started a small colouring group in May 2015 to colour with other people in a social setting. I created the group on Facebook. I have learned what people want in a colouring book and what the frustrations are for seniors with the current styles of adult colouring books. A lot have eye sight and dexterity issues which make the intricate pages impossible for them to colour.

column1: I need to get the group from facebook and into its own website where colouring books can be sold, the pages coloured can be displayed, events calendar for people to see the upcoming free events and a blog where i can be doing videos and writing about colouring tips!

I want to create a colouring book with multiple artists to provide a variety of images. I want lots of natural images with some intricate and some easy so that everyone can find a page to colour! I will have images for men and women, images from the decades they grew up in and music to go along with the books to make them smile.

column4: >The top priority is getting the book together. It has to be on good quality paper, with single sided images. The book will be coil binded with the coils at the top so that pages can  be removed and used to decorate or to send a letter to a friend by writing on the back.

column1: The books will cost approximately 6.50 each to print(not bulk). I need to provide books at 2 price points one at below 10 dollars and the other at 18.00.

column4: >No matter how much i make i will be collecting images for colouring for this book and will be bringing them to retirement homes in my area.

column1:
The Impact

Adult colouring books are big business and are therapeutic. Anyone can colour you do not need to have artistic talent and it can be done with dollar store pencils.  The New York Times Best Seller list has 5 of their top 10 books as adult colouring books.  By 2020 10% of the world population will be over 65. I want to bring a little childhood joy back to them and respect their likes and dislikes. I want to colour with alzheimer and dementia patients to see if i can get a smile from them with the music they love in the background!  I just want to bring a little joy into their lives!
Risks &
column2:
Challenges

I have been looking for the right opportunity for me to make a true difference in this world. I personally struggle with complex PTSD depression and anxiety so this is also therapeutic for me. I know that this will be healing for me and for the seniors i can bring joy too.

column1:
Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't contribute do you know someone who is an artist who might want to contribute a picture for this book?
Do you know a group of seniors that would love to be interviewed about what they want in a colouring book?
Please share with the tools on this site and tell all your friends about my idea if its one you believe in!

The times that i saw her happy was when she was childlike. Her face would light up for chocolate and wine! She is my inspiration and the reason I want to create colouring books for senior citizens. What We Need & What You Get I am a single mother who lives paycheck to paycheck I started a small colouring group in May 2015 to colour with other people in a social setting. I created the group on Facebook. I have learned what people want in a colouring book and what the frustrations are for seniors with the current styles of adult colouring books. A lot have eye sight and dexterity issues which make the intricate pages impossible for them to colour.

I need to get the group from facebook and into its own website where colouring books can be sold, the pages coloured can be displayed, events calendar for people to see the upcoming free events and a blog where i can be doing videos and writing about colouring tips!

I want to create a colouring book with multiple artists to provide a variety of images. I want lots of natural images with some intricate and some easy so that everyone can find a page to colour! I will have images for men and women, images from the decades they grew up in and music to go along with the books to make them smile.

The top priority is getting the book together. It has to be on good quality paper, with single sided images. The book will be coil binded with the coils at the top so that pages can  be removed and used to decorate or to send a letter to a friend by writing on the back.
The books will cost approximately 6.50 each to print(not bulk). I need to provide books at 2 price points one at below 10 dollars and the other at 18.00.
No matter how much i make i will be collecting images for colouring for this book and will be bringing them to retirement homes in my area.

Hey hi how are ya! My name is Vivian Laurence. I’m 19 years old and I currently live in Los Angeles, California. I’m an independent artist by nature -- I love to sing, play, produce, write, paint, design, and dream up anything I can imagine. This is my wildest idea yet and I want you to be part of it.

On May 20th, my very first show will come to life in Los Angeles. Gaia’s Garden is the first mini-tour of my debut EP Flowers and the launch of my creative arts collective called Light Lair. The Light Lair is a community of artists who have joined together on a mission of spreading light and love through art and creation. Our aim is to unite female creators across the globe and through all art forms to share and empower our perspectives. Light Lair’s first gallery exhibit is part of the Gaia’s Garden experience -- bringing young artists together to create a supportive environment that uplifts women’s voices.

Together, we can create a vision of how full of love the world can be. Our generation of conscious creative youth has the power to create a new world, and we’d like your support to do it. To bring Gaia’s Garden to life, we are inviting friends, family, fans, and dreamers alike to sponsor the Gaia’s Garden showcases. As the saying goes, April showers bring May flowers. Will you join us?

Los Angeles show: May 20, 2016 at SIR Los Angeles. 6465 Sunset Blvd, Los Angeles, CA 90028.

San Francisco show: to be announced

Here’s what we need:

$20,000 in funding. This budget will allow us to cover the production cost of two showcase performances, a live album recording of the show, videography, photography, stage design, band rehearsals, merchandise, and the Light Lair gallery exhibit.

Share and spread the word! Thank you for supporting the launch of Vivian and sharing in my vision of bringing light and love to the world through artistic expression. Flowers will grow here soon... x

0,"<div class=""routerContentStory-storyBody"" data-v-1df7bf5a=""""><div>
A Quick Background

Thanks to the local community the launch of The Kelsey Theater has been a growing success, and even given birth to what we now call The Lake Park Arts District. That left us wondering, ""What else can we do to make Lake Park great?"" The answer is to utilize the only real estate we have left in a project that benefits local artists and the community alike.

Where others saw only a blank wall A.J. Brockman and company saw a blank canvas with seemingly endless opportunities. The plan is to turn the back side of the 700 block into a giant mural with contributions from multiple artists. Much like Miami's Wynwood we are taking an otherwise unremarkable alleyway and turning it into a cultural destination. We already have one section completed (you can learn More here : Phase 1)

So why are we raising money? All of the artists involved are professionals, people who make their living from their art. Many times people get artists to do something like this in exchange for ""exposure"" and as artists ourselves we feel that is not always fair. They deserve compensation for their contribution. So the money raised will first purchase the materials needed and then every remaining cent will go to paying the artists for their work.
Won't you join us and make Lake Park beautiful again?
<h3>What We Need &amp

So, we need to fill this wall with eye-popping color that will make The Lake Park Arts District visible from outer space! Okay, maybe that's a bit unrealistic, but we still want to beautify this town with public art. The extent to which the wall gets painted depends on how much money we raise. Here is a quick illustration for those visual learners.

100% of all the funds raised will be going towards supplies, rental equipment, permitting and actually paying these artists because artwork is WORK. Once we reach our initial goal any additional money raised will be put into escrow and applied to the next round of muralists until we are able to paint the entire 700 building (pretty much a city block). After that, we start again right back at the beginning so there is always fresh imagery to inspire our community.

We are also partnering with local businesses, art stores, construction companies, and the suppliers themselves in order to minimize the amount of money we have to actually spend to make this wall happen. In turn, we are able to put more money into the artist pockets allowing them to continue to share their work and make a living.

Now to the good part… What you get in return for your support! We have a bunch of great perks at all different contribution levels, the majority of which center around ""The 3yr Anniversary Block Party"" scheduled for May 13, 2017. This will serve as our official wrap party and unveiling of the finished mural. Food trucks, vendors, craft beer, live music, art demonstrations, and much more will be going down as we put the finishing touches on this masterpiece the day of. Not a local? No problem, many of our perks are easily shipped so you can help support this project from anywhere in the world. At the very least, come party with us at this free event and see what's happening at The Lake Park Arts District for yourself!
The Artists

Below are all the approved artists involved in our second round of mural–y goodness. All of which have already submitted sketches and artwork to be approved. These are professionals, artists literally making a living from their craft… And for the first time, we even have some international renowned muralists. Who is your favorite?

column2: >Craig McInnis – Born in a small town in Connecticut, June 12th 1972. Music and art runs through his family tree. His Mother is an artist and his grandfather and great Uncles were all big band musicians. Cartoon enthusiast. Foodie. Jokester. Halloween FREAK. Craig cherishes his friends and family. He creates art, for him, with hopes that it will stir something in the viewer…there is no other reason. He creates because he must do so to maintain sanity and relative balance.
>Kevin Goff + Artists from Ivy and Oak– a 39 year old working artist hailing from Boston, Ma.  He's been working with a variety of mediums including but not limited to oil paint, graphite &
column3: charcoal and the art of tattoo. Focusing on the relationship between light and dark in his pieces, he has supported himself most of his adult life with his art. He is currently the owner and head artist of Autumn Skye Art Gallery &amp
column4: Custom Tattoo and Ivy and Oak tattoo artist studio.  He is inspired by life and motivated by music as well as his family and his favorite artists Dali, Edward Hopper &amp
column5: Egon Schiele.  He is a strong supporter of the recovery community and has overcome many personal obstacles of a related nature. ""I want my art to tell a story, to capture a moment in time the way it appears to me.  My intention is to paint with my heart but my hands get in the way.""

column2: >Adam Hale – Arriving at a place somewhere near 10,000 hours, Adam Hale emerges with a mastery of style that enchants the soul while engaging the cultivated mind. His subjects reveal a sometimes satirical, and often comical view of business, politics, culture and society. As he playfully entertains, he invites insights into our humanity. This process delights the artist as much as his observers. “I see a lot of humor in my work. I like to watch these silly ideas in my head take shape and become even funnier as they emerge onto the canvas.”

>Sterling Goller-Brown – best known for his large-scale spray-painted mural works. In 2013, he cofounded Eastside Murals with artist Ian Lawrence and has been commissioned by the likes of Vanderbilt University, Pabst Blue Ribbon, Jagermeister, American Heart Association, Stella Artois and more. He attended college at the University of Tennessee in Knoxville prior to which he had no formal artistic training.There he received a Bachelor of Fine Arts degree with a concentration in painting.Upon graduating in 2014, he moved back to Nashville where he began organizing and curating pop-up exhibitions, painting murals and traveling.His artworks take on many forms and range from public murals to sculptures and installations

>FABS– I've been in the art field since the late 90's, when I began studying music in the Middle School of the Arts in West Palm Beach, Florida. Later, at Dreyfoos School of the Arts, after singing in the chorus for four years, I decided to change my major to Visual Arts. I graduated in 2004 and went to live in Miami to continue my academic career at New World School of the Arts. During my time there, I was absorbed by street art and wanted to continue traveling and painting. After some time, I settled down in Quito, Ecuador, where my mother is from and where I had spent four years of my childhood. Five years passed and I received my Bachelors degree from Universidad Central del Ecuador (Central University of Ecuador), majoring in Sculpture. During that time I worked in the urban area, including abandoned buildings in various cities of Ecuador. Currently, I alternate between Florida, Mexico, and Ecuador.

>Jennifer Chaparro – She grew up in San Diego, but has lived in Florida since 1999. She has a degree in Design from UCLA. She began street painting in 2004 in Lake Worth, Florida, with her daughter, Mercedes, and then her other daughter, Carmen.  Her company, Amazing Street Painting, creates large scale art in many mediums, including chalk &
column3: paint, for companies like Starbucks, Lexus and Ford.  Jennifer has won many awards for her chalk art, and travels the world creating custom works of art for festivals and special events.  She received her Maestro Certification in 2011, and is known for her exquisite portraiture, but also for exciting 3D anamorphic street art that boggles the mind. Jennifer was the first US woman to win an award in the 3D category at the Street Art Festival in Wilhelmshaven, Germany.  She also recently won the CANVAS West Palm Beach Local Showdown for her mural work in 2016.

column2: >Jose Gaddi – I was born in Argentina and raised in the States. Art is something that was always a passion to me as a child and as an adult, more like my mistress. Art nights are no sleep nights. My best art is done during the late hours. I went to school for fine arts. Bak Middle School of the Arts was my base. As I got older, Dreyfoos School of the Arts helped me find myself as an artist. I tried college but found myself in the real world and had to work. Today I find myself tattooing and painting for a living and couldn't be happier. Tattooing at Ritual Ink has given me the pleasure to do art and live. Murals are something I have love for but I haven't had too many chances to show off publicly. I've aways done them in private homes. It's always nice to get a public recognition when it comes to big art. I live for the smile people get when they see art and are confused or intrigued.

>Mayling Pao – born in Matagalpa, Nicaragua and raised in South Florida. She attended the prestigious high school, New World School of the Arts in Miami, FL and received her BFA from the Kansas City Art Institute in Kansas City, MO. Her fine art has been exhibited in galleries and art festivals in Miami, West Palm Beach, FL, and Kansas City, MO. Her art includes fine art paintings, portraits, murals, and paper maché sculpture. She is also a body painter and special effects makeup artist.

>Sami Makela – (born 1972) is from Helsinki, Finland. As a son of a well-known World War II illustrator, Reijo Makela, Sami grew up appreciating all types of art. After finishing art school in Helsinki and making a name for himself as a graffiti mural artist, Sami traveled to Paris to seek inspiration. Finally in 1994, Sami decided to pursue his dreams in America. As an owner of Makela Art Studio, art restoration, murals and decorative painting is close to Sami’s heart. He has also continued to create his original paintings for clients. He has also been involved in street art events and work since the mid-1990s, and many of his murals are still in existence around Palm Beach County. In addition, one of his mural works “History of Helsinki” (1992) is part of a permanent exhibit in Helsinki Museum of Art.

>Evgeniy Shurakov – Born and raised in Russia in 1981.  I drew a lot as most children do but at about age 11 I made a conscious choice to become an artist.  In 1996 my mother brought me here to South Florida.  Graduated Deerfield Beach High School in 2000.  In high school, I was a part of the Magnet program and I did illustration for the school's newspaper and other publications.  Between 2000-2003 apprenticed at an art studio under master artist doing murals, faux finish, hand painting among many other things.  Did a lot of work in the style of Trome l'oeil.  I went on to graduate Ringling College of Art and Design in 2007 with a BFA in Illustration and minoring in Fine Art.  From 2008-2013 moved to Russia and worked as a concept/2D artist at Playrix Entertainment (casual gaming industry).  Since 2013 I moved back to South Florida with my wife and kids and continue as a freelance artist doing murals, theater production, digital illustration among many other things.

column1: <h3>Risks &amp

column2: >With the success of one of the most-funded campaigns in Indiegogo history in the theater category, so let's just say this is not our first rodeo. We have built an awesome core team of organizers, have city and governmental support, own the building, pulled permits, have artists ready and waiting, not even mother nature can hold us back (we have plenty of rain ponchos for our artists and have even scheduled more than two weeks to create these murals before the big unveiling
column3: even if we are dodging South Florida sun showers). The only thing missing is the money, coffee, and paint thinner to get this mural launched!

column1: In addition to contributions, we really need your help getting the word out. Word of mouth is always the best way for something like this to gain momentum so please take a moment to share this on your Facebook or Twitter. Share this page with your friends and family, tell them why you think it's a great project, and ask for their support.
Together we can make this happen, and feel free to come and check it out for yourself!
","A Quick Background

Thanks to the local community the launch of The Kelsey Theater has been a growing success, and even given birth to what we now call The Lake Park Arts District. That left us wondering, ""What else can we do to make Lake Park great?"" The answer is to utilize the only real estate we have left in a project that benefits local artists and the community alike.

Where others saw only a blank wall A.J. Brockman and company saw a blank canvas with seemingly endless opportunities. The plan is to turn the back side of the 700 block into a giant mural with contributions from multiple artists. Much like Miami's Wynwood we are taking an otherwise unremarkable alleyway and turning it into a cultural destination. We already have one section completed (you can learn More here : Phase 1)

So why are we raising money? All of the artists involved are professionals, people who make their living from their art. Many times people get artists to do something like this in exchange for ""exposure"" and as artists ourselves we feel that is not always fair. They deserve compensation for their contribution. So the money raised will first purchase the materials needed and then every remaining cent will go to paying the artists for their work.
Won't you join us and make Lake Park beautiful again?
What We Need & What You Get

So, we need to fill this wall with eye-popping color that will make The Lake Park Arts District visible from outer space! Okay, maybe that's a bit unrealistic, but we still want to beautify this town with public art. The extent to which the wall gets painted depends on how much money we raise. Here is a quick illustration for those visual learners.

100% of all the funds raised will be going towards supplies, rental equipment, permitting and actually paying these artists because artwork is WORK. Once we reach our initial goal any additional money raised will be put into escrow and applied to the next round of muralists until we are able to paint the entire 700 building (pretty much a city block). After that, we start again right back at the beginning so there is always fresh imagery to inspire our community.

We are also partnering with local businesses, art stores, construction companies, and the suppliers themselves in order to minimize the amount of money we have to actually spend to make this wall happen. In turn, we are able to put more money into the artist pockets allowing them to continue to share their work and make a living.

Now to the good part… What you get in return for your support! We have a bunch of great perks at all different contribution levels, the majority of which center around ""The 3yr Anniversary Block Party"" scheduled for May 13, 2017. This will serve as our official wrap party and unveiling of the finished mural. Food trucks, vendors, craft beer, live music, art demonstrations, and much more will be going down as we put the finishing touches on this masterpiece the day of. Not a local? No problem, many of our perks are easily shipped so you can help support this project from anywhere in the world. At the very least, come party with us at this free event and see what's happening at The Lake Park Arts District for yourself!
The Artists

Below are all the approved artists involved in our second round of mural–y goodness. All of which have already submitted sketches and artwork to be approved. These are professionals, artists literally making a living from their craft… And for the first time, we even have some international renowned muralists. Who is your favorite?

Craig McInnis – Born in a small town in Connecticut, June 12th 1972. Music and art runs through his family tree. His Mother is an artist and his grandfather and great Uncles were all big band musicians. Cartoon enthusiast. Foodie. Jokester. Halloween FREAK. Craig cherishes his friends and family. He creates art, for him, with hopes that it will stir something in the viewer…there is no other reason. He creates because he must do so to maintain sanity and relative balance.

Kevin Goff + Artists from Ivy and Oak– a 39 year old working artist hailing from Boston, Ma.  He's been working with a variety of mediums including but not limited to oil paint, graphite & charcoal and the art of tattoo. Focusing on the relationship between light and dark in his pieces, he has supported himself most of his adult life with his art. He is currently the owner and head artist of Autumn Skye Art Gallery & Custom Tattoo and Ivy and Oak tattoo artist studio.  He is inspired by life and motivated by music as well as his family and his favorite artists Dali, Edward Hopper & Egon Schiele.  He is a strong supporter of the recovery community and has overcome many personal obstacles of a related nature. ""I want my art to tell a story, to capture a moment in time the way it appears to me.  My intention is to paint with my heart but my hands get in the way.""

Adam Hale – Arriving at a place somewhere near 10,000 hours, Adam Hale emerges with a mastery of style that enchants the soul while engaging the cultivated mind. His subjects reveal a sometimes satirical, and often comical view of business, politics, culture and society. As he playfully entertains, he invites insights into our humanity. This process delights the artist as much as his observers. “I see a lot of humor in my work. I like to watch these silly ideas in my head take shape and become even funnier as they emerge onto the canvas.”

Sterling Goller-Brown – best known for his large-scale spray-painted mural works. In 2013, he cofounded Eastside Murals with artist Ian Lawrence and has been commissioned by the likes of Vanderbilt University, Pabst Blue Ribbon, Jagermeister, American Heart Association, Stella Artois and more. He attended college at the University of Tennessee in Knoxville prior to which he had no formal artistic training.There he received a Bachelor of Fine Arts degree with a concentration in painting.Upon graduating in 2014, he moved back to Nashville where he began organizing and curating pop-up exhibitions, painting murals and traveling.His artworks take on many forms and range from public murals to sculptures and installations

FABS– I've been in the art field since the late 90's, when I began studying music in the Middle School of the Arts in West Palm Beach, Florida. Later, at Dreyfoos School of the Arts, after singing in the chorus for four years, I decided to change my major to Visual Arts. I graduated in 2004 and went to live in Miami to continue my academic career at New World School of the Arts. During my time there, I was absorbed by street art and wanted to continue traveling and painting. After some time, I settled down in Quito, Ecuador, where my mother is from and where I had spent four years of my childhood. Five years passed and I received my Bachelors degree from Universidad Central del Ecuador (Central University of Ecuador), majoring in Sculpture. During that time I worked in the urban area, including abandoned buildings in various cities of Ecuador. Currently, I alternate between Florida, Mexico, and Ecuador.

Jennifer Chaparro – She grew up in San Diego, but has lived in Florida since 1999. She has a degree in Design from UCLA. She began street painting in 2004 in Lake Worth, Florida, with her daughter, Mercedes, and then her other daughter, Carmen.  Her company, Amazing Street Painting, creates large scale art in many mediums, including chalk & paint, for companies like Starbucks, Lexus and Ford.  Jennifer has won many awards for her chalk art, and travels the world creating custom works of art for festivals and special events.  She received her Maestro Certification in 2011, and is known for her exquisite portraiture, but also for exciting 3D anamorphic street art that boggles the mind. Jennifer was the first US woman to win an award in the 3D category at the Street Art Festival in Wilhelmshaven, Germany.  She also recently won the CANVAS West Palm Beach Local Showdown for her mural work in 2016.

Jose Gaddi – I was born in Argentina and raised in the States. Art is something that was always a passion to me as a child and as an adult, more like my mistress. Art nights are no sleep nights. My best art is done during the late hours. I went to school for fine arts. Bak Middle School of the Arts was my base. As I got older, Dreyfoos School of the Arts helped me find myself as an artist. I tried college but found myself in the real world and had to work. Today I find myself tattooing and painting for a living and couldn't be happier. Tattooing at Ritual Ink has given me the pleasure to do art and live. Murals are something I have love for but I haven't had too many chances to show off publicly. I've aways done them in private homes. It's always nice to get a public recognition when it comes to big art. I live for the smile people get when they see art and are confused or intrigued.

Mayling Pao – born in Matagalpa, Nicaragua and raised in South Florida. She attended the prestigious high school, New World School of the Arts in Miami, FL and received her BFA from the Kansas City Art Institute in Kansas City, MO. Her fine art has been exhibited in galleries and art festivals in Miami, West Palm Beach, FL, and Kansas City, MO. Her art includes fine art paintings, portraits, murals, and paper maché sculpture. She is also a body painter and special effects makeup artist.

Sami Makela – (born 1972) is from Helsinki, Finland. As a son of a well-known World War II illustrator, Reijo Makela, Sami grew up appreciating all types of art. After finishing art school in Helsinki and making a name for himself as a graffiti mural artist, Sami traveled to Paris to seek inspiration. Finally in 1994, Sami decided to pursue his dreams in America. As an owner of Makela Art Studio, art restoration, murals and decorative painting is close to Sami’s heart. He has also continued to create his original paintings for clients. He has also been involved in street art events and work since the mid-1990s, and many of his murals are still in existence around Palm Beach County. In addition, one of his mural works “History of Helsinki” (1992) is part of a permanent exhibit in Helsinki Museum of Art.

Evgeniy Shurakov – Born and raised in Russia in 1981.  I drew a lot as most children do but at about age 11 I made a conscious choice to become an artist.  In 1996 my mother brought me here to South Florida.  Graduated Deerfield Beach High School in 2000.  In high school, I was a part of the Magnet program and I did illustration for the school's newspaper and other publications.  Between 2000-2003 apprenticed at an art studio under master artist doing murals, faux finish, hand painting among many other things.  Did a lot of work in the style of Trome l'oeil.  I went on to graduate Ringling College of Art and Design in 2007 with a BFA in Illustration and minoring in Fine Art.  From 2008-2013 moved to Russia and worked as a concept/2D artist at Playrix Entertainment (casual gaming industry).  Since 2013 I moved back to South Florida with my wife and kids and continue as a freelance artist doing murals, theater production, digital illustration among many other things.
Risks & Challenges

With the success of one of the most-funded campaigns in Indiegogo history in the theater category, so let's just say this is not our first rodeo. We have built an awesome core team of organizers, have city and governmental support, own the building, pulled permits, have artists ready and waiting, not even mother nature can hold us back (we have plenty of rain ponchos for our artists and have even scheduled more than two weeks to create these murals before the big unveiling
column2: even if we are dodging South Florida sun showers). The only thing missing is the money, coffee, and paint thinner to get this mural launched!

Short Summary

Subject: Post is student led, produced and funded, its scholarly pursuits are those of the participating students and the interstices that form between their works. It will span mediums and disciplines, involving painting, drawing, digital drawing, lens-based works and videos, installation and textile art. 

The prefix ‘post-’ is implicated in long list of compound words that persist within a state of subsequence, as in ‘post-human,’ ‘post-mortem,’ and ‘post-graduate.’ While ‘post-‘ suggests a present or prescient afterwards, it also connotes to the act of publishing, as in, to post is to make public. It is between these posts that ten graduating Visual Studies undergraduate students pursue their eight-month arts-based research projects towards a final culmination in a week-long art exhibition and accompanying publication, open to public engagement.

 

What We Need &
column2:
What You Get

 

Each of us has a unique perspective and method to explore visual art and what it means. Even though our ideas are vastly disparate we are producing a cohesive and interesting exhibit.

We need enough money to host and staff our opening and hopefully have enough left over to pay for some of the supplies we bought to produce our 4-8 month long projects. If we don't reach our goal, we will use whatever we have to help us fund the opening so that all of our sponsors, peers and fellow artists can come and see our final projects!

You get to come with us to the party and celebrate the success!

 

 

The Impact

With the generous help from our sponsors and funders, it is our goal to curate the most-attended exhibition in the history of the University's Thesis exhibitions. Spanning 3 days, the exhibition will take place April 7 to 9 at 563 Spadina Avenue, at our spacious installation studio on campus.

For decades the Thesis program has been an independent program led by students supplemented with mentorship from professors. The goal is to prepare and cultivate visual artists for contemporary Toronto art scene, not to mention the contemporary Canadian as well as the International art industry.

Every year, we have paid all of our money to the school, and now is our opportunity to reap the benefits and we want to share them with you!

 

Risks &
column3:
Challenges

For eight months we have been working individually and collaborating with each other to make the upcoming night perfect for ourselves and yours. We are working hard organize and design everything down to the freshest coat of paint to make the reception and following days of the exhibition inviting and stimulating.

 

 No amount is too small or too big ...

 

Please share this indiegogo page with any friends, colleagues or family members who would like to attend the event or may be able to help.

Please use the Indiegogo share tools!

Like and follow us on facebook and instagram @subject.post for updates and sneak peaks!!

Don't forget to check out our ever-evolving website http://www.subjectpost.com/

AND COME TO OUR SHOW!

Your generous nature creates the best art show ever.

Hi I'm Robert Hughes, a self taught artist.  I'm very excited that the Cafe Verde in Ann Arbor will host an art show with my art.  I have a number of pen and ink with watercolor pencil drawings, which are ready to show
column2: however, I think that my best art is the digital images that I've created.

column1: The contributions that you make here will fund the professional printing of some of these digital images I've designed.  Paragon Display, in Ann Arbor, is an excellent print shop.  For $500 they will take one of my digital images and blow it up to four feet by five and a half feet.  I'd love to see some of my images at that size in the Cafe!

However, it may be that I don't raise my goal of $2000.  If that is the case, I'll have to go for smaller sizes of these prints.  A framed ten inch by fourteen inch print costs $96 for the print shop to make.  That's a respectable size
column2: and it would be great to have several of my images showcased that way.

column1: If I only raise a very small amount of money, I'll put it into framing the pen and ink drawings that I have done and get them to the cafe.  These signed original artworks can be purchased as perks on this fundraising site.  They are done on 90 lb watercolor paper produced by Strathmore.  They have a cold pressed surface and are acid free.  The drawings, made about two years while I lived at the Zen Buddhist Temple, are holding up very well, and if kept from direct sunlight should be genuine heirloom pieces.

The drawings are easy to spot in the gallery section of this fundraiser.  They are the photos where you can see my hands holding the art at the top and bottom of the artwork.  The digital art images, from which I'll make the art cards (and larger sized posters) are also in the gallery section.  They are the flatter images with no hands holding the art.

The art cards (and 8 and a half by 11 inch posters) that I am offering here are made with longevity in mind.  They are made on 65 lb weight acid free card stock with a HP color laser printer.  Kept from direct sunlight, they will maintain their splendid colors for many, many years.

The artwork that I have made will amplify and enhance the ambiance of the Cafe Verde, where people of all ages converge.  Your generous contribution will increase the impact that the art has on the people visiting the store.
If you aren't in a position to support this project financially, please consider posting this link to Facebook, or sending out an email about it.
Thank you for visiting my fundraiser.
