column1: ","Was ist 77?

77 ist eine etwa 160 Seiten umfassende Publikation die sowohl als Printmedium als auch online erhältlich sein und publiziert werden soll. Siebenundsiebzig Doppelseiten bilden den Inhalt, wobei jede einzelne von einem/r unterschiedlichen KünstlerIn gestaltet wurde. Es gibt also keine journalistischen Inhalte im klassischen Sinn, das Magazin besteht voll und ganz aus individuell kreierten Beiträgen.
Helft mit, das 77-Magazin drucken zu lassen und setzt somit ein Zeichen für Kunst und Kultur abseits von Industrie, Anzeigen-Auflagen-Spiralen und Markt-Abhängigkeiten!
Was sind unsere Inhalte?

Wir haben die unterschiedlichsten Menschen dazu eingeladen, jeweils eine Doppelseite völlig frei zu gestalten. Egal ob es sich dabei um Fotografie, Grafik, Poesie oder Graffiti, Konkretes oder Abstraktes handelte – alles war erlaubt! Und so vielfältig und ungestüm wie die Vorgabe sind auch die Kunstwerke geworden, die uns KünstlerInnen, FotografInnen, SchriftstellerInnen, MusikerInnen, WissenschafterInnen und allerlei sonstige kreative Menschen aus allen Ecken der Erde zusandten und die einen verblüffenden Querschnitt durch eine junge und aufstrebende Kultur darstellen.
Warum 77?

77 sieht sich in diesem Sinne als ein “alternativer Filter” für Kultur. Das Ziel ist es, nicht nur durch spannende Beiträge und Inhalte zu unterhalten, sondern damit auch den vielen unbekannten ProduzentInnen, DenkerInnen und BeobachterInnen unserer Gegenwart ein Gesicht und eine Präsentationsfläche zu bieten.
Wie könnt ihr helfen?
Einmal natürlich indem ihr unsere Kampagne unterstützt und dafür einen unserer vielen tollen Perks bekommt!
Aber es wäre auch super, wenn ihr einfach allen Menschen die ihr kennt von 77 erzählt, es auf Facebook teilt, tweetet oder sonstwie eure Freunde daran teilhaben lasst!
Was bekommst du?1) Das 77-Magazin als digitalen Download (PDF)
2) Das 77-Magazin in gedruckter Form
über 160 Seiten Kunst & Kultur
Grafik, Fotografie, Literatur, Poesie, Statistik, Streetart, Mode, Experimentelles, Tagebücher, Real-Life!
77 Doppelseiten von
77 unterschiedlichen Künstlerinnen & Künstlern
4-Farbdruck und hohe Qualität
3) Die offizielle 77-Bio-Fair-Trade-Tasche
4) Das offizielle 77-Poster! (Das Motiv deiner Wahl, in A3)
5) Das offizielle 77-Bio-Fair-Trade-T-Shirt (in weiß)
6) Das offizielle 77-Bio-Fair-Trade-T-Shirt (in grau-schwarz)
Helft mit, das 77-Magazin drucken zu lassen und setzt somit ein Zeichen für Kunst und Kultur abseits von Industrie, Anzeigen-Auflagen-Spiralen und Markt-Abhängigkeiten!
Weil uns ein bewusster Lebensstil wichtig ist, sind wir froh darüber, mit zerum einen fairen Kooperationspartner gefunden zu haben.
Alle Produkte werden in der EU produziert und sind zu 100% biologisch, das finden wir gut!
www.zerum.at

www.77magazin.at / office@77magazin.at

BorgoIndie Festival/Conferenza

A noi non sembra poi così balzano organizzare un festival/conferenza dedicato a musica, makers, editoria, enogastronomia e innovazione a Brisighella. È uno dei borghi più belli d’Italia. In una delle valli più belle d’Italia. Il tessuto produttivo romagnolo è ricco di esempi di innovazione e creatività. Chiamiamo a raccolta chi pensa e fa in modo indipendente e ascoltiamo i loro racconti.

Dove puoi saperne di più?

sul nostro sito: BorgoIndie

• Vorremmo ospitare gli artisti che parteciperanno al festival

Hello.  The builders of Beau Le'Phant (the pink elephant) have a new Mutant Vehicle they would like to bring to BRC this year, The Bi-Polar Express (BPE).  The team of Dr. Galaxo Magic, Captain Danger Shipwreck and Uncle Charlie have already secured the base vehicle, a 1987 Cushman Turf Truckster.  Uncle Charlie has refurbished it and we begin construction shortly.

Dr. Galaxo has worked on Mutant Vehicles since 2001,  Captain Danger was lead builder of Beau Le'Phant (2011, 2012) and Uncle Charlie helped build Beau.  Now Uncle Charlie has become the lead builder of the Bi-Polar Express (BPE).  The BPE will feature a locomotive and coal car, plus one to two Circus Cage cars being pulled by the locomotive.  The Circus Cage cars will transport the wild animals of BRC around the desert in caged delight.
We expect the BPE to cost around $3000 to bring to BRC.  We just need a little help to bring this awesome train to the folks of BRC.

We have several Perks that we think will fit any budget and might work for you to help us.Beau Le'Phant was a huge success on the playa in 2011 and 2012 but it took 3 days to assemble Beau once we were on the playa.  The BPE will be built and transported to the playa on a flatbed trailer.  That way, the BPE can return again and again to BRC.  And the BPE can make appearances away from BRC, like parades and regional Burning events.
We successfully built Beau Le'Phant with no blueprints, the BPE will use our expertise to bring lighting, steampunk, the circus, a train, color, sound and amusement to the folks of BRC.
So please help us make this an awesome Mutant Vehicle by donate to the Bi-Polar Express.
For more information on the Bi-Polar Express Build and progress, check out our Weebly page at:http://bipolarexpress2014.weebly.com",3.0,0,"4 Campaigns
|","Chico, United States",https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/bipolar-express-mutant-vehicle-train-for-burning-man-2014/pica

YOU can help us exhibit art quilts from the Walsh Collection!  The Texas Quilt Museum needs your help to pay for shipping costs.

We invite quilt lovers to help us ship 54 art quilts from the world-famous collection of John M. Walsh III for our Fall 2014 exhibition season.  This will be the first major exhibition of the Walsh Collection quilts in Texas and the most comprehensive display anywhere of his quilts!  We are the only quilt museum in the American
Southwest (texasquiltmuseum.org), celebrating our second-year
anniversary. (We are a 501 c 3 organization.)

WHY SHOULD YOU HELP?  John Walsh has been collecting for more than 20 years, and his collection represents the very best in art quilts.  Opening in early October and running through mid-December, the Walsh exhibition will be a blockbuster show, completely filling the Texas Quilt Museum.

WHAT ARE YOU HELPING US PURCHASE?  You are helping to pay for a professional art transport company to bring the quilts cross country via truck from the Walsh storage facility to La Grange.  We are applying for grant money to pay for returning the quilts via art transport.
WHY ARE WE ASKING FOR SO MUCH MONEY?  Art transport is quite expensive, and we need $4000 to pay for one-way shipping.  Also, administrative costs from IndieGoGo and First Giving
take approximately ten percent of money contributed.  (Your receipt from The Quilt Institute will
be emailed by First Giving, which manages the IndieGoGo non-profit
campaigns.)
If we happen to exceed our goal, additional funding will be applied
to the Museum's exhibitions budget. <span style=""line-height: 1.45em

The Basics

Working under the nom de guerre of Rustbelt Cartography, I've been a professional cartographer for about 20 years and a self-acknowledged artist for about ten years. As an artist, I have found success selling my prints in Cleveland, Ohio when I was living there and I have succeeded in entering several group and juried shows with my art. I was also artist-in-residence at The Art Dogs studio in Gardiner, Maine.

This effort is a little different from the artwork that I have produced in the past in that it is a combination of my profession (map design) and my passion (art). While i have played a prominent role in numerous shows in both Ohio and Maine, this is my first solo show.

Submitting a handful of pieces to an art show is not very difficult, but an entire show is difficult because the up-front costs increase significantly. For instance, the cost of a frame will run about $75–$100 for each piece. (Consider that the next time you're in an art gallery!)
Contributions to this campaign will pay for those up-front costs that prevent struggling artists—such as myself—with the working capital to put this show together.
<hr/>
My needs
<div>
I need money. I'm sorry to be so blunt, but after being laid off from my job about a year ago, my finances have been limited. Any contibutions that are submitted will go for very specific materials:
<ul>
• Picture frames. I've already mentioned their expense! Frames will consume approximately 90% of this campaign.
• Paper for printmaking supplies. The blocks are already cut, but printmaking paper is expensive
• Perks. You'll make a contribution for this project, but you'll also help with its promotion.
That's it. No hidden agenda!
<div>
Other Ways You Can Help
Maybe you can't contribute enough to earn a ""Perk
column2: that's ok. Small contributions are also welcome. If you can't contribute cash, please spread the word about this campaign—perhaps someone else that you know shares the belief that Cartography is an Art worthy of its own recognition.

column1: The Show

The Lost Maps of Norumbega will be presented in April, 2013 at the Monkitree Gallery in Gardiner, Maine. As more details are available (specific dates, opening reception, and so on), I will post them here and in an email to my supporters. If you can be in Maine during the late spring of 2013, I encourage you to visit the show!

The show itself will feature my maps utilizing a variety of media: block printing, ink illustrations, and watercolor. As the development progresses, additional media may also be employed as appropriate.

My name is Courtney Rutter, I am an artist from Miami, Florida. My husband, Richard Ralph, and I are trying to raise money to go to New York and sell our work in a street fair/ art show. We have been selling our work every month during Miami's Art Walk, trying to make a name for ourselves. We have had nothing but great feedback from our city! We want to see what the Big Apple thinks! :) We found a street fair in New York called the SOHO Autumn Fair on Oct. 13th, and we are beyond excited to see what the big city thinks of our work! Unfortunately we have to drive there because we just dont have any other way of getting all our huge paintings and crates of buddha sculptures all the way across the country! The trip will take over 2 days just to get there, and another 2 days to get back. All funds raised here will be going towards our gas and motels. If we dont make it in October we will try again for the spring. I really appreciate anyone even taking the time to read this! Anything Helps!
If you donate please email me @: SarahCourtney85@aol.com and send me your mailing address and I will send some, one of a kind, stickers made by both of us!
Also to see more of our work, please check out our websites: www.ChooseYourPeace.com www.305Kid.com
Thank you again for taking the time to read this!

Peace Love and Art!

Short Summary
My name is Will Graham.  I am a professional artist who is looking to expand artistically, and bring exposure to other talented, but struggling artists.

Will Graham is a globally collected, Canadian born muti-media artist. He has exhibited in galleries from London, to New York, and gained world recognition with ‘sell out’ art shows and several of his pieces featuring in numerous publications, and prominent locations, such as the iconic LED billboards in Times Square.  His work is heavily influenced by Van Gogh, Monet, and the neo impressionists, and has been compared to the likes of Tim Burton, and David Bollt.  However, due to the self-taught nature of his paintings he is in a class all his own, using bold lines and vibrant colours to stand out among the rest.  He is a successful tattoo artist, experienced graphic designer, and award winning chalk artist.
To know more about me, check out my website at www.willgrahamgallery.com
Art is so underappreciated in this day and age.  And so much of it goes unnoticed largely because showcasing art is expensive and space is limited.

It is my hope with this campaign, to secure a creative studio space and gallery.  The studio space would allow me to create the large pieces I have plans for, unhindered by the shortcomings of my basement.   Among the new collections I have plans for, is a series of portraits of infamous buildings.  Such as the Dakota Building, where John Lennon was shot and killed.  I am seeking to tell a story with these pieces, and bring the history of these iconic buildings to the public eye.  It is my vision that this studio will offer space to other artists needing a creative outlet to work from, but do not have, nor can they afford to rent an appropriate space.  This studio space would also house a public gallery to showcase my art collections.  This gallery would also offer public exposure for the many fine artists in London and surrounding area, by allowing them to showcase their work as well. The unique and personal gifts hand-crafted by our artists, as well as the original paintings created by the artists showcasing in this gallery will reflect the creativity of the thriving arts community in our region.

A professional studio space to work from and a public upscale gallery which is accessible by all artists who may need it, is in my opinion, a facility that has a real need in this community.  Providing more exposure for local artists and engaging the public with more awareness of the arts is goal that has benefit for everyone.
What We Need &
<div>
This project has come at a crucial time in my career.  I run a successful business that operates on the reputation of the artists that work out of my tattoo studio.  The Neon Crab Tattoos &
column2: Piercing studio runs like a well oiled machine.  For the first time, I have the ability to focus my efforts on a truly artistic endeavor.  Hundreds of artists will be able to create and display their art.  But we need your help!

column1: Your contribution will play a key role in the financing of such a large undertaking. With your donation, large or small, you will pledge that you believe, like us, that art is an integral component of a healthy community.  Through our art we can challenge perception and provoke change in a positive manner.  By supporting us, you will become a member of our ever-growing creative family, and you will stand beside us as we spread our message.

In recognition of your support, certain ""perks"" will be made available.  Everything from recognition on our highly trafficked websites and social media outlets to VIP tickets to the opening night of the gallery are available as a thank you for your contribution.  Please, pledge today.  We deeply appreciate your help.
The Impact

For those in the art world, we know the term 'starving artist' is very real, and it is very difficult to actually make a living creating art.  I know first hand the stuggles an artist goes through to simply do what they love doing.  I studied art all though school, I worked in print and lithography, I moved into graphic design before discovering tattoo art.  I quickly moved into that arena, and thrived there for years.  I regularly work with chalk in street painting events, have created murals and corporate art to make ends meet, and all the while I have worked to gain recognition for my own personal oil on canvas paintings.  Only now, after what seems like a lifetime of pushing myself as an artist, do I feel that I am starting to gain some recognition.  It's been a long journey, as it has been for many other artists just like me.  So it should be of no surprise, but your support (financially and spiritually) is keeping my dream alive and allowing me to continue to develop as an artist. Without your ongoing contributions I would not be this far along in my career. Thank you for believing in me and allowing me to continue on this creative journey.  And with this project, we will help many other struggling artists gain the recognition they deserve.
<div>
Other Ways You Can Help

Whether you can afford to donate $1000 or $1, every dollar helps and is immensely appreciated. Some people just can’t contribute financially, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help.  This fundraiser has to be about our energy and positive spirits. In order for us to succeed in creating this community art gallery, your role in personally asking friends, family, artists, and art lovers to support us is equally as important.
Pass on this message through email, facebook, and personally reaching out to your friends and family, share us through indiegogo tools. and together we can make this project a reality

The Impact

For those in the art world, we know the term 'starving artist' is very real, and it is very difficult to actually make a living creating art.  I know first hand the stuggles an artist goes through to simply do what they love doing.  I studied art all though school, I worked in print and lithography, I moved into graphic design before discovering tattoo art.  I quickly moved into that arena, and thrived there for years.  I regularly work with chalk in street painting events, have created murals and corporate art to make ends meet, and all the while I have worked to gain recognition for my own personal oil on canvas paintings.  Only now, after what seems like a lifetime of pushing myself as an artist, do I feel that I am starting to gain some recognition.  It's been a long journey, as it has been for many other artists just like me.  So it should be of no surprise, but your support (financially and spiritually) is keeping my dream alive and allowing me to continue to develop as an artist. Without your ongoing contributions I would not be this far along in my career. Thank you for believing in me and allowing me to continue on this creative journey.  And with this project, we will help many other struggling artists gain the recognition they deserve.
Other Ways You Can Help

Whether you can afford to donate $1000 or $1, every dollar helps and is immensely appreciated. Some people just can’t contribute financially, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help.  This fundraiser has to be about our energy and positive spirits. In order for us to succeed in creating this community art gallery, your role in personally asking friends, family, artists, and art lovers to support us is equally as important.

Pass on this message through email, facebook, and personally reaching out to your friends and family, share us through indiegogo tools. and together we can make this project a reality",0.0,0,"1 Campaign
|","London, Canada",https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/will-graham-gallery/pica

Bigger is Better!

My name is Rod Lindauer. I've been a full time artist for twelve years, mostly as a sculptor and furniture maker. I recently seriously injured my left hand in a shop accident, making me unable to work in my traditional media for several months. I have always been interested in antique film photopraphy and had been working off and on as time and funds permitted to build a very large format film camera and perfect the chemistry and techniques required to make large glass plate negatives. I am trying to build a camera that will allow me to take life sized portaits and contact print those onto handmade photographic paper. These techniques date back to the dawn of photography, and are as tedious, cumbersome, and uncertain as today's digital photography is thoughtless and perfect. The funding for this project will allow me to push past the experimental phase and replace my cardboard prototype with a durable camera and pay for the chemistry and paper that I need to make negatives and photographs. The result will be a totally handmade photograph, with all the artifacts and imperfections that come with that.
<div>
A huge negative means bigger everything.

The biggest challenge for my project was to find a lens large enough to cover such a huge negative. Large lenses are very expensive and most of those will only cover a negative that is 8x10 inches, the size of the most common large film still available. The answer to my problem was a lens from a very old machine that duplicated poster art. Now I need a camera to mount it on. That means I'll have to build one. My cardboard test camera revealed that I need six feet of bellows between the lens and the film to produce a portrait. That's a big ass camera! The negatives will be three feet by three feet. That means large trays for coating and processing the images and lots of silver nitrate, gelatin, and developer. The funding from this site is the only way I'll be able to afford to take this to the next level.
<div>
Why go to so much trouble for a photograph?
<div>

Kodak is going to stop making film. It's a digital world now. Every phone is a camera and a dozen apps can make you Andsel Adams. Why bother? I like the idea that this giant dinosaur of a camera will be the polar opposite of convienient. It will take all day to make just one photograph. If you sit for your portrait, you will have to be perfectly still for several minutes. It's not a disposable thing. It will take time and skill and the result will never be perfect.
I'm poor, how can I help?
If you can't donate and you like the idea, you can help spread the word. Put me on your Facebook page or pin me in Pinterest. I'd really appreciate it!

PLEASE NOTE THIS FUNDRAISER IS SUSPENDED for the time being. The tone of the convention itself has changed so dramatically given recent events in and around Phil Cambpell, Alabama, that we are refocusing our efforts on ways to help the tornado-stricken town (the town's Hoedown has been canceled). 

Ultimately, we will be trying to a) provide direct help to the residents of Phil Campbell, and b) draw attention to the town's urgent needs.

Whatever money earned here will redirected into our new fundraising efforts . If anyone who's already given has a problem with that, as our mission has changed, please contact me ASAP and I will arrange to reimburse you.

thanks! phil campbell (Brooklyn)

==============

I am the organizer of the first ever International Phil Campbell Convention, to be held this June 17-18 in Phil Campbell, Alabama. My goal -- my OBSESSION -- for the past year has been to a) make sure that all the Phil -- as well as any other derivation of Phil, like Phyllis, Felipe, etc. -- Campbells living all over the world have been invited, and b)...well, I didn't know there was a ""b"" until last week, with less than two months before the convention.

I'll get to ""b"" in a moment. You can check out our media coverage in several places: AOL News, http://tinyurl.com/3m723dx
column3:
and a front-page story and online video from the Wall Street Journal, http://tinyurl.com/3ogtygp.

OK, b) is this: We have a few Phil Campbells who want to come, but cannot afford to. And we need your help!

We have four Phil Campbells —from San Jose, California
column6:
and Aberdeen, Scotland — who need financial help. Domestic and international air fare. Some hotel expenses. And, as the convention organizer, I'm trying to get my own airfare and hotel covered if possible.

Nobody’s flying first class or staying in a five-star hotel, folks. We Phil Campbells just want to get there. If you were a Phil Campbell, wouldn't you?

column1:
Think of it this way, for every $1,200 or so we raise, another Phil gets to go!

We need your help because -- Oh, What FUN This Will Be! The International Phil Campbell Convention is coming to Phil Campbell, Alabama during the town's annual hoedown. And not just any hoedown. This is the town of Phil Campbell's 100th anniversary celebration. People will be there from all over the region. There will be a dunking booth. There will be a mechanical bull. There will be live music and Southern barbecue! 

The Phil Campbell of Birmingham, Alabama is bringing a Scottish marching band with him to lead the parade of Phil Campbells down Phil Campbell’s very own Maple Street. Riding in a truck behind this Phil are all the other Phil, Phyllis, and Philippe Campbells.

And there will be a documentarian on hand to record it all…the International Phil Campbell Convention is, ultimately, a film project for Southern documentarian Andrew Reed, as well as a potential publishing project for me, Phil Campbell of Brooklyn, a published author.
 
Any donation you can give to make this bizarre, surreal, incredible experience come true for these Phil Campbells would be greatly appreciated

<strong>
PROMOTEUR DE DIVERSITÉ AU LONG COURS
Vues d’Afrique, c’est avant
tout « aller aux vues », pour un autre regard sur l’Afrique et sa
diaspora. Créée à Montréal en 1984, Vues d’Afrique est une ONG qui fait dialoguer les cultures
québécoises, canadiennes, africaines et créoles grâce aux arts.
Nous offrons des activités de
rencontre avec des <b>artistes originaires d’Afrique et des
pays créoles. Nous touchons aussi bien au cinéma qu’aux arts visuels ou à la
musique.
La route est longue et riche
de partenariats avec des médias, des institutions culturelles et des organismes
favorisant le rayonnement du continent africain à l’international. Nous sommes
fiers d’avoir développé un vaste réseau de festivals jumelés présents en
Amérique, en Afrique et en Europe.

EN 2014, NOUS FÊTONS NOS 30 ANS!

Cette année, nous voyons la culture en grand!
Nous célébrons 30
ans de mission culturelle acharnée ainsi
que la 30e édition de notre festival
de cinéma.
Plus motivés que jamais, nous vous présentons le
meilleur du cinéma et des arts visuels sur l’Afrique et sa diaspora avec :
<ul>
• le 30e
Festival international de cinéma Vues d’Afrique (du 25 avril au 4 mai)
• les 30
expositions du Rallye-Expos (du 1er février au 30 juin)
Pour mener à bien ces activités et développer de
nouveaux projets innovants répondant aux besoins des professionnels et artistes
issus de la diversité, notre organisme recherche de nouvelles solutions de
financement.
DEMAIN AVEC VOUS, VUES D'AFRIQUE S'INSCRIT DANS UNE NOUVELLE ÈRE!
<ol>
• Nous voulons faire
de l’outil numérique un atout  pour
enrichir l’offre multiculturelle à Montréal. Au programme : des évènements
organisés en direct sur les réseaux sociaux, des tables-rondes sur le cinéma
numérique ou encore des rendez-vous professionnels sur les moyens alternatifs
de diffusion et de promotion.
• Nous souhaitons
mettre en place une plateforme numérique de location de films, pour que vous puissiez
retrouver en ligne les œuvres marquantes du festival.
<li>

Nous développons de nouveaux partenariats dans les provinces anglophones canadiennes. Nous voulons y démontrer toute l'originalité et l'authenticité de la francophonie africaine et créole. Nous sommes déjà présents  en Ontario avec la  Nouvelle scène à Ottawa et en Saskatchewan en collaboration avec l'Université de Regina.
<h4 style=""text-align: center
column2: ><em>Nous faisons appel à votre soutien pour nous

column1: permettre d’avancer et de continuer à en faire bénéficier le plus grand nombre.
Votre don, quelqu’ en soit le montant aidera à faire la différence.
<h4 style=""text-align: center
column2: >Pour les plus petits contributeurs (moins de 10 $) nous marquerons votre nom sur notre liste de remerciements diffusée sur notre site internet.

City Dwellers is an exhibition of contemporary Indian art opening August 30 at the Seattle Art Museum. In this fantastic and exclusive
exhibition that can be seen only in Seattle, audiences will get an insider’s
view of India today—in all its complexity and contradictions—seen through the
work of 12 artists living and working in India’s urban centers.

Hey there!
Project Project is having a fundraiser – we’re about to ask
you for a donation and here’s why…
For almost a year now, we at Project Project have provided
the city of Omaha and the surrounding region with exciting new contemporary art
exhibitions featuring the work of many extremely talented artists, many of whom
are showing in Omaha for the first time. On top of that, we have been able to
use our space and resources to host lectures and concerts which adds to our
monthly exhibition schedule. Plus we have had a lot of fun and we love giving
back to our community and its artists.
From the very beginning, we have gladly covered all of the
costs for this space with money from our own pockets, but we want to offer
more. To this point, the space has been rent-free but that will soon change. We
are also unable to offer any sort of compensation to our exhibiting artists
aside from 80% of sales, meals and beers. We want to take Project Project to
the next level, and that is where we hope you come in
We are resurrecting an Omaha art tradition by hosting a $100
Art Sale. Unlike previous, similar events, not one penny will be spent anywhere
aside from rent for the space, new exhibitions and gallery upkeep. We have no
interest in making money off of Project Project or the artists that choose to
show there. Another year of supporting artists could be funded by the sale of
just 42 pieces.
We are holding this online portion of the fundraiser so that
friends of the gallery who are out of town or people that cannot attend will be able to help contribute as

well. Thanks for taking the time to hear our request. Have a great day!

Albert DeMuth is looking for a small financial push from the backers

column1: of the INDIE GOGO community to turn a project he initially created into
something he could only dream of creating by molding this record into

the beautiful piece of art it was intended to be.

A little goes a
long way when stretching for the final push, which includes funding for
film, development of film, renting a camera, buying cowboy boots, and procuring a large transparent

water container.

It's very important to meet this objective as he cannot do this on his own.

We've got a lot of great rewards you can see them below or to the column at the right.

Albert is looking forward to making this Indie GOGO campaign all it can be.

The Impact

This album was birthed from water and fire damage to an apartment Albert once lived in. He now wants to return the album to the same fate as it's birth. It is a circle of life. The essence of good mixed with the proponents of evil. This is something not everyone gets to experience in their own lifetime, let alone the same year as its birth.
Risks &
column2: ChallengesIn the Gallery tab you can view Albert DeMuth Commercial #1. Albert has experience with being able to use fire as a distressing agent. But he seems to be a novice when it comes with the properties of something as simple as Two hydrogen atoms combine with an Oxygen ion. The original creator and destroyer of worlds, Water.

column1:
THE 5800 DOLLAR SUPER PRIZE!!!!
You will fly/boat/drive to Rhode Island to hang out for the
day/night/weekend with Albert. (winner must arrange transportation and
lodging) I will take you around to all of my favorite spots, this
includes Spike's Junkyard Dogs where I will get a veggie dog with
saurkraut, swiss cheese and spikes mustard, this comes with poodle
fries. (a curly french fry variety). I also like to mix soda water with
pink lemonade. I will show you the proper proportions for MAXIMUM
ENJOYMENT.  They usually have the history channel on, we will watch an
episode of whatever is on at the time. (may include Ancient Aliens,
CURSE OF OAK ISLAND). Then we will get matching ankle tattoos of the
date of our hang out. If you do not want a TATTOO we will get our BELLY
BUTTONS PIERCED. You will also receive a limited edition T shirt that
features my face on it that I've been wearing around for the last 8
years. Along with all of these rewards you will also get a WATER and
FIRE DAMAGED version of the ALBERT DEMUTH self titled debut album.
Limited to 300 copies, this album includes a DOUBLE SIDED SILKSCREENED

COVER, WRAPPED IN GOLD FOIL, THEN SIGNED BY THE ARTIST.
","Albert DeMuth is looking for a small financial push from the backers
of the INDIE GOGO community to turn a project he initially created into
something he could only dream of creating by molding this record into
the beautiful piece of art it was intended to be.A little goes a
long way when stretching for the final push, which includes funding for
film, development of film, renting a camera, buying cowboy boots, and procuring a large transparent

water container. It's very important to meet this objective as he cannot do this on his own. We've got a lot of great rewards you can see them below or to the column at the right. Albert is looking forward to making this Indie GOGO campaign all it can be.   The ImpactThis album was birthed from water and fire damage to an apartment Albert once lived in. He now wants to return the album to the same fate as it's birth. It is a circle of life. The essence of good mixed with the proponents of evil. This is something not everyone gets to experience in their own lifetime, let alone the same year as its birth.

Risks & ChallengesIn the Gallery tab you can view Albert DeMuth Commercial #1. Albert has experience with being able to use fire as a distressing agent. But he seems to be a novice when it comes with the properties of something as simple as Two hydrogen atoms combine with an Oxygen ion. The original creator and destroyer of worlds, Water.
THE 5800 DOLLAR SUPER PRIZE!!!!You will fly/boat/drive to Rhode Island to hang out for the
day/night/weekend with Albert. (winner must arrange transportation and
lodging) I will take you around to all of my favorite spots, this
includes Spike's Junkyard Dogs where I will get a veggie dog with
saurkraut, swiss cheese and spikes mustard, this comes with poodle
fries. (a curly french fry variety). I also like to mix soda water with
pink lemonade. I will show you the proper proportions for MAXIMUM
ENJOYMENT.  They usually have the history channel on, we will watch an
episode of whatever is on at the time. (may include Ancient Aliens,
CURSE OF OAK ISLAND). Then we will get matching ankle tattoos of the
date of our hang out. If you do not want a TATTOO we will get our BELLY
BUTTONS PIERCED. You will also receive a limited edition T shirt that
features my face on it that I've been wearing around for the last 8
years. Along with all of these rewards you will also get a WATER and
FIRE DAMAGED version of the ALBERT DEMUTH self titled debut album.
Limited to 300 copies, this album includes a DOUBLE SIDED SILKSCREENED
COVER, WRAPPED IN GOLD FOIL, THEN SIGNED BY THE ARTIST.",0.0,1,"1 Campaign

Who are Chuckle Cabin Records?

We are a new Melbourne record label focusing exclusively on stand-up comedy. Each year Australian comedians develop 1000s of new hours of comedy and most of it is then lost forever. We want to capture that and share it with the world.
While this is our first full-length standup album, we have heaps of experience:
<ul>
• Producing live standup shows
• Filming and producing standup videos
• Producing podcasts
Who is Laura Davis?
Laura is a multi-award winning standup comedian.
She's appeared on SBS's Standup @ Bella Union, ABC's Comedy Up-Late and recently had her own hour long comedy special on ABC TV.
'...extraordinary stand-up that squeezes your heart until you feel the blood surging through your body' ★★★★1/2 - The Age
Why We Need Your Help:

We want to register Chuckle Cabin Records with ARIA so we can put forward 'Cake in The Rain' for nomination in the Best Comedy Release category. This costs exactly $500. Any further $$ we raise past this will be spent on marketing the album to get it out there for more people to hear and enjoy.
Registering with ARIA will also let us nominate future releases for award consideration.
<div>
What You Get:

You will see a list of ‘perks’ on the sidebar of the page, from digital downloads, to CDs and T-Shirts. These vary in price with the smallest amount being $7 and we are super grateful for everything we receive!
When Will You Get Your Perks:
As soon as the campaign is done, if not sooner! Will try and get the goodies out to you all ASAP.

Short Summary

Hello, Spinbliss.com is a web based business that also intends to have a local brick and mortar presence with the mission of promoting and supporting the arts, entertainment, and culture on a local, national, and global scale.  Spinbliss.com intends to be the premier resource for artist, crafters, and arts organizations  to gain maximum exposure and distribution to a more diverse, worldly audience.
Your contribution today will help us complete more features on the site, which will add value to those who are already willing to use the site and to those who might use it in the future.

Your donation today will also go a long way toward helping artist, crafters, and arts organizations achieve their goals as well because that is what the site is for.  So your donation will ultimately help them.
We also want to create a platform for the average person to be able to discover all the unique independent creative stuff that is all around them.
We are providing an avenue for everyone to be able to promote and/or discover their own bliss.
What We Need &

We need to write code for the site and to do that we need money to pay our coders (programmers).  We have three super people employed as coders at Spinbliss and we would like to hire more to speed up the process so that we can bring these great features to the public faster.

Your donation today will bring you closer to being able to enjoy a fully functional website, but you can also choose other rewards such as a CD from Mercury Descends, prints from artist Rashelle Dawn, Philly Johnmeyer, Craig Downs, and Chris Sabatino.  There are also handmade hand bags from Kassioh, as well as stickers and T-shirts from Spinbliss.  We are also giving away some free perks to be used on the site and  VIP invitations to our launch party.
The Impact
Your, donation today will have a bigger impact than you can probably imagine.
1st.  Your donation will obviously have an impact on Spinbliss and the employees who will receive a paycheck because of your donation.

2nd.  Of course there is always an economic multiplier effect to consider as well.  When we pay our coders, with your donation, they will go spend that money somewhere else.  (Which creates even more jobs and stimulates the economy.)

3rd.  Your donation will help build the premier platform for artist, crafters, and arts organizations to promote and distribute their stuff.  This means that they will create another revenue stream for themselves  which in-turn will multiply also….(Creating jobs and stimulating the economy even more.)

4th. When you make a donation you will also receive a reward or perk and someone has to make those perks.  So the manufactures (who make the perks) will pay their employees to make the rewards, possibly have to hire more people to keep up with demand and thus stimulate the economy even more.

5th. Last but not least is the impact those will feel when they use the site.  They might find some amazing inspirational video that seems to answer all the questions about life they had, or someone might be able to reach a new contact and collaborate on a new awesome project, or maybe an up and coming artist in France could start to develop a huge following in Brazil.

The possibilities for the impact of your donation are limitless, but it does seem that you will help bring art, entertainment, and culture to those who need and want it most… and at the same time possibly solve a major economic problem too.
Seems like a no brainer.  Really great perks and really great outcomes.
Please pick your perk to the right and make a donation.
Other Ways You Can Help
There are multiple ways you can help besides making a monetary contribution.
1st.  Join the site at www.spinbliss.com
2nd. After joining the site stop by the Spinbliss profile page and tell us what you think.
3rd.  Promote this campaign on your other social media sites such as Facebook, Google+, and linkedin
4th.  Please tell everyone you know about our campaign and our soon to be great website.
And hey, thank you so much.  Your donation literally means the world to us.
Check out the details of the perks.
Mercury Descends.

<h2 style=""font-size: 1.17em
column2: >Check out the video above for an introduction to us and some of the puppets that want to come to DC!

column1: <h3 style=""font-size: 1.17em
column2: >In response to certain remarks about Big Bird made by candidate Mitt Romney in the first presidential debate of 2012 there has been a call for a Million Puppet March on Washington DC on November 3rd. This started as a Million Muppet March but was later expanded to be inclusive of all puppetkind and their allies.

column1: <h3 style=""font-size: 1.17em
column2: >The People's Puppets* (the Occupy Wall Street Puppet Guild) are trying to get to DC to show the Corporate Puppets (Politicians) that we don't take kindly to anyone threatening to cut funding for PBS.

column1: <h3 style=""font-size: 1.17em
column2: >Not only is it important to us to stand up for the future of Public Broadcasting but we are also excited about the opportunity to meet and network with other radical puppetry groups from around the country! We hope to make lasting connections and also organize workshops and skillshares around puppetry as activism.

column1: <h3 style=""font-size: 1.17em
column2: >Though this event was inspired by comments made by Romney, OWS is a nonpartisan movement and we are going to show our support to all puppetkind and make it clear that anyone, no matter their party, will be met with resistance to the idea of cutting Public Broadcasting.

column1: From their website the mission of the Million Puppet March is:

We believe in public media.  We believe that a strong public broadcasting system builds a stronger nation.  And we believe that it is essential to provide adequate federal funding to our public broadcasters.

Through federal financial support, we the people of this great nation demonstrate our commitment to providing all Americans, regardless of their location or economic situation, free access to the best quality educational and cultural programming available anywhere, improving learning outcomes, increasing cultural awareness, and informing our electorate.

Through community events and social media, Million Puppet March seeks to increase awareness of the importance of federal funding to our public broadcasting system and to promote broad based support for its continuation.

column2: >*The People's Puppets of Occupy Wall Street is a collective of puppeteers and artists from many disciplines who pool their inspiration, energy and resources to spread Occupy Wall Street's core message of economic and social justice. Using art's unique power to envision other worlds and explore sustainable alternatives, The People's Puppets have created hundreds of puppets for Occupy gatherings and in solidarity with allied organizations, community groups, and unions since October 2011.

column1: <h3><span class=""Apple-style-span"" style=""font-size: 12px
<div>

The $1000 covers renting two large vans, one cargo van for the puppets and one 15 passenger van for the puppeteers, as well as gas, travel expenses, and materials for workshops. If there is any left over money it will be used to buy supplies for building more new wonderful puppets.

We have some fun and exciting puppet related rewards, including your very own baby debt monster, a tour of the puppet lair, or even a puppet made specifically for your cause and more to be listed in coming days!
<div>
The Impact

This is an incredible opportunity to spread an important message in a really fun and accessible way and also for us to meet and organize with other puppeteers from around the country! This is part of puppet history!
Also, if there is a Million Puppet March and the People's Puppets aren't there it would just be wrong. And you don't want things to be wrong, do you?
<div>
Other Ways You Can Help

Even a dollar helps get us closer to our goal, but we understand not everyone has a dollar to spare. If you're financialy disabled and can't donate money, please spread the word about this and encourage others with the means to donate to do so. If you can get someone else to donate $20 that's even better than you giving us $1. Tell your friends! Tell your acquaintances!
","Check out the video above for an introduction to us and some of the puppets that want to come to DC!

In response to certain remarks about Big Bird made by candidate Mitt Romney in the first presidential debate of 2012 there has been a call for a Million Puppet March on Washington DC on November 3rd. This started as a Million Muppet March but was later expanded to be inclusive of all puppetkind and their allies.
The People's Puppets* (the Occupy Wall Street Puppet Guild) are trying to get to DC to show the Corporate Puppets (Politicians) that we don't take kindly to anyone threatening to cut funding for PBS.

Not only is it important to us to stand up for the future of Public Broadcasting but we are also excited about the opportunity to meet and network with other radical puppetry groups from around the country! We hope to make lasting connections and also organize workshops and skillshares around puppetry as activism.

Though this event was inspired by comments made by Romney, OWS is a nonpartisan movement and we are going to show our support to all puppetkind and make it clear that anyone, no matter their party, will be met with resistance to the idea of cutting Public Broadcasting.
From their website the mission of the Million Puppet March is:

We believe in public media.  We believe that a strong public broadcasting system builds a stronger nation.  And we believe that it is essential to provide adequate federal funding to our public broadcasters.

Through federal financial support, we the people of this great nation demonstrate our commitment to providing all Americans, regardless of their location or economic situation, free access to the best quality educational and cultural programming available anywhere, improving learning outcomes, increasing cultural awareness, and informing our electorate.

Through community events and social media, Million Puppet March seeks to increase awareness of the importance of federal funding to our public broadcasting system and to promote broad based support for its continuation.

*The People's Puppets of Occupy Wall Street is a collective of puppeteers and artists from many disciplines who pool their inspiration, energy and resources to spread Occupy Wall Street's core message of economic and social justice. Using art's unique power to envision other worlds and explore sustainable alternatives, The People's Puppets have created hundreds of puppets for Occupy gatherings and in solidarity with allied organizations, community groups, and unions since October 2011.
What We Need & What You Get

The $1000 covers renting two large vans, one cargo van for the puppets and one 15 passenger van for the puppeteers, as well as gas, travel expenses, and materials for workshops. If there is any left over money it will be used to buy supplies for building more new wonderful puppets.

We have some fun and exciting puppet related rewards, including your very own baby debt monster, a tour of the puppet lair, or even a puppet made specifically for your cause and more to be listed in coming days!
The Impact

This is an incredible opportunity to spread an important message in a really fun and accessible way and also for us to meet and organize with other puppeteers from around the country! This is part of puppet history!
Also, if there is a Million Puppet March and the People's Puppets aren't there it would just be wrong. And you don't want things to be wrong, do you?
Other Ways You Can Help

Even a dollar helps get us closer to our goal, but we understand not everyone has a dollar to spare. If you're financialy disabled and can't donate money, please spread the word about this and encourage others with the means to donate to do so. If you can get someone else to donate $20 that's even better than you giving us $1. Tell your friends! Tell your acquaintances!",0.0,0,"1 Campaign
|","New York, United States",https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/ows-puppet-guild-goes-to-the-million-puppet-march/pica

A Little About Us

I am a print-maker living at Milepost 5, a community for creatives in Portland, Oregon.  150 artists, writers, film makers, and musicians  live, work, and create together here in an historic, slate-roofed mannor.  As emerging artists, resources are hard to come by, so we rely on eachother and share resources (for example, the video for this campaign was put together by a film-maker in the building, earlier this year, my dog appeared in one of his projects).

All of us came here to launch or advance our creative careers.  In order to do that, we need to be able to produce engaging and graphicly pleasing promotional materials, book covers, CD jackets, flyers, and posters.  We have made-do with a cobbled together, single color screen printing set-up untill now, but to do this thing right, we need the right equipment.
<div>
What We Need

In order to create the visually striking book covers, CD sleaves, posters, broadsides, and fine art prints necessary to make our collective mark, we need a Four Color Silk Screen Press.  Buying a new, commerially made press could cost
column3: products_id=1231"" rel=""noopener nofollow"">thousands of dollars,  but we have the skills and tools to build one for $500.  Thats where YOU come in: one contribution from you supports the careers of over a hundrad artists!

column1: $500 is the bare minimum we need to make this happen.  Any additional funds raised, above the cost of building the press, will go towards essentials such as emulsion, ink, and paying for the space where the press will be located.  Additional funding will also allow us to make the press available to local schools and community groups. This is a project that never stops giving!
<div>
The Impact
With your help, we will be able to make everything from promotional items to fine art prints  ~in technocolor!  Your donation will help not just one person, but
column2: >a hundrad and fifty, to live and thrive from their creative process. Your donation ensures our continued ability to pursue creative endevors and ability to reach our full potential.
>Having a four-color press will also enhance our ability to serve our community partners: the schools, community groups, and non-profits with whome we collaborate and create.
>With one contribution, you do a world of good!

column1: <div>
What if you have no money to spare?
Sometimes you just can’t contribute, believe me I get it, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help:
Make Some Noise About This Project

Tweet this page to your followers, post about it on Facebook, blog about it, Tumblr it, do whatever you can to spread the word! The more people hear about this and see this page, the greater the chance that it reaches those who can contribute!
In-kind Donations

If you are in a possition to donate silkscreening supplies, or materials for building the press, we would LOVE to talk to you about that! In-kind donations could dramatically reduce the cost of this project and allow us to do more.  You can get in touch at twohandsstudio@gmail.com
","A Little About Us

I am a print-maker living at Milepost 5, a community for creatives in Portland, Oregon.  150 artists, writers, film makers, and musicians  live, work, and create together here in an historic, slate-roofed mannor.  As emerging artists, resources are hard to come by, so we rely on eachother and share resources (for example, the video for this campaign was put together by a film-maker in the building, earlier this year, my dog appeared in one of his projects).

All of us came here to launch or advance our creative careers.  In order to do that, we need to be able to produce engaging and graphicly pleasing promotional materials, book covers, CD jackets, flyers, and posters.  We have made-do with a cobbled together, single color screen printing set-up untill now, but to do this thing right, we need the right equipment.
What We Need

In order to create the visually striking book covers, CD sleaves, posters, broadsides, and fine art prints necessary to make our collective mark, we need a Four Color Silk Screen Press.  Buying a new, commerially made press could cost  thousands of dollars,  but we have the skills and tools to build one for $500.  Thats where YOU come in: one contribution from you supports the careers of over a hundrad artists!

$500 is the bare minimum we need to make this happen.  Any additional funds raised, above the cost of building the press, will go towards essentials such as emulsion, ink, and paying for the space where the press will be located.  Additional funding will also allow us to make the press available to local schools and community groups. This is a project that never stops giving!
The Impact

With your help, we will be able to make everything from promotional items to fine art prints  ~in technocolor!  Your donation will help not just one person, but a hundrad and fifty, to live and thrive from their creative process. Your donation ensures our continued ability to pursue creative endevors and ability to reach our full potential.
Having a four-color press will also enhance our ability to serve our community partners: the schools, community groups, and non-profits with whome we collaborate and create.
With one contribution, you do a world of good!
What if you have no money to spare?
Sometimes you just can’t contribute, believe me I get it, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help:
Make Some Noise About This Project

Tweet this page to your followers, post about it on Facebook, blog about it, Tumblr it, do whatever you can to spread the word! The more people hear about this and see this page, the greater the chance that it reaches those who can contribute!
In-kind Donations

If you are in a possition to donate silkscreening supplies, or materials for building the press, we would LOVE to talk to you about that! In-kind donations could dramatically reduce the cost of this project and allow us to do more.  You can get in touch at twohandsstudio@gmail.com",0.0,0,"1 Campaign

0,"<div class=""routerContentStory-storyBody"" data-v-1df7bf5a=""""><div>
Thanks so much for taking the time to check out our project. Here at Spark Box Studio we are on a mission to expand our community printshop.

Over the past three years Spark Box Studio has opened its doors to welcome hundreds of artists, arts enthusiasts, and youth to use the printmaking equipment. The studio moved into its new location in 2011 and is ready to enter a new phase. There has always been something missing from our space, a special bit of printmaking that everyone can enjoy– letterpress.

We are creating a campaign to purchase a beautiful letterpress studio from Lock's Press located in Kingston, Ontario. Once we have completed this project we can share our movable type and photo polymer plate equipment with local community members, workshop attendees and our visiting artists. This equipment will open the doors to self-publishers of zines, newsletters, comics, books, and more.

This is where you come in! We need to raise $6,000 to make this next big change. With your donations, Spark Box Studio can take the next giant leap into the world of letterpress. Think about it this way if everyone of our Facebook, Twitter and Blog followers donated just $10.00 each we would meet our goal.
If we were to exceed our goal the additional money will go towards outfitting this new part of the studio with any additional requirements, including a new set of rollers.

INTERESTED IN KNOWING MORE?

With this funding we will be adding an entire letterpress studio to our shop. Here is what will be included:

Vandercook SP-15, serial #29667, bed 15”wide, 17 ¾” to dead area.
1 lead cutter

","Thanks so much for taking the time to check out our project. Here at Spark Box Studio we are on a mission to expand our community printshop.

Over the past three years Spark Box Studio has opened its doors to welcome hundreds of artists, arts enthusiasts, and youth to use the printmaking equipment. The studio moved into its new location in 2011 and is ready to enter a new phase. There has always been something missing from our space, a special bit of printmaking that everyone can enjoy– letterpress. We are creating a campaign to purchase a beautiful letterpress studio from Lock's Press located in Kingston, Ontario. Once we have completed this project we can share our movable type and photo polymer plate equipment with local community members, workshop attendees and our visiting artists. This equipment will open the doors to self-publishers of zines, newsletters, comics, books, and more.

This is where you come in! We need to raise $6,000 to make this next big change. With your donations, Spark Box Studio can take the next giant leap into the world of letterpress. Think about it this way if everyone of our Facebook, Twitter and Blog followers donated just $10.00 each we would meet our goal.
If we were to exceed our goal the additional money will go towards outfitting this new part of the studio with any additional requirements, including a new set of rollers.

INTERESTED IN KNOWING MORE?With this funding we will be adding an entire letterpress studio to our shop. Here is what will be included:Vandercook SP-15, serial #29667, bed 15”wide, 17 ¾” to dead area.1 lead cutter 1 Rouse & Co lead shaver (also cuts mitres) for leads up to 10 ½” long: 18 x 13 x 8” high 9 quoins + 3 on a 10” long bar + a quoin key6 ink spatulas 1 glass inking slab on a cheap wooden cabinet 16 x 19 ¾” x 28” high 1 woodblock (4 ½ x 8 ¾ x 1 7/8”) (for checking that type sitting on feet) + mallet Up to 5 chases Up to 11 galleys
Furniture:large amount in cutlery trays

Short Summary
<div class=""wp-caption alignright"" id=""attachment_2294"" style=""width: 178px
Quilt by Doris Prouty
Introduction

I am Torreah ""Cookie"" Washington, curator of Mermaids and Merwomen in Black Folklore: A Fiber Arts Exhibition, which features the works of over fifty of the country’s premiere African-American fiber artists including internationally known artists Dr. Edward Bostic,  Donna Chambers, Marion Coleman, Arianne King Comer, Michael Cummings, Dr. Deborah Grayson, Dr. Myra Brown Green, Dr. Kim Hall, and Patricia Montgomery.  These artists come together to weave a journey of color and inspiration and to tell the tales of these legendary merfolk.
An accompanying catalogue, Black Mermaids: In Vision and Verse, invites you to celebrate the relationship between fine craft and poetic verse. The exhibtion dates are:
Mermaids and Merwomen in Black Folklore: A Fiber Arts Exhibition at the City Gallery at Waterfront Park in Charleston, South Carolina.
Exhibiton Opening and Artist Reception, Saturday, September 8, 2012,  5:00-8:00 p.m.
<div><strong>What We Need &amp
<div>

We need to raise funds to pay for transportation and lecturer fees for scholar and African art historian Dr. Henry John Drewal.  There is also a need for additional funds to offset costs related to opening weekend events.
Our Perks include:
<ul>
• original mermaid sculpture by Everttte White
• Italian, hand blown glass pendants
• Michael Cummings signed Haitian Mermaid poster
• Book: autographed copies of Mami Wata by Dr. Drewal
• Donna Chambers Cameo and earrings
• Exhibition Note Cards with Mermaid Stamps
• Book: Black Mermaids in Vision and Verse
• Complete Mermaid Swag Gift set
The Impact
<div>

This exhibit is as much about celebration as it is about re-imaging ourselves as women and girls.  Just think what it would do in the psyches of young girls to see the black faces of mermaids and perhaps find a source of empowerment that asks them to think of themselves in larger dimensions beyond the currrent sterotype of the ""hoochie mama"".
Other Ways You Can Help
<div>

We have two months to make a difference! While you may not be able to contribute, please take a moment and share this campaign far and wide with friends on Facebook and the world.  Please do spread the word!!
Thank you! Thank you!

0,"<div class=""routerContentStory-storyBody"" data-v-1df7bf5a=""""><div>
Who We Are

The Workshop for Community Arts is a community-based and artist-run organization located in Santa Ana that facilitates creative workshops and events.  With expertise in creative writing, visual art, music, and community organizing, we use our experience, resources, and craft to engage in collaborative art-making and create opportunities for people to share their stories.
The Project

Cartonera Cartography (Aug 4th-18th) is a community art project which brings artists and residents together in collaboration to create – by means of writing, photography, art, and cardboard – a cartonera “guidebook” of Santa Ana. In a series of workshops, participants will explore and document the places and experiences that, for them, represent the “essence” of Santa Ana: What do I see that you do not see? What do I love about this city and have never told anyone? Cartonera bookmaking is a form which first began in Latin America and which invites active community participation in the process of making and publishing books, a process which thereby promotes accessibility, creativity, and self-sufficiency, as well as environmental responsibility by using recycled materials. With the guidance of Nicole Cecilia Delgado, an internationally-recognized cartonera artist (hear her talk about cartonera here ), participants will see their words and ideas come to life. They will be trained in cartonera bookmaking, resulting in the publication and distribution of over 120 handmade guidebooks throughout Santa Ana. The final “guidebook” about the city Santa Ana will be a community document – created by, for, with, and in the community.
<div>
<h3>What We Need &amp

We're trying to raise $1,500 to help cover the costs of the Cartonera Cartography.  And, realistically, this only covers part of what it takes to put on this kind of event.  We've had many generous donations of time, talent, and supplies.  BUT there are still things that we have to pay for, and that's where this fundraising drive comes in.  Your donation on this website will help for travel expenses to get our amazing guest artist from Puerto Rico (where she runs Atarray Cartonera) to Santa Ana, California.  And for bookmaking supplies -- because we can't make books without'em!
And we have some really nice handmade thank-you gifts which we will send you if you donate at the following levels:
<ul>
• For $5 dollars, show your support for art in the community and in return we offer our profound gratitude!
• An artist-designed hand-stenciled cartonera postcard in your mailbox! for a $25 donation.
• A cartonera guidebook created in the workshops! for a $50 donation.
• An awesome screenprinted t-shirt with the Cartonera Cartography logo! for a $100 donation.
• The t-shirt plus the guidebook! for a $150 donation.
• And for $175 and up, you can have it all -- the postcard, the book, and the t-shirt.
<div>
Other Ways You Can Help
You can also get inolved by donating supplies, attending the final event, or even applying to take part in the workshops.  Go to our website for more info.

0,"<div class=""routerContentStory-storyBody"" data-v-1df7bf5a=""""><div>

I would like to introduce you to my father, Vince Semary.  He is the greatest man I know.  My father is an accomplished artist, teacher, business man, football player and coach.  He began his life as one of three sons of immigrant parents from Italy and Sicily.  Vince grew up in the inner city of Cleveland, Ohio in the 1940's and '50's, a time he looks back on with great fondness.  Stories of working for Uncle Joe, the shoemaker, hopping trains along Train Avenue to go downtown with his pals to visit the Cleveland Museum of Art where lessons were free, afternoons filled with playing outdoors
column2: cornerlot baseball, football, wrestling and exploring trainyards and alleys, and a mother whose sole purpose in life was to make her sons and husband happy, fill my father's memories.  It was a time of innocence, of discovery, of hope and dreams.  Dreams, that at times, seemed out of reach, given his poor performance in school.

column1: While he didn't shine brightly in the classroom, he loved to draw.  His third grade teacher began calling him ""Michaelangelo"" and sent him off to paint murals throughout the school, boosting his self-confidence.

Fortunately, there was West Tech High School, an early prototype of a magnet school.  It offered him the opportunity to major in art, receiving thorough training as well as preparation for college.  Vince majored in art and played football, two things he had always felt passionate about.

""The art was there for me.  I was able to find my way through it.  The art department was very diversified and we were provided with a strong commercial background.  But I loved football, too. It was the best of both worlds.  I had a great senior year and, although I lacked the English credits to go to a Big Ten school, I was recruited by Don Schula and accepted by the University of Kentucky on a scholarship. Blanton Collier was coaching at the time, so it was a perfect opportunity.

""I found myself totally lost in art, however.  It was the early sixties and the universities were becoming the mainstream for avant-garde art.  My background was so concrete, that when we were assigned a garden to draw, mine was the only one with recognizable trees, bushes and pathways.  The others were completely abstract. I was told my grade would be affected if I couldn't grasp the concept of abstract expressionism.

""As the end of my term approached, I had five paintings to do in two weeks and a C- average.  In frustration, I went out on the town with my football buddies.  When we got back, we all picked up brushes and did the paintings.  You can imagine what they looked like, but I turned them in and, to my astonishment, the professor raved about them, gave me an A, and said I'd finally grasped the expression of the inner self!  I've laughed about that many times over the years, but the experience did help me to develop a more complex approach to my art"".

After earning his Master's Degree, Vince taught art and coached football at many high schools and universities, finally landing a job at Rice University, which brought him to Houston, Tx. in 1976.  Football and art were a comfortable balance until 1979, when he took an art class from a talented 18-year-old who reintroduced him to watercolors.
The following year, an admirer of his art commissioned him to produce twenty-four paintings in twelve months, and he's been painting professionally ever since.

In 1978, Vince left coaching and he and his wife Susan opened a gallery in Kingwood, The Shadow Box Gallery, where he taught art and painted.  ""I think like an athlete.  I accept the challenge of coming up with the perfect performance.  Here it's paint across paper instead of a ball across a field.  The goal is still the same.  I want people to like what I do"".

For 34 years now, my father and mother have been in business, and as with all small businesses have seen prosperous times and hard times.  The last four years they have been hit hard by the economic downturn our country has been in and by mounting bills and expenses to keep the business doors open.  Facing retirement with a mound of debt is stressful to say the least.  Meanwhile, the gallery is full of beautiful original paintings by my father and stacks of prints.

In an effort to help them with the debt and move some of this gorgeous work, and share with the world the talent of Vince Semary, we are asking for your donations in return for his work.  For each level of donations, you will receive a beautiful print, set of prints, or at the highest level of donations, an original commissioned art work of your choice of subject matter.

You will receive the artwork, and we will receive the funds to help pay off mounting debt and the hope for a peaceful retirement for two people who have worked hard their whole lives to bring beauty into the world through art.  There could be no greater gift than peace of mind for these small business owners who have lived a life of passion and purpose to do something good in this world and provide for their family.
<div>

In order to make a dent in the debt, we need at least $20,000 to pay off creditors.  But, the money you give will get you a beautiful print that you cannot purchase anywhere else but here.  (Please see slideshow to view prints)

At the $10 level, you will be able to choose from a variety of pencil drawing prints by the artist.  These are 5 1/4"" x 7"" prints of the original artwork he did for the Kingwood book, which was published in 1981. They are
column2: Deer on the Golf Course, Wild Bull, Fire Station, Trails End, Boat Docks and Cypress Trees.  Kingwood is a master planned community northeast of Houston and the City of Humble.  Kingwood is known as ""The Livable Forest"" and has so much beauty everywhere you look, that it inspired this gorgeous book of pencil drawings and history of the community.  The book has long since been out of print, but the prints from the book are still available to buy and frame.

column1: At the $25 level, you will receive a small Window of Art History print, with an image size approximately 14"" x 16"".  This is a print of a compilation drawing Vince made of all the great periods and styles in art.  It features works from the 1880's to the 20th century.  You will also receive a list of all the artists, styles, and periods included in the print.
At the $75 level, you will receive a large Window of Art History print, which has an approximate image size of 18"" x 20"".
At the $100 level, you will receive one of the (Humble) Good Oil Days prints of your choosing
column2: Good Oil Days (features a lightening storm) and has an approx. image size of 18"" x 24"", The Humble Depot, with an approx. image size of 14"" x 21"", Main Street 1908, with an approx. image size of 15"" x 21 1/2"", and Mary Stanley Bath House, which has an approx. image size of 10"" x 25"". These were a series of paintings Vince did in commemoration of the Humble Good Oil Days from 1981-1984.The following is a brief history of Humble, Tx.

>Just before the Civil War, a wandering fisherman named P.S. (Pleasant) Humble brought his family into the area. They settled on the banks of the San Jacinto River and operated a ferry near the present U.S. 59 crossing. A flood drove his family away from the river in search of higher ground. Soon a small community began forming in the area.

>A pioneer oil boom town. Originated as crossroads community named for settler Pleasant Smith Humble (1835?-1912), who lived here before 1889, hewing his timber into railroad ties, mining gravel from his land, keeping store, and serving as justice of the peace.

>Economic bases were farms and sawmills. The post office opened 1902. In 1904 C. E. Barrett (1866-1926) drilled for oil in this area, securing small production on Moonshine Hill. On Jan. 7, 1905, he brought in the No. 2 Beaty Well which yielded 8,500 barrels a day, opening the great boom. From a village of 700, Humble grew at once into a town of 20,000. Field production-- the largest in Texas for the year 1905-- was 15,594,923 barrels of oil. The field was named for the town. A group of its operators, including Ross S. Sterling, later (1931-33) governor of Texas, in 1911 incorporated a new oil company named for the field, The Humble Oil Company, thus spreading into the annals of world commerce the town's name. Production from several strata here exceeded the total for fabulous Spindletop by 1946. Known as the greatest salt dome field, Humble still produces and the town for which it was named continued to thrive.

>The Humble Oil Company's name was changed to Exxon two decades ago. The opening of Houston Intercontinental Airport was a major local growth catalyst on the late 1960's. Located less than five miles from Humble, this event stimulated development throughout Houston's north side. Soon, subdivision development was initiated nearby. The resultant growth started a transformation of the City of Humble and the surrounding rural homestead areas. Kingwood, Forest Cove, Northshire, Atascocita, Eagle Springs, Summerwood, The Commons of Lake Houston just to name a few.

column1: At the $125 level, you will receive your choice of one of the Four Seasons prints
column2: Winters Pink Blossoms, Summertime Nesting, Springtime in the Meadows, and The Passage of Fall.  Approximate image size of all prints is 19 1/2 "" x 27"".

column1: At the $500 level, you will receive the complete set of all four Four Seasons prints.

At the $1000 level, you will receive a commissioned original watercolor painting on a full sheet (22"" x 28"") of the subject matter of your choice (message artist through Facebook page to discuss details).

All funds raised will go to paying off debt, even if we do not reach our entire goal, your generosity will aid us in moving through this financial crisis and moving out some of this beautiful art, and sharing my father's talent with the world!

Even if you can't help financially at this time, please share this page with your friends and family, using the Indiegogo share tools!  Maybe someone you know is looking to furnish their first home, their office or is re-decorating their home.  These are prints that you will only find here and available at The Shadow Box Gallery in Kingwood, Tx.  Don't miss this opportunity to own this beautiful artwork and help these struggling small business owners out of debt at the end of their career. Thank you for your help!
To contact Vince, send him a message on Facebook
http://www.facebook.com/vince.semary
