I was told my grade would be affected if I couldn't grasp the concept of abstract expressionism.

As the end of my term approached, I had five paintings to do in two weeks and a C- average.  In frustration, I went out on the town with my football buddies.  When we got back, we all picked up brushes and did the paintings.  You can imagine what they looked like, but I turned them in and, to my astonishment, the professor raved about them, gave me an A, and said I'd finally grasped the expression of the inner self!  I've laughed about that many times over the years, but the experience did help me to develop a more complex approach to my art"".

After earning his Master's Degree, Vince taught art and coached football at many high schools and universities, finally landing a job at Rice University, which brought him to Houston, Tx. in 1976.  Football and art were a comfortable balance until 1979, when he took an art class from a talented 18-year-old who reintroduced him to watercolors.
The following year, an admirer of his art commissioned him to produce twenty-four paintings in twelve months, and he's been painting professionally ever since.

In 1978, Vince left coaching and he and his wife Susan opened a gallery in Kingwood, The Shadow Box Gallery, where he taught art and painted.  ""I think like an athlete.  I accept the challenge of coming up with the perfect performance.  Here it's paint across paper instead of a ball across a field.  The goal is still the same.  I want people to like what I do"".

For 34 years now, my father and mother have been in business, and as with all small businesses have seen prosperous times and hard times.  The last four years they have been hit hard by the economic downturn our country has been in and by mounting bills and expenses to keep the business doors open.  Facing retirement with a mound of debt is stressful to say the least.  Meanwhile, the gallery is full of beautiful original paintings by my father and stacks of prints.

In an effort to help them with the debt and move some of this gorgeous work, and share with the world the talent of Vince Semary, we are asking for your donations in return for his work.  For each level of donations, you will receive a beautiful print, set of prints, or at the highest level of donations, an original commissioned art work of your choice of subject matter.

You will receive the artwork, and we will receive the funds to help pay off mounting debt and the hope for a peaceful retirement for two people who have worked hard their whole lives to bring beauty into the world through art.  There could be no greater gift than peace of mind for these small business owners who have lived a life of passion and purpose to do something good in this world and provide for their family.

In order to make a dent in the debt, we need at least $20,000 to pay off creditors.  But, the money you give will get you a beautiful print that you cannot purchase anywhere else but here.  (Please see slideshow to view prints)

At the $10 level, you will be able to choose from a variety of pencil drawing prints by the artist.  These are 5 1/4"" x 7"" prints of the original artwork he did for the Kingwood book, which was published in 1981. They are
column2: Deer on the Golf Course, Wild Bull, Fire Station, Trails End, Boat Docks and Cypress Trees.  Kingwood is a master planned community northeast of Houston and the City of Humble.  Kingwood is known as ""The Livable Forest"" and has so much beauty everywhere you look, that it inspired this gorgeous book of pencil drawings and history of the community.  The book has long since been out of print, but the prints from the book are still available to buy and frame.

column1: At the $25 level, you will receive a small Window of Art History print, with an image size approximately 14"" x 16"".  This is a print of a compilation drawing Vince made of all the great periods and styles in art.  It features works from the 1880's to the 20th century.  You will also receive a list of all the artists, styles, and periods included in the print.
At the $75 level, you will receive a large Window of Art History print, which has an approximate image size of 18"" x 20"".
At the $100 level, you will receive one of the (Humble) Good Oil Days prints of your choosing
column2: Good Oil Days (features a lightening storm) and has an approx. image size of 18"" x 24"", The Humble Depot, with an approx. image size of 14"" x 21"", Main Street 1908, with an approx. image size of 15"" x 21 1/2"", and Mary Stanley Bath House, which has an approx. image size of 10"" x 25"". These were a series of paintings Vince did in commemoration of the Humble Good Oil Days from 1981-1984.The following is a brief history of Humble, Tx.

column1: Just before the Civil War, a wandering fisherman named P.S. (Pleasant) Humble brought his family into the area. They settled on the banks of the San Jacinto River and operated a ferry near the present U.S. 59 crossing. A flood drove his family away from the river in search of higher ground. Soon a small community began forming in the area.

A pioneer oil boom town. Originated as crossroads community named for settler Pleasant Smith Humble (1835?-1912), who lived here before 1889, hewing his timber into railroad ties, mining gravel from his land, keeping store, and serving as justice of the peace.

Economic bases were farms and sawmills. The post office opened 1902. In 1904 C. E. Barrett (1866-1926) drilled for oil in this area, securing small production on Moonshine Hill. On Jan. 7, 1905, he brought in the No. 2 Beaty Well which yielded 8,500 barrels a day, opening the great boom. From a village of 700, Humble grew at once into a town of 20,000. Field production-- the largest in Texas for the year 1905-- was 15,594,923 barrels of oil. The field was named for the town. A group of its operators, including Ross S. Sterling, later (1931-33) governor of Texas, in 1911 incorporated a new oil company named for the field, The Humble Oil Company, thus spreading into the annals of world commerce the town's name. Production from several strata here exceeded the total for fabulous Spindletop by 1946. Known as the greatest salt dome field, Humble still produces and the town for which it was named continued to thrive.

The Humble Oil Company's name was changed to Exxon two decades ago. The opening of Houston Intercontinental Airport was a major local growth catalyst on the late 1960's. Located less than five miles from Humble, this event stimulated development throughout Houston's north side. Soon, subdivision development was initiated nearby. The resultant growth started a transformation of the City of Humble and the surrounding rural homestead areas. Kingwood, Forest Cove, Northshire, Atascocita, Eagle Springs, Summerwood, The Commons of Lake Houston just to name a few.
At the $125 level, you will receive your choice of one of the Four Seasons prints
column2: Winters Pink Blossoms, Summertime Nesting, Springtime in the Meadows, and The Passage of Fall.  Approximate image size of all prints is 19 1/2 "" x 27"".

column1: At the $500 level, you will receive the complete set of all four Four Seasons prints.

At the $1000 level, you will receive a commissioned original watercolor painting on a full sheet (22"" x 28"") of the subject matter of your choice (message artist through Facebook page to discuss details).

All funds raised will go to paying off debt, even if we do not reach our entire goal, your generosity will aid us in moving through this financial crisis and moving out some of this beautiful art, and sharing my father's talent with the world!

Even if you can't help financially at this time, please share this page with your friends and family, using the Indiegogo share tools!  Maybe someone you know is looking to furnish their first home, their office or is re-decorating their home.  These are prints that you will only find here and available at The Shadow Box Gallery in Kingwood, Tx.  Don't miss this opportunity to own this beautiful artwork and help these struggling small business owners out of debt at the end of their career. Thank you for your help!
To contact Vince, send him a message on Facebook
http://www.facebook.com/vince.semary",0.0,0,"1 Campaign

<h2 style=""margin-left: 180px
<div>

My New Years resolution for this year was to create ninjas for my shop. Previously, I had not really delved into doing such but for someone who really loves ninjas I felt that my shop was seriously deprived of them. In December of 2011, I sent off designs of my very first batch of laser cut arcylic charms to a laser cut supplier. One of them contained my very first ninja design.

In Feburary of this year, I bought my first Tecre button machine. One of my earliest button designs was (you guseed it) of a ninja. Since I have a bit of a soft spot for ninjas and cute things, I figured the latter out and then began to create even more ninja-related items that included clay forms too.
<h2 style=""margin-left: 90px
""THE MANY FACES OF A NINJA""

Over the summer, I released a series that titled ""The Many Faces of a Ninja."" This series has so far been very well received among many of my supporters. The series contains eight ninjas and their various forms of faces. They are very simply designed, but I intended to keep it that way since I believe that eyes can tell a plethora of stories by themselves.
MY GOAL

My objective is to raise $600. This amount is the minimum that I need to cover expenses to order the supplies needed for my project. I plan to order all eight ninja designs as vinyl stickers and 1"" inch laser cut charms.
My supplies include laser cut charms, jewelry components, vinyl stickers, the supplies for pinback buttons, printer ink, chain, cell phone charms, and key rings. All of this comes to around my goal.
<div>
Any additional that could be raised will help fund rewards for my project and will enable me to order even more supplies!

The campaign has ended
Thank you all for contributing! It has been a whirlwind 2.5 months, and even though we haven't reached the ultimate goal, you've all made a huge difference!

Even though the campaign is over, of course it's only the beginning for the Entoforms. Keep an eye on the official website, and feel free to contact me in case you'd like to purchase one (or several).
Thanks also to those who retweeted my messages, you've all really helped. And congratulations to Eduardo from Mexico City for winning his very own unique Entoform!
Thanks again!
Dolf (macouno)
What's the deal?

This campaign will fund the creation, and exhibition of a series of limited issue, highly collectible, art pieces called Entoforms. They are artificial life, generated in the computer, printed in 3d, grown, and collected by macouno.
Visit the project's website: http://www.entoforms.com
Visit macouno's website: http://www.macouno.com
What I need money for
Making art takes an investment of not only time but also money. Not only for final production, but also for lots, and lots of testing. Here is a rundown of the costs involved in this project.
<ul>
<li>
Half of the budget has been reserved for the creation of my gifts to you!
<li>

3D printing
Printing in 3D is still a very new technology. It is really quite cool, but it's not yet cheap, especially in the more exotic materials (Sterling silver for instance). It starts at $1.- and goes up to as much as $20.- per cubic centimetre.
<li>

Presentation supplies
Boxes, labels, pins, and such all have to be ordered from specialist Entomology suppliers. The boxes have to seal properly, the labels have to be acid free, and the pins rust proof.
<li>

Various art, and office supplies
Drills, pliers, drill bits, nails, stickers, paper, envelopes, boxes, postage stamps. In short... a multitude of items is required to take the Entoforms from a concept to a finished product.
<li>

Space rental
In august of 2011 the Entoforms will be exhibited in association with a renowned art gallery in Amsterdam. In this case part of the cost is covered by the gallery and part by the artists.
<li>

Foodstuffs
For the duration of the project, the artist has to be fed. This keeps him running at peak performance. Unfed he becomes grumpy, uninspired &
<div>
Giving back to the community

The Entoforms are created with custom/new python scripts in Blender 3D, an open source (free) program. These scripts (addons), are not only useful for this project, but in some cases the entire 3D community. All the scripts will be released to the on-line community.
<div>
Project timeline

column2: />I actually started working on the Entoforms back in January of 2011, and I foresee much more time than the span of this campaign being spent on them. The Campaign is here to fund the work's continuation during 2011, and at least 2 art exhibits within that year. The deadline is on the opening of the first exhibit of the Entoforms!

column1: If you want to follow the project, be sure to check out the blog. Every time a new generation of Entoforms has been grown, a blog post will be made detailing the progress. Many pictures and videos can be found there.
http://www.entoforms.com/news/
Thank you very much

Thank you ever so much for your consideration, and time. If you can not help out with the project yourself, please consider sharing a link to the project on facebook or twitter. The more people see this page, the bigger the chance that this campaign will be a success!
There are also two banner images available if you want to put a link to this campaign on your website.
<ul>
• vertical banner
• horizontal banner
Thank you for making this project possible!

0,"<div class=""routerContentStory-storyBody"" data-v-1df7bf5a=""""><div>
THE PROJECT

April 20 marks the two year anniversary since the biggest oil spill in history. In May I will spend eight days in exile on Horn Island in the Gulf of Mexico. There I will study the longer term effects of the BP spill. Afterwards there will be two exhibitions to raise awareness of the ongoing impact.

Why eight days? When I was a flight attendant. We had a mantra of survival. 3 minutes without air, 30 minutes of exposure, 3 days without water, 7 days without food. Eight days exceeds those numbers. It invokes resource management and supplies enough time to investigate and aquatint myself with the space. - Though I think Andy Goldsworthy would think it 3 or 4 years too short.It causes you to begin to understand and question what is necessary for survival and what is not. Everything I bring will be essential and have purpose for my life.

During the eight days, I will gather information on the islands current state, from found objects, flotsam and jetsam mostly, to making sketches and other documentation. I expect to find signs of the damage of human pollution, including but not limited to the recent gulf oil spill.

After I get back I will create works based on my experience and observations during my exile. These will be displayed in Seattle and Memphis, and will include community outreach events. The overall purpose of the outreach and artwork is to draw attention to the fact that our energy need puts at risk the worlds habitats, and can cause long term consequences.
THE ISLAND

Horn Island is an island within the Gulf Island National Seashore, that is only reachable by boat, and one of the barrier islands off the coast of Mississippi and Alabama. Getting to the island will require that I hire a private ferry. And I will live on the park in primitive camping conditions.
BIO
I am a visual artist who creates work from found and recycled objects.

Recently I have participated in Particles on the Wall in the Odegaard Undergraduate Library at the University of Washington. This is an interdisciplinary exhibit exploring the elements of the nuclear age, Hanford history, and its impacts on humans and the environment. This allows art to bring science to a new audience.
<div>
OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP
Make some noise. Tell people you are concerned about the lasting effect of the BP Oil Spill. Tell them about about this project, and the exhibition.

Summary

""The blacksmith and the artist 
Reflect it in their art 
Forge their creativity 
Closer to the heart""
-Rush
Hi, I'm Wade, I live in Manitoba with my beautiful girlfriend and amazing daughter.

I have a passion for history, and i love working with metal. The relative difficulty of working in this medium, in my humble opinion, is part of the reason it's so beautiful. Unfortunately, it's almost died as a craft, and that's a shame. As you can tell from the lyrics above, the blacksmith has had a pivotal role in society, if you wanted ANYTHING made of metal you had to visit the local blacksmith. This included all of your wrought iron fixtures, utensils, railings, decor and sculptures. Blacksmithing was both a trade and an art form, with the skills being passed down from Master to Apprentice and honed with hours of hard work to produce beautiful pieces of art.
As things are now, I have most of the basic hand tools and an antique coal forge bought from a local farmer but im still missing some of the necessities.
Help me follow my passion and keep this art form alive and forging ahead into the future! (See what I did there?)
What You're paying for:
<ul>
<li>
Weekend course with a Master $250
<li>
Various blacksmithing tools (vise, files, sander, and proper tongs) $250
• $500 dollars to donate to the Pembina Hills Art Center

Our Story
We are Spiral Fae Accents (Mitch &
column2: Amber) the fairies, or the mask people as we are known throughout these United States. We are known for our beautiful hand crafted leather masks and gemstone jewelery. It is our mission to keep "" hand made"" in the vocabulary of America. For the last four years we have traveled across the country selling our one of a kind artworks, sharing the beauty and happiness with so many people.

column1: You may have seen us at World of Fairies outside of Chicago, Fairie Worlds in Oregon, The Renaissance faire's of Missouri and Kansas or in the company of our beloved and talented musician friend S.J. Tucker.

We understand that this past year was the hardest it has ever been on every one. Gas prices being so high last year made it much harder to have anything in savings for this years start, and that is where you come in.
The Impact

You have a chance to really make an Impact in someones life. This is our 9-5 job. The success or failure of this campaign is real. This not only effects us but many other people as well. If this campaign fails we will have no income, no food and no way to pay our bills. The festivals we attend also employ hundreds, sometimes thousands of people. Without vendors like us most of these faire's would not be able to opperate and would have to shut down putting so many more people in this country out of work.
<h3>What We Need &amp
We only need $2,500 to make it through the entire year. Your donations will make it possible to get the first shows booked and traveled to, after that the shows take care of themselves.
Other Ways You Can Help

The other way you can totally make a HUGE difference in this world, get the word out. Shout it from the tops of the cyber mountains, post this link everywhere you can. If you love Cons, fests, art shows, craft shows, ETC... tell everyone. If you have never been to any of these, let your hair down and your creative side out and get out there , find out how much fun you can have and how bright and colorful the world really is.
","Our Story

We are Spiral Fae Accents (Mitch & Amber) the fairies, or the mask people as we are known throughout these United States. We are known for our beautiful hand crafted leather masks and gemstone jewelery. It is our mission to keep "" hand made"" in the vocabulary of America. For the last four years we have traveled across the country selling our one of a kind artworks, sharing the beauty and happiness with so many people.

You may have seen us at World of Fairies outside of Chicago, Fairie Worlds in Oregon, The Renaissance faire's of Missouri and Kansas or in the company of our beloved and talented musician friend S.J. Tucker.

We understand that this past year was the hardest it has ever been on every one. Gas prices being so high last year made it much harder to have anything in savings for this years start, and that is where you come in.
The Impact

You have a chance to really make an Impact in someones life. This is our 9-5 job. The success or failure of this campaign is real. This not only effects us but many other people as well. If this campaign fails we will have no income, no food and no way to pay our bills. The festivals we attend also employ hundreds, sometimes thousands of people. Without vendors like us most of these faire's would not be able to opperate and would have to shut down putting so many more people in this country out of work.
What We Need & What You Get
We only need $2,500 to make it through the entire year. Your donations will make it possible to get the first shows booked and traveled to, after that the shows take care of themselves.
Other Ways You Can Help

The other way you can totally make a HUGE difference in this world, get the word out. Shout it from the tops of the cyber mountains, post this link everywhere you can. If you love Cons, fests, art shows, craft shows, ETC... tell everyone. If you have never been to any of these, let your hair down and your creative side out and get out there , find out how much fun you can have and how bright and colorful the world really is.",0.0,0,"1 Campaign

Hi guys!! I am not sure if you know but our wonderful friend Richard Yoders mom is not doing well. He has been flying back and forth over the last few months. I am not sure if you have met his Mom but she is an amazing woman. Obviously because she gave birth to Richard : )
He recently had to give up his upcoming show because his mother has taken a turn for the worse. The doctors fear that over the next few weeks she will slip into a coma and that her body is now currently preparing to leave this planet.
He's such a light and joy I figure let's return that joy and light.

No one likes to ask for help and he didn't ask me to do this. But the one thing he shouldn't have to worry about right now is money. This amount will cover 2 one way tickets as well as a cab to and from the airport. He might leave before than, but at least he can be reimbursed. I hope you will give whatever you can. PLEASE DO NOT tell him about this and be carful if you share it on Facebook : ) Love to you all

Vasthy

We are seeking support for an exhibit of resistance art posters in tandem with a promotional tour of 3-5 cities for ALMOST HOME: TAIWAN, a documentary about Taiwan's struggle for democracy by Victoria Linchong. Interested in broadening support for Taiwan among artists and activists? Want to make sure that ALMOST HOME: TAIWAN screens in your city? We need your support! 

We're hoping to travel from New York City to Boston, DC, San Francisco and Seattle, with possibly a stop in Portland if we have the funds. We'll screen the film, talk up Taiwan and exhibit 6 to 8 posters created by artists in Taiwan and the United States in the tradition of resistance art from the Spanish Civil War, the United Farm Workers movement, and Mai 1968.
column2: >Posters from the exhibit will be available for sale at the art opening, which will also feature a sneak preview of the film. The screening will be free for people who supported the making of the film from 2008 to 2012 and for those of you who donate to this campaign!
column3: >By commissioning renowned political artists to create work about Taiwan, Art for a Free Taiwan aims to raise international concern for Taiwan's continuing struggle for democracy. We have a $3,000 grant from Taiwan Democracy Fund but this is far less than is needed to make this project happen - and beside we have to match the grant! The Taiwanese movement hasn't yet tapped the power of art to move the public. Your contribution will help create a new platform for discussions about Taiwan's democratic movement.
column13:
>Why this matters even if you're not Taiwanese

The story of Taiwan’s democracy is extraordinary and inspiring. Yet few people outside of Taiwan are aware of the bravery, passion and self-sacrifice that transformed Taiwan from a one-party state to one of the first democracies in Asia. Taiwan is in the peculiar position of being a country that is not really considered a country, of being a homegrown democracy that should be valued by the Western world, but is instead considered a nuisance and a threat to global peace. International pressure for Taiwan to unite with China rarely considers what would happen to Taiwan’s hard-won civil rights and democracy. The Taiwanese are never part of the One China debate, even though the political status of Taiwan is a central issue. It’s almost as if the Taiwanese don’t exist.

Some considerations:

column1: • For over 50 years, Taiwan's identity has been subsumed or repressed. Taiwan has its own unique history and culture that deserves to be celebrated. The majority of Taiwanese people are of Chinese descent, but Taiwan is not China. If that sounds confusing, just think of it this way: the U.S. is definitely not England although we speak English in America and a good percentage of us are of English descent.

• The Taiwanese should be included in the One China debate, which is couched as a power struggle between two Chinese powers (the Nationalists and the Communists). All people should have the right of self-determination, but the Taiwanese are never considered when it comes to political jurisdiction over their own island.

• Taiwan's freedom of speech, direct elections, and human rights need to be considered in the cry for unification with China. While unification with China may mean ""cross-strait peace"" for the Nationalists and the Communists, it would be a big step backward for the Taiwanese in terms of the democratic rights that they won with much tears and bloodshed.

Efforts to consolidate support for Taiwan’s democracy have largely concentrated on higher political circles. Formosan Association for Public Affairs (FAPA) has been very successful in rallying Congress to sign up for the Taiwan Congressional Caucus. It’s currently the second largest country caucus with over 150 members who receive a steady stream of current information on Taiwan. But advocacy in higher government is only one ingredient of a strong and successful movement
column2:
there needs to also be intense international concern and pressure.

In order to gain the empathy and support of the wider world, it is my belief that artists and grassroots activists need to be engaged. Artists in particular have the loudest voices, the biggest reach, and the deepest influence. Art provides an avenue for people who are not Taiwanese to identify with the movement. Nick Ut’s iconic photograph of a naked Vietnamese girl running away from a napalm bombing moved many people to join the anti-Vietnam War movement. The music of Hugh Masekela and Ladysmith Black Mombazo broadened international awareness of the anti-apartheid movement. The documentary film Burma VJ introduced the world to the injustices of the military dictatorship in Myanmar.

Art for a Free Taiwan seeks to jumpstart international awareness of Taiwan’s precarious democracy through commissioning six political artists to create posters that would be exhibited in five cities. The posters would additionally be viewable on a dedicated website and available to purchase online. Art for a Free Taiwan is designed to be sustainable, with a percentage of sales set aside to commission more posters from artists all over the world. Eventually, it is hoped that the project will engage over 25 artists and offer over 50 posters that will cause the general public to stop, think, and be curious enough to investigate the full story of Taiwan’s democracy. 

More about the project

column1: This project came from an idea to grow the movement for Taiwan's democracy in tandem with promotional efforts for ALMOST HOME: TAIWAN.
The basic idea is to utilize resistance art posters to raise awareness of Taiwan’s

precarious democracy. The first stage of this project will be to create posters that would be exhibited and sold in the cities that have already supported ALMOST HOME: TAIWAN. While the art exhibit will include a sneak preview screening of the film, the posters themselves are not advertisements or otherwise connected to the film beyond having the same political viewpoint.
They will stand on their own as dynamic,
provocative, resistance art posters. The project is meant to be self-sustaining and grow into an international movement of art for Taiwan. This initial stage will be comprised
of the following elements:

Artists who are involved

Herewith in alphabetical order are bios for the amazing artists who are contributing to this phase of Art for a Free Taiwan, followed by an example of their work. If you're interested in finding out about Victoria Linchong, check out her personal website. 

Peter Kuper's illustrations and comics appear regularly in Time, Newsweek, The New York Times, and MAD, where he illustrates SPY vs. SPY every month. His most recent books are adaptions of Franz Kafka's The Metamorphosis, Upton Sinclair's The Jungle and Sticks and Stones, a wordless graphic novel about the rise and fall of empires, which was awarded the gold medal in the sequential arts category in the 2004 Society of Illustrators competition. In 1979 he co-founded the political comix magazine World War 3 Illustrated and remains on its editorial board to this day. Since 1986 he has taught courses in comics and illustration at the School of Visual Arts and currently at Parsons in New York City. 

Luba Lukova is a Bulgarian-born artist and designer widely regarded for her editorial illustrations for The New York Timesand has received commissions for her work from the Wall Street Journal, Time, Adobe Systems, Sony Music and Harvard University.
column2: >Lukova has won many awards including Grand Prix Savignac at the International Poster Salon, Paris, France
column3: the Golden Pencil Award at the One Club, New York
column4: ICOGRADA Excellence Award at the Poster Festival in Chaumont, France
column5: and Honor Laureate at the International Poster Exhibition in Fort Collins, CO. Solo exhibitions of her work have been held at UNESCO, Paris
column7: La MaMa, New York and the Art Institute of Boston. Her work is included in the permanent collections of the Museum of Modern Art, New York
column8: the Library of Congress, Washington, DC
column9: and Bibliotheque Nationale de France.
column12: > is a designer, artist, activist, and archivist. Founder of the
column14: > political graphics collective, MacPhee is author or editor of five books and curator of two major touring exhibitions on political art and the visual culture of protest. Since 1998, he has commissioned over 100 posters in the
column16: > series, which was published in book form in 2010. Most recently, MacPhee co–founded the
column18:
>, a zine archive and exhibition space in Brooklyn that collects and displays socially–engaged art and activist publications. 

Mac McGill is a pen and ink artist whose work has been published in World War III Illustrated, Tikkun Magazine, The Amsterdam News, Chimurenga Magazine (South Africa), Warburger Comix (Slovenia) and The Black Panther Community News Service. His illustrations have also appeared in several books, among them, Mumia Abu-Jamal’s All Things Censored (Seven Stories Press), Wobblies! A Graphic History of the Industrial Workers of the World (Verso), and The Quotable Rebel...Political Quotations for Dangerous Times (Common Courage Press). IX XI MMI, eight pen-and-ink images of the events of 9/11, was featured at Exit Art in New York City in early 2002 and subsequently purchased by the Library of Congress and the Brooklyn Museum of Art. His work has also exhibited internationally in Portugal, Greece, and Italy, as well as at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine and ABC No Rio in New York City.  

Nicole Schulman is
column19: >known for her comics, posters and illustrations which have appeared in The New York Times, The Progressive, and Inguine Mah!gazine (Italy), as well as in World War 3 Illustrated — of which she is on the editorial board. She has never made much of an attempt to break into the gallery world, yet through the prodding and hard work of other people, Nicole's work has been exhibited in Exit Art, in 3 Cities Against the Wall exhibition (shown simultaneously in New York, Tel Aviv and Hebron), The Art Museum of Ravenna during the Komikazen Festival 2005, and the Brooklyn Historical Society. Her comic from the 911 issue of WW3 is in the permanent collection of the Library of Congress.
column20:
>

Wang LeWei is a Taiwanese illustrator whose work has been exhibited throughout Taiwan and in Hong Kong. 

Your Donation

We are thrilled that Taiwan Foundation for Democracy gave us a $3,000 grant for this project, but now we need to match it! Their donation will go towards gallery rental, printing of posters, and travel. We need you to help us with the following expenses:

column1: • Artist and administrative fees (allow $1,200)
• Framing and shipping of 6 posters (allow $1,200)
• Design and launch of website that will not only offer posters for sale, but also be a central online location for books, films, music and other artistic works about Taiwan (allow $600)

This is the minimum we need to make this project happen. With another $1000-$2000, we could have the exhibit up for a whole weekend and we'll also be able to afford a reception for the opening. So please tell your friends. Any donation, big or small, will help make this project a reality! 

Other Ways You Can Help

This campaign can only be successful if it reaches as many people as possible. Please share it on your facebook page, write about it on your blog, and send the link to friends whom you think would like to support democracy in Taiwan. Thank you!

Our purpose:

The purpose of the piece is to engage artists, writers and thinkers with
the mission of Mouth&amp
seeks to create an online platform for a multimedia erotic experience
that exists beyond the context of dominant social and sexual ideals. We
wish to present a counterpoint to this ideal that is both celebratory
and sensuous. We would deeply appreciate the opportunity to engage
further with the arts community in the context of celebrating ""The
Erotic"" as this is precisely what we aim to do with our online platform.
Mouth&
column2: Mouth Magazine is “tabula rasa”. We want you to forget

column1: what you think you know when you look at us. We want you to forget what

you think we want. We want you to look at us.

The magazine is set to launch Friday, 04/25/2014.

Description of the piece:

The piece is
a multimedia collaboration. The exterior is comprised of an
(approximately) 3'x3'x3' solid plywood case. The case is supported by
solid wood stilts so that the top of the piece measures (approximately)
6' off the ground. The case is supported by stilt legs. The stilts are draped by fitted maroon velvet ""curtains"" (reminiscent of

theater curtains).

The case is plain on three sides. The fourth side of the case
features a protruding androgynous face. This protuberance occurs in a
manner not unlike Han Solo frozen in ""carbonite"". The face is
indistinctive and androgynous except for its lips. The lips are cast
from a realistic lip mold - using color (unlike the rest of the face).
The lips are parted and contain a peephole big enough to peer into

comfortably. 

The peephole provides the only view of the interior of the case. The
act of looking into the mouth ""peephole"" creates a compelling and

layered visual for those witnessing the act. We want viewers to be vaguely aware of the glory hole / peep show reference. We want viewers to be disturbed by the visual trope which blurs the line between the audio and the visual.  The case, face and lips are built and sculpted by artist, Robert MacDonald.

Inside the case, an
erotic scene is projected on the wall visible to the viewer. This
erotic scene is produced and directed by Rebecca Reilly, Mouth&amp
column3:
Mouth Magazine mission statement, email and site url are featured on a third side of the exterior of the case.

What we need:

1. Five sheets of 4'x8' plywood

column1:
2. Four yards of velvet fabric
3. One small projector
4. Lumber
5. Materials for mottling and casting the lips
6. One pair of headphones
7. A clipboard

Costs include:

1. Two models for video piece
2. Small projector
3. Lumber

4. Four yards of velvet
5. Headphones
6. A clipboard
","Our purpose: The purpose of the piece is to engage artists, writers and thinkers with
the mission of Mouth&Mouth Magazine. Mouth&Mouth Magazine (MMM)
seeks to create an online platform for a multimedia erotic experience
that exists beyond the context of dominant social and sexual ideals. We
wish to present a counterpoint to this ideal that is both celebratory
and sensuous. We would deeply appreciate the opportunity to engage
further with the arts community in the context of celebrating ""The
Erotic"" as this is precisely what we aim to do with our online platform.
Mouth&Mouth Magazine is “tabula rasa”. We want you to forget
what you think you know when you look at us. We want you to forget what
you think we want. We want you to look at us.The magazine is set to launch Friday, 04/25/2014. Description of the piece: The piece is
a multimedia collaboration. The exterior is comprised of an
(approximately) 3'x3'x3' solid plywood case. The case is supported by
solid wood stilts so that the top of the piece measures (approximately)
6' off the ground. The case is supported by stilt legs. The stilts are draped by fitted maroon velvet ""curtains"" (reminiscent of
theater curtains). The case is plain on three sides. The fourth side of the case
features a protruding androgynous face. This protuberance occurs in a
manner not unlike Han Solo frozen in ""carbonite"". The face is
indistinctive and androgynous except for its lips. The lips are cast
from a realistic lip mold - using color (unlike the rest of the face).
The lips are parted and contain a peephole big enough to peer into
comfortably.  The peephole provides the only view of the interior of the case. The
act of looking into the mouth ""peephole"" creates a compelling and

layered visual for those witnessing the act. We want viewers to be vaguely aware of the glory hole / peep show reference. We want viewers to be disturbed by the visual trope which blurs the line between the audio and the visual.  The case, face and lips are built and sculpted by artist, Robert MacDonald. Inside the case, an
erotic scene is projected on the wall visible to the viewer. This

erotic scene is produced and directed by Rebecca Reilly, Mouth&Mouth Magazine's Video Editor.The Mouth&Mouth Magazine mission statement, email and site url are featured on a third side of the exterior of the case. What we need: 1. Five sheets of 4'x8' plywood

2. Four yards of velvet fabric 3. One small projector 4. Lumber5. Materials for mottling and casting the lips 6. One pair of headphones7. A clipboardCosts include:1. Two models for video piece2. Small projector 3. Lumber
4. Four yards of velvet 5. Headphones 6. A clipboard",0.0,0,"1 Campaign
|","Seattle, United States",https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/mouth-mouth-magazine-s-art-installation-for-the-seattle-erotic-art-festival/pica

Summary
My name is Amber Carman. I have been a blown
glass artist since 2003, creating whimsical glass objects in vibrant,
happy colors. I operate Amber's Glass, a small West Virginia-based hot

shop and gallery business.

For
me to work with fire and create shapes in glass with my breath is to
allow the divine to flow through me and be one with god. Bringing beauty
into the world is an incredible way of life.
For that glass to bring joy and inspiration to others is an

added bonus!

Since
2012, I have been working to renovate a building, and build an
economically viable hot shop for the production of art glass. Now that
the equipment is finally working well, I have been able to develop

several quality product samples.

Thanks so much for reading on, to learn about my campaign.

What We Need &
primary objectives at this time are to keep production going, establish
wholesale clients, and maximize Amber’s Glass income earning potential.
The success of Amber’s Glass is dependent on working capital for
production costs, wholesale marketing, and continued product

development. 

I
have made diligent efforts to keep costs low. Therefore, to get
launched now
and continue with low overhead, $3,500 is all that is needed initially.
It would be lovely to see this campaign advance this business faster
and with more ease. Ideally, the business needs $3,500-15,000. The full

business plan is attached and more numbers are available upon request.

In
short, raw materials need to be replenished and gas utility has to
remain current for operation to continue. Marketing costs include show
fees, printed collateral, and packaging. If additional funds beyond the
goal are donated, equipment upgrades will improve the quality of the
work and more innovative designs can begin. I would love for you to
follow Amber's Glass on Facebook and see the progress that has been

made.

Some fabulous
pieces have been created in the process of tweaking the equipment.
Simple items like ornamental orbs with confetti colors have been
accumulating. I would love to share these objects
with you, and know that as you admired them in the light of your home,

that you knew my story.

The Impact

This campaign has been set-up in ways to insure
that I can make it on my own, or to be able to grow rapidly, if needs
be. I could hire another glass worker immediately and grow much faster,
also creating a job for another artist. That requires additional
capital. There are other aspects of this business that can create jobs
here at the facility. The impact of selling American made goods to
retailers in the United States supports many small businesses and local

jobs. 

Other Ways You Can Help

It would be great to learn about retailers in
your area who would be interested in carrying my art glass. Please
support your local shops and artists. Start new family traditions by
collecting art or giving it as gifts. I like the idea of giving glass to
someone who has lost a loved one, as glass is soothing and calming. The
play of light

upon the colors can be mesmerizing.

Please Share Amber's Glass on your Facebook page, and on Etsy and Pinterest with Indiegogo tools.

With lots of love and gratitude, Amber Carman

Short Summary

My name is Haleema Nuredeen and I am the artist behind Hijabi Picasso Fundraising. My mission is to assist institutions such as schools, universities, charitable organizations and other similar groups by providing them with original fine art for their upcoming fundraising event.

How it Works
<li>
<b style=""letter-spacing: 0px
column2: > If  a school organizes a fundraising event, they can contact me to use my original artwork to sell or auction off.

column1: <li>
I will create the paintings and ship them to the school etc. free of charge.
<li>
If they are successful they send me a small percentage of the sales to continue my mission for the next school, etc. and the cycle continues!
What We Need &
column2:
What You Get

Technically speaking I only need about $150 to get started. (Indiegogo required me to put a minimum goal of $500)

Since I am not charging these organizations any upfront fees for my services I will need raise money for supplies, such as paint, canvases, and shipping materials.

So when the first organization  says ""Yes! We need your help!"" I will already have the materials needed to get started. =) Make sense?

The Impact

I've been painting professionally for over a year now. I enjoy it very much. But I would like to give back to the community while at the same time gain exposure for my artwork. Through this fundraising project, I feel that this is the best way to combine both.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

column1: • Tell a friend!
•  Use the Indiegogo share tools!
• or share this campaign link on your facebook/twitter account

And that's all there is to it!

UPDATE: Things are coming together with just few scant days left until I leave I just want to say Thank You so much to everyone who has supported me so far, you should be receiving your Virtual Travelogue e-mails in the next two days. Check out the tumblr for some new pictures and if you haven't already please share the Campaign page on your social media!



Hi, my name is Will Farris and for the past five years I have been making art in Chicago, Illinois. The city has been a great resource and constant influence on my work but I feel it is time for a much needed change of scenery, so this summer I will be walking trails, bike paths, and roads for the 2,131 miles between my current address and Golden Gate Park in San Francisco, California. Along the way I will be photographing, sketching, writing, and recording as much of the experience as possible, and with your help, when I reach my destination I will be distilling the journey into a series of works on canvas and mixed media pieces.

Every penny I get in funding will help produce the art which is the core of this project. Since this trip will involve adventuring on a daily basis, the Virtual Travlogue I will be updating over the course of the trip is a great way to bring some of the best aspects of being on the road into your life. Any contribution above $1 includes a subscription to  my Virtual Travelogue via mailing list. Everything from the $5 contribution which puts film in my camera to the $500 contribution, resulting in a beautiful 60""x72"" piece of art, keeps me on the road, well-supplied, and working!

This campaign offers us both an unexpected opportunity to make new connections. I will update my blog, hiketosf.tumblr.com, weekly, and subscribers to the Virtual Travelogue will receive more frequent updates. If you want to meet me along my walk, feel free to e-mail me at wfreazon (at) gmail (dot) com.

At the end of my journey, I will present a multifaceted perspective on what the American West feels like 'in situ' and you can bring a little bit of that adventure into your life while helping me disseminate it to a wider audience. Whatever your level of involvement, the best contribution you can make is to spread the word! Let others know about my trip and encourage them to help, and don't forget to mention they can get some sweet art out of it.

column5:
>WOW! THANK YOU! We've reached our initial goal! We have a week left in our campaign! We're hoping to double the amount we raise and our goal is now $5000! Our initial funding will go into paint, lighting, safety, insurance, weatherproofing, and other basic build-out needs. 

If we hit $5000 we can acquire seating for events, a new projector for film screenings, tables for workshops, a P.A. system for performance events, new additions to our zine library, a comfy couch, and a community party when we launch next month. More info here.
column11:
>THE ANNEX

Little Berlin is opening a space for public events and a zine reading room.


WHAT WE’RE DOING

This summer, Little Berlin is launching The Annex, a 600 square foot space adjacent to Little Berlin’s gallery in the Viking Mill Building in Kensington. This new space will be dedicated to special events and a comfortable reading room for the Little Berlin Zine Library, a collection of hundreds of artist-made books. Unlike Little Berlin’s gallery, the Annex will not hold monthly exhibitions or installations. Instead, this intimate space will feature film screenings, performances, talks, poetry readings, lectures, badminton tournaments, workshops, and lots of opportunities for new artists, musicians, curators and creative practitioners.

WHO WE ARE

Little Berlin is a cooperative exhibition space run by approximately 10 people who curate the space using a collaborative, do-it-yourself ethic. Located in Kensington, Philadelphia, members actively pursue community outreach through ongoing projects such as the Philadelphia Public History Truck, The Fairgrounds community garden as well as monthly exhibitions. As opposed to an artist cooperative, we do not usually show our own artwork. Instead, we feature emerging and established artists from the neighborhood, from around Philadelphia, and from across the country.
column14:
>As our audience has grown, we need space to hold many more events and a dedicated space for people to experience our artist zine library.

WHAT KIND OF HELP DO WE NEED

Little Berlin is a volunteer, cooperative, non-hierarchical collective. We do not receive city, state or federal funding. Members pay monthly dues and we accept donations from visitors. Thousands of people have come through our doors. To expand our activities and allow us to present even more events, we need your help funding some of the renovations needed to open our new Annex space. We are enterprising artists. With only a modest budget, we can dramatically improve the warehouse space we acquired and open it to the public.


OUR PAST

Little Berlin was founded in 2007 by Kristen Neville-Taylor and Martha Savery in the Berks Warehouse in Kensington, in their former art studio space. Someone told Neville-Taylor and Savery that with artists rehabbing buildings and starting up projects in an urban industrial neighborhood, Kensington felt like postwar Berlin, thus the name Little Berlin. To help with funding and running the gallery, which operates with a DIY ethic and no outside financial support, Neville-Taylor and Savery put out an open call for membership for an “undefined exhibition space.” Each member came from various backgrounds, including sculpture, new media, performance, installation, and experimental art, and events at the space reflected this diversity in curatorial approach through hosting dozens of artists from the Philadelphia community and around the world in monthly exhibitions. In early 2011, after extensive renovations, Little Berlin moved and opened a bigger space in the Viking Mill building in East Kensington, and Little Berlin began playing within the boundaries of “curating” as art practice.


In 2012, Little Berlin began developing a vacant plot of land next to the Viking Mill building. Through a successful Knight Arts Challenge Grant, Little Berlin built The Fairgrounds, a large outdoor community park and sculpture garden, which has hosted barbecues, movie screenings, block parties, and a community garden.  The gallery dramatically expanded again in 2013 and 2014 with a combination of earlier and new members. Since then, Little Berlin has grown into an epicenter of culture for its East Kensington home, and the city of Philadelphia as a whole. We are regularly reviewed by art publications, local papers and blogs, and we are also a space for our neighbors to come enjoy a show or garden with us. And we like it that way.


PERKS AS THANK YOU FOR YOUR SUPPORT

All images have been designed for us by artist Mark Price. Shirts are printed on American Apparel t-shirts, as well as special totebags, locally screenprinted in our neighborhood by Greg Labold.

Little Berlin Graffiti image by Mark Price

Note (will be screenprinted in black ink on a light grey American Apparel shirt)

Little Berlin Blueprint image by Mark Price

Note (will be screenprinted in red ink on a light blue American Apparel shirt)
column17:
>$5 Pat yourself on the back

$18 - Tote bag

$20 - Graffiti shirt (note: black ink on gray shirt!)

$20 - Blueprint shirt (note: red ink on light blue shirt!)

$35 - Any shirt and a graffiti-image tote

$50 - 2 shirts and a tote

$100 -  Naming Rights. Your name on a plaque in The Bathroom for 1 year! And a shirt!

$250 - Hold an event in The Annex! We’ll work with you to host your event! Also: we’ll stick your name on a plaque in the bathroom for 1 year! Plus 2 shirts and a tote!

$500 - Permanent plaque inside the Annex with your name and special recognition at our opening events. If you desire, we’ll help you organize an event in The Annex. Plus: 2 shirts and a tote!


THANK YOU FOR YOUR SUPPORT!

“Hot sauce must be hot. If you don't like it hot, use less.”
--David Tran, creator of Sriracha Hot Sauce
Can you imagine pho without Sriracha? Can you imagine tacos
without Tapatío?  Now can you imagine
breathing without air?  That’s how we at
the museum feel – that it’s impossible to live without these two sauces so we
are creating an art exhibition to celebrate Tapatío and the much coveted rooster sauce.
Our
upcoming exhibition L.A. Heat: Taste-Changing Condiments examines Los Angeles in a new way by exploring
two hot sauces that are produced in Los Angeles.  What is the
significance that these two quintessential American condiments were developed
and made in Los Angeles?  What can it tell
us about our city and our city’s role in America’s shifting culinary
traditions?  And what will happen when we assemble 25 Los Angeles based artists together
to create work based off of red-hot, mouth burning condiments?  <b>Donate
now to see what happens!
Your contributions will
enable the museum to develop a catalog and exhibit works inspired by Sriracha
and/or Tapatío in a variety of mediums from established as well as emerging
artists based in Los Angeles.
The
exhibit is scheduled to open in March 2014 and will run through July 2014. We
are open to the public and our admission is free.
Participating Artists
• Edith Beaucage
• Erik Benjamins
• Audrey Chan
• Ching Ching Cheng
• Chris Christion
• Dave Chung
• Clayton Brothers
• Eye One
• Gajin Fujita
• Daniel Gonzalez
• Patrick “Pato” Hebert
• Phung Huynh
• Tomo Isoyama
• Nery Gabriel Lemus
• Sandra Low
• Trinh Mai
• Patrick Martinez
• Michael Massenburg
• Kwanchai Moriya
• Jose Ramirez
• Yoshie Sakai
• Jose Sarinana
• Sand One
• Sket
• Slick
• Henry Taylor
• Shark Toof
• Werc

More information the exhibition can be found on our website:
http://camla.org/upcoming-exhibits/#laheat
Who are
Since
its opening in 2003 in downtown Los Angeles, the Chinese American Museum has presented numerous
permanent and temporary exhibitions designed to foster a deeper understanding
and appreciation of America’s diverse heritage by
researching, preserving, and sharing the history rich cultural legacy, and

continuing contributions of Chinese Americans

Visit camla.org for more information on the museum

column2: >Nad Ronnoco (Dan Oconnor backwards), born 1973 in Rahway New Jersey, never formally trained in any school, but started drawing the funnys in the news paper with his mother. She then gave him a set of oils and let him at it, creating nothing but mud his first 100 tries, he then watched Bob Ross on channel 13 pbs and watched and watched until he started creating his own landsacapes. rough around the edges, and not patient he gave up on oils.
column4: >After taking a fifteen year break and facing some trials and tribulations and some of lifes unexpected tragedies in 1999 he picked up his brushes with a new vigor and zest for life and art. a passion that has satyed with him since.
column6: >His style is diverse and not consistent but explores many different styles with his own insight and eye for color and fun energetic paintings....... his ever changing style is what he calls his niche, he chooses to not be drawn to one style or range but to explore, like a true Gemini from one to the next and finding new experiences to drive his art. He never looked to do anything but paint and be able to continue his love and passion for art.... a true lover of nature and lifes mysteries come follow him as he evolves...

column1: <span style=""letter-spacing: 0.0px
column10: >As follows: I am an artist, I am a sculptor, a painter, a photographer, most of all these I love art.... What I am not, definitely not a business person,  or salesperson, or a marketeer, these things I am sure of.....another thing I am sure of is that most people don't have thousands of dollars to spend on awesome , fantastic, artwork that they love....this needs not change, and I am the one who is willing to do it.....my goal is to get art in to those who otherwise normally couldn't afford it but certainly deserve , and desire , original artwork.......I don't  want there only options for affordable art to be Department Stores for there ""sofa matching art"".   I can create fantastic paintings in many genre's, large sizes and on a budget similar to the large chains.  Not prints, not duplicates, all originals on canvas or muslin, gallery wrapped and signed.      Art is to be seen ,enjoyed ,shared, and like music it should be  affordable and enjoyed with out breaking the bank.....my goal is to create 100 paintings for this year and sell not one painting of this series for more than 300$ for the largest 36x48  and most entry level 20x26, 24x24, 30x40, 24x56 priced on a sliding scale starting at 50$.

","Nad Ronnoco (Dan Oconnor backwards), born 1973 in Rahway New Jersey, never formally trained in any school, but started drawing the funnys in the news paper with his mother. She then gave him a set of oils and let him at it, creating nothing but mud his first 100 tries, he then watched Bob Ross on channel 13 pbs and watched and watched until he started creating his own landsacapes. rough around the edges, and not patient he gave up on oils.After taking a fifteen year break and facing some trials and tribulations and some of lifes unexpected tragedies in 1999 he picked up his brushes with a new vigor and zest for life and art. a passion that has satyed with him since.His style is diverse and not consistent but explores many different styles with his own insight and eye for color and fun energetic paintings....... his ever changing style is what he calls his niche, he chooses to not be drawn to one style or range but to explore, like a true Gemini from one to the next and finding new experiences to drive his art. He never looked to do anything but paint and be able to continue his love and passion for art.... a true lover of nature and lifes mysteries come follow him as he evolves...

MY VISION. As follows: I am an artist, I am a sculptor, a painter, a photographer, most of all these I love art.... What I am not, definitely not a business person,  or salesperson, or a marketeer, these things I am sure of.....another thing I am sure of is that most people don't have thousands of dollars to spend on awesome , fantastic, artwork that they love....this needs not change, and I am the one who is willing to do it.....my goal is to get art in to those who otherwise normally couldn't afford it but certainly deserve , and desire , original artwork.......I don't  want there only options for affordable art to be Department Stores for there ""sofa matching art"".   I can create fantastic paintings in many genre's, large sizes and on a budget similar to the large chains.  Not prints, not duplicates, all originals on canvas or muslin, gallery wrapped and signed.      Art is to be seen ,enjoyed ,shared, and like music it should be  affordable and enjoyed with out breaking the bank.....my goal is to create 100 paintings for this year and sell not one painting of this series for more than 300$ for the largest 36x48  and most entry level 20x26, 24x24, 30x40, 24x56 priced on a sliding scale starting at 50$.
The budget for this project includes: canvas, paint, photography and online store.

UPDATE JULY 26, 2013
Funding for this campaign may have ended two months ago, but that does not mean you are too late.  Please contact me with any requests or questions at josh.rickun@gmail.com.

I have been hard at work all summer perfecting the process to make a better, stronger, and more effective pair of glasses and feel confident with the progress that has been made thus far.  The official release date will now be sometime this August or September.  Please stay on the lookout or follow this project on Twitter at twitter.com/ProperWood.
Proper Eyewear - Made in Milwaukee

My name is Josh Rickun, I'm a glasses wearing, nearsighted student at the Milwaukee Institute of Art and Design, part time graphic designer, concert poster maker, vintage sunglass collector, and volunteer screen printing instructor at Discovery World, a hands on science museum.

I've been hard at work for the better part of the past year discovering a process that is successful in producing beautifully detailed, hand crafted wooden eye glasses that are unwilling to compromise form for the limitations of the material.  It took numerous failed attempts until I completed a pair that worked.  There’s still a small ways to go and always room for innovation, and I am excited for new breakthroughs and discoveries.

I use only Wisconsin sourced, sustainably grown and fallen urban lumber, carefully selected individually for its unique grain and figure for every pair made.  In addition to its beauty, the wood is chosen for its hardness, resiliance, and resistance to breaking or scratching. Proper Eyeglasses are one of a kind wearable works of art
that are as strong as they are beautiful.
Immediate Goals

In addition to helping make Proper glasses available anywhere, supporting this project will allow me to produce hinges right here in Wisconsin, rather than China, that reinforce the strength of the temples and allow optometrists anywhere to adjust the glasses to any wearer.

I am working with a veterean optometrist of 48 years, Lupe Aguilar of Innovative Optique in Fox Point, WI, to make sure Proper glasses are of the highest quality and universally accepted by optometrists anywhere in the world.
<div>
The Impact

By contributing to this project, you are helping me continue to develop a high quality product that is produced right in Milwaukee out of sustainable and gorgeous Wisconsin lumber.  Milwaukee has a long standing reputation of hard work and innovation and I believe this project follows that tradition.  I am fortunate to live in a place that grows some of the best wood in the world

Last week, an Atlanta woman named Gabrielle Mirville was arrested while topless in Woodruff Park. Her arrest, and subsequent jailing and fining, go against Georgia's laws which allow for women to go topless wherever it's okay for men to do so.

To read more about Gabrielle's story, Georgia's law, and the implications of this kind of discrimination, check out this article in Creative Loafing: http://clatl.com/atlanta/right-to-bare-breasts/Content?oid=9000712

Gabrielle Mirville was a model in a photo shoot on the morning of August 4th. The shoot consisted mostly of the 24-year-old model standing alone against the early morning cityscape. The resulting photos are elegant, reverent portraits of both the model and the city.
A few of the shots required Mirville to be momentarily topless. This is where things got tricky. And Mirville got arrested.

Considering previous shoots that included nudity, Mirville says the team thought they had a good grasp of the law. On previous shoots in public places, Mirville claims, nearby APD officers had told them essentially ""do what you gotta do and don't be porny."" They quickly got the shots they needed, the project was tasteful and professional, and Mirville remained clothed except for the actual moment the photos were being taken.

On this morning, however, a bike cop felt differently. He arrested Mirville for public indecency. She subsequently spent nine hours in jail before being bailed out. At her Atlanta Municipal Court appearance the next morning, unaware of what constituted public indecency, she pled no contest.

""This was my first appearance so I hadn't been assigned a public defender or anything,"" Mirville told me. ""I wasn't sure what I should do. I was on my own. If I knew then what I know now about the law, there's no way I would've accepted any of that.""

By Mirville's account, Judge Terrinee Gundy allegedly wasn't interested in hearing her defense: ""When I tried to explain to the judge, she said, 'No, and next time maybe you'll learn to carry yourself like a lady.'""
Mirville had a choice: spend 10 days in jail or pay nearly $500 right then. Without anyone to counsel her on possible options, she paid up.
This campaign is to help raise money to cover her fines, and contribute to her legal fees as she challenges the ruling.
Your support is greatly appreciated!

Hi everyone. My name is Kevin Amos and I am a broadcaster based in
Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania. I am also the founder of the Black Music Education
Project.

PROJECT:  Acquire and renovate a community artist space in
the Homewood-Bruston community to house visiting artists, foster collaboration,
and present events including house concerts.  A House For Community
Collaboration will also include a community based radio station.

PLAN: Purchase a house in Homewood-Brushton, an underserved area
in Pittsburgh, PA.  Renovate the house to meet the above criteria. Begin
providing programming.

OUTCOME:  A catalyst to attract and retain artists, musicians
and cultural tastemakers in Homewood.  Our goal is to help Homewood become
an Black Arts &
column2:
Culture destination in the City Of Pittsburgh. This method
of neighborhood revitalization has proven successful Lawrenceville and the Penn Avenue Arts District, but made little to no impact with attraction, inclusion and retention Black cultural and community workers.

column1:
HISTORICAL SIGNIFICANCE: Homeood-Brushton is a historically
vibrant Black music and arts community.   It was the home of Ahmad Jamal,
Billy Strayhorn as well as  Madame Mary Caldwell Dawson and the National
Negro Opera Company. The sense of community will be enhanced with this new addition to the community.

ASSETS/ SKILLS: Established in 1995, the Black Music Education
Project educates the community through traditional and new media platforms as well as producing various events.

The BMEP produces a weekly music program on Black Music called
“One to One w/ Kevin Amos. “One to One” is a Sunday morning tradition for
Pittsburgh radio listeners.

The program airs on www.wrct.org to a worldwide audience Sundays from
6AM-Noon EST. Locally the program airs on frequency 88.3 FM on WRCT, the
student-run station at Carnegie-Mellon University. The program has run weekly
for the past 20 years. Kevin Amos has been a community volunteer at the
station since 1982 and an independent broadcaster and producer for over 30
years.

WAYS TO PARTICIPATE:  Be part of a physical legacy for future
collaborations and future generations.
Choose a level of giving by clicking on the sidebar.

Pledge materials for renovation and /or things for the performance
space and to the house in general.

<div>
Your Money Makes Art Happen!

It's almost time for Sideshow Crazy 8! A two-day festival of art and music that celebrates the local arts scene and is unique in Dayton for its variety, ambition, and all-volunteer grassroots energy. This year's Sideshow will feature a variety of artwork including paintings, photographs, sculptures and video installations from more than 50 artists as well as performances by over 20 musical acts. Admission is free, and open to everyone.
That doesn't mean The Sideshow is free to put on though - this year we estimate operating costs to be approximately $5000, for items such as tents, sound pros &
column2: equipment, required permits and much more - and this is where we need your help.

column1: <div>
Our campaign is only for $1500, less than a third of our estimated budget. If we exceed our goal (and we hope we will by a lot!) know that all the money will be used to make the Sideshow even better!

If you're an artist or musician that has participated in a past Sideshow, please donate! If you are friends with artists or musicians who have participated in a Sideshow, please donate! If you just like the idea of supporting a great art show or seeing cool things happen in Dayton, Ohio, please donate!
Any amount helps whether it is $5 or $500... think about it, where else will you get to see that amount of art and music for $5!

It's not just your money that makes art happen, your friend's money works too! Look at some of the big dollar perks we have and pool your money together to get them. Who wouldn't want a private rock show with 40 of your friends? Share this all over facebook and anywhere else that you can think of as well - the more it is out there, the better chance we have of exceeding our goal!
And keep checking back, we will be adding new perks through the month.
Most important, even if you can't afford to donate, make sure you come to The Sideshow on May 10 &
column2: 11 at the Yellow Cab building (700 E. 4th St.) and see what gets created!

column1: Your Money Makes Art Happen!
<div>

The Sideshow is magic - both for the people who participate and for those who attend. Built by artists just for the sheer fun of celebrating art and music, it is a unique show. This is our eighth year holding The Sideshow, and it is safe to say that hundreds of artists and musicians have added their talent and emotion to the Sideshow. For many it was their first time exhibiting or playing in front of a live audience. For others, it was a chance to experiment and try totally new things. You may have participated in past Sideshows yourself, and know the magic that we speak of... if not it is likely that you know at least one person, and more likely multiple people who have played a part in putting on the Sideshow. Your donations help make all this possible.

Greetings! We are the 2012 Up From The Roots slam team and this October, we'll be heading to Saskatoon to compete head-to-head against teams from across this talented country of ours at the Canadian Festival of Spoken Word.
And we need your help.
Why? Because traveling across our country is expensive and we're poets, not CEOs.
You should contribute to our journey if you:
<ul>
• Think poets are sexy.
• Appreciate the type of spoken word that makes your soul shudder.
• Know how hard it is to make a living as an artist in Canada.
• Have a spare $10 that you would otherwise be spending on a ridiculously overpriced beer somewhere.
• Know Dwayne Morgan, Ritallin, Patrick De Belen, Lishai or Serafina personally.
• WANT to know Dwanye Morgan, Ritallin, Patrick De Belen, Lishai or Serafina personally.
• Want to feel directly connected to GLORIOUS VICTORY (hopefully).
Whether it's $5 or $50 or $5000... we appreciate any contribution more than you know.

Thank you, thank you, thank you.
The UFTR 2012 Slam Team

Citizens Warehouse

The Historic Warehouse Arts District in downtown Tucson is an eclectic, thriving and growing community. Citizens Warehouse, a cornerstone to this community, is home to 23 artists of varied mediums and disciplines. For the past few months we have been working on an art book featuring the artists of Citizens Warehouse.
About the Book

The primary purpose of the book is to support and give exposure to the artists in Citizens Warehouse. It showcases select works from 20 artists, amounting to more than 120 full color images of paintings, drawings, sculpture, ceramics, metal work, furnishings, and multi-media art. There are also photographs to illustrate the culture of the warehouse from events, excursions and figure drawing sessions. It is a perfect bound, coffee table, art book measuring 8""x10"" closed with a soft cover, 104 pages in length.

The book also presents the stories of Bicycle Inter-Community Art and Salvage (BICAS) and its Art Annex, a historic essay about the warehouse—how it came to be what it is today, and more about the Tucson Historic Warehouse Arts District, Citizens Artist Collective (CAC) and Warehouse Arts Management Organization (WAMO).
Why a Book?

Citizens Warehouse, and spaces like it everywhere, is in danger of being lost, which would be a tremendous shame as the community of artists here would be displaced, as well as BICAS and their Art Annex. Currently, Citizens Warehouse offers affordable studio space (below market rate) to these artists which, if lost, would negatively impact the arts community—specifically, the Tucson Historic Warehouse Arts District.

column3: title=""Artists in Drawing Session""/>So we want to spotlight this unique building and its artists with a beautiful art book. We think folks are really interested to know more about the inspired work that goes on in this concrete art bunker.

column1: Book Sales

All money generated from the sales of this book after printing will be donated to funds for maintenance and repairs on the building, further marketing and promotion of the artists who work here, community programs such as field trips and workshops for students, and programs to help protect the warehouse—insuring it remain a vital part of the Arts District Community.

This book will also be an important part of the Social Capital Campaign that WAMO is implementing—the purpose of which is to bring attention to the Historic Warehouse Arts District and its rich culture of creativity.
More About the Artists
Be sure to
column2: a=1609093"" rel=""noopener nofollow"">click on the gallery tab at the top to view some of the artists' work that will be in the book, as well as a few videos. And feel free to visit us online at: citizensart.com

column1: Thank you!
Please support this project! Make a pledge of $40 or more and receive your own copy of the book.

Cover Art by Titus Castanza: ""The Fisherpeople,"" 48""x42"" (cropped), oil on canvas

","Citizens Warehouse

The Historic Warehouse Arts District in downtown Tucson is an eclectic, thriving and growing community. Citizens Warehouse, a cornerstone to this community, is home to 23 artists of varied mediums and disciplines. For the past few months we have been working on an art book featuring the artists of Citizens Warehouse.
About the Book

The primary purpose of the book is to support and give exposure to the artists in Citizens Warehouse. It showcases select works from 20 artists, amounting to more than 120 full color images of paintings, drawings, sculpture, ceramics, metal work, furnishings, and multi-media art. There are also photographs to illustrate the culture of the warehouse from events, excursions and figure drawing sessions. It is a perfect bound, coffee table, art book measuring 8""x10"" closed with a soft cover, 104 pages in length.

The book also presents the stories of Bicycle Inter-Community Art and Salvage (BICAS) and its Art Annex, a historic essay about the warehouse—how it came to be what it is today, and more about the Tucson Historic Warehouse Arts District, Citizens Artist Collective (CAC) and Warehouse Arts Management Organization (WAMO).
Why a Book?

Citizens Warehouse, and spaces like it everywhere, is in danger of being lost, which would be a tremendous shame as the community of artists here would be displaced, as well as BICAS and their Art Annex. Currently, Citizens Warehouse offers affordable studio space (below market rate) to these artists which, if lost, would negatively impact the arts community—specifically, the Tucson Historic Warehouse Arts District.

So we want to spotlight this unique building and its artists with a beautiful art book. We think folks are really interested to know more about the inspired work that goes on in this concrete art bunker.
Book Sales

All money generated from the sales of this book after printing will be donated to funds for maintenance and repairs on the building, further marketing and promotion of the artists who work here, community programs such as field trips and workshops for students, and programs to help protect the warehouse—insuring it remain a vital part of the Arts District Community.

This book will also be an important part of the Social Capital Campaign that WAMO is implementing—the purpose of which is to bring attention to the Historic Warehouse Arts District and its rich culture of creativity.
More About the Artists
Be sure to click on the gallery tab at the top to view some of the artists' work that will be in the book, as well as a few videos. And feel free to visit us online at: citizensart.com
Thank you!
Please support this project! Make a pledge of $40 or more and receive your own copy of the book.
