 SUIT YOURSELF:

“Behind the storm of daily conflict and crisis, the dramatic confrontations, the tumult of political struggle, the poet, the artist, the musician, continues the quiet work of centuries, building bridges of experience between peoples, reminding man of the universality of his feelings and desires and despairs, and reminding him that the forces that unite are deeper than those that
divide.”
John F. Kennendy

Some days you wake up and put on clothing that came from China or Indonesia and was made by many different hands, and some days you wear something that is made of fine Italian silk, and some days it’s something that was formerly owned by a stranger.  It is unlikely that anyone wakes up and wears a garment that they made themselves in their own space, just the day before.  I want to know what this feels like and suffer all of the physical and emotional consequences.  I want to talk about this process and show that it is gratifyingly both simple and strenuous.

I am an artist and designer living and working in New York City.  My practice circulates around utilizing everyday objects and materials to elevate our understanding of the creative process and accentuate the daily presence of the transcendent act of making.  I use fabric, clothing, food, and design as a way to engage the public and exemplify the unsung masterpieces inherent to our daily lives.

This project is important to me because a devotion to meaningful work promises to provide a space for meditational experience and the unmatched gratification that is derived from making something out of nothing.  For the past four months I have been engaging in a rigorous schedule commuting back and forth from New York to Boston each week in order to teach in several college programs.  This process has been physically, emotionally, and socially challenging, but has overall allowed me to recognize that repetitive, steady practice is absolutely necessary to my process.  Not able to maintain this regular practice has left me deeply desiring a regimented project in which my only task is to create every day.  This focus will inevitably lead to a higher understanding of myself and of the processes that I utilize in my work.  In addition to this personal experience that is necessary to my work right now, I feel that this performance accentuates the labor and material that is invested in the objects that we interact with very casually on a day-to-day basis.  I am requesting funding for this project so that I may embark on this journey without pressures to distract away from the experience and true and unadulterated focus.  The length of the project will be dictated by how much funding I receive through this platform and other sources.  The funds will be used for material (fabric, notions, and food stuffs for dinners), equipment, and rent.  If enough is raised, I would like to rent a space dedicated solely to this piece, a storefront would be ideal, allowing this process to be accessible to the public for the duration of the project .

The proposed project, entitled Suit Yourself, is a publicly accessible, long-term, intensive performance with weekly craft-based workshops and culinary events.  The artist will design and construct each article of her clothing every day for at least one month but not to exceed one year.  No individual garment will be worn for more than one day, after which it will be catalogued and stored until the end of the performance.  The project is comprised of four major components:
<ol>
• PERFORMANCE:
• Craft-based, process-oriented performance in which the artist designs and constructs all items of clothing to be worn each day.
• Concept circulates around production and practice of dressmaking and emphasizes material wastefulness and the disregard with which we treat most garments.

• Sisyphean process (spending each day wearing what was made the day before while making the clothing to be worn the next day) is a metaphor for futility of repetitive, monotonous work while simultaneously exhibiting reverence for meaningful work and skillful practice.
• Public hours will be available for visitors to come by and observe this work and talk to the artist about this experience.
• DINNERS/WORKSHOPS:

• Each week the artist will host and prepare a dinner for 10 participants who reserve a seat ahead of time.  The purpose of this gathering is to discuss the performance and the creative process involved in everyday activities such as dressing and cooking.

• Each week the artist will run a workshop teaching simple skills involved in the performance (hemming pants, mending, altering, baking, pickling, etc) that accentuate the transcendent nature of unpacking habitual process and learning self-sufficiency.
• DOCUMENTATION:
• BLOG: each day the production will be carefully documented on a journalistic photo blog.
• CATALOGUE: an image catalogue of each singular garment will be compiled at the end of the performance.
• RECIPE BOOK: A book of the recipes prepared at the 24 meals will be created.
• EXHIBITION:
• The project will culminate in an exhibition of all garments created, exemplifying the scope of production. (180 bras, 180 undergarments, 180 outfits, etc.)

Though I have significant sewing experience, there will inevitably be frustration with certain items.  I recently executed a condensed version of this project at chashama266 in New York for three days.  I doing so, I was confronted with the task of constructing a brassiere for the first time, which ultimately proved to be very challenging.  By the third day I had improved significantly, but was by no means adept.  After ten months and the creation of approximately 300 bras alone, I will have found rhythm and ease with this process.  I am interested in the compulsive nature of honing physical skills through repetition.  I am eager to witness the psychological fallout, as I do believe it will be an overall enriching experience. Monotonous practice catalyzes inward reflection and amplifies the thought process as practice settles into a pattern-based flow.

This project examines the use of tangible skills pertaining to goods and services.  It analyzes the impulse to cover and decorate the body through a series of creative decisions based on social, cultural, and historical instincts and questions the classification of meaningful work and its ability to facilitate a transcendental experience.  I am interested in how we approach the act of adorning our bodies as a basic utilitarian need and as a vehicle for social or cultural expression.  Fashion articulates who we are—the intrinsic manifestation of art and life colliding.  I aim to accentuate the minute, creative ventures that happen everyday
column2: the shape and palette of an outfit, flavor profiles of a meal, the composition of a room.  These unsung masterpieces are inadvertently similar to the artistic process.  I am interested in accessing this foundation of basic creative procedures as an impetus for dialogue and cooperation.  My work explores the inherent human visionary intuition.

column1: Any support from donations received through Indiegogo will further this body of work by providing funding for equipment, materials, and space.  I have recently engaged in a studio-based graduate program, founded a communal gallery and studio space in Brooklyn, attended a studio residency in Boston MA, and taught at several colleges in the art and design programs.  This vested interest in community engagement in terms of education and public participation is at the heart of my career and my work.  It is pivotal to creation and existence of this work.  An opportunity that incorporates community discourse with making art would both shape my work and help me to extend this knowledge to my public.  It is these qualities, along with my experience in design and my education in New York City, that I am most proud of and have formed me into a valuable member of the arts community with an unmatched devotion to my practice.

I truly thank each and every one of you in advance, for even reading this far and considering this project worth your time.  Please spread the word, far and wide, and help me to make this project a reality.

Hi, my name is Mahieu Spaid,

I specialize in landscape painting using acrylics and oils. My most recent collection was inspired by travels to the Caribbean Islands. The bright colors and hidden beaches truly made an impression. Capturing the colors of the water and the lush vegetation was a challenge. Some of the scenes were painted from my memories of exploring the different islands.

Mahieu Studios launch is about a new art shop that I have setup on Etsy for you. The art pieces are ready for you to view and purchase. Be one of the first customers to assist me in sharing my art with everyone!  By contributing right away you will receive a piece of art hand signed by me. The art given in this campaign will be the very first prints ever by Mahieu Studios! Please take a look at the site located at http://www.etsy.com/shop/MahieuStudios  Choose the perk that is right for you when considering the amount to give to my project.

Our Story

My dream is finally coming to fruition because of YOU!  My name is Katherine Nelson, and I am an art teacher at Warren T. White High School in Dallas.  The school was built in 1964, and although it is located in a beautiful area, we are a Title 1 school (underprivileged student body).  This year, we officially began a Fine Arts Academy and the administration has agreed to offer Ceramics next year, a program that will give our students the opportunity to express themselves through clay.    My school budget is dedicated to purchasing clay and other basic art supplies.  Here's where you come into the picture.  The only equipment we have is a small kiln.  We have absolutely NOTHING else needed for the program.  Some of the items needed to get a ceramics program started are expensive and will be used for many years by thousands of students
column2: your gifts will outlive us all and continue serving our students.  It has always been a dream of mine to teach ceramics and I SO appreciate any help you can give!

column1: The Impact
<h3><span class=""Apple-style-span"" style=""font-size: 14px
column3: >Ceramics is one of the very few subjects where everyone can succeed, regardless of socioeconomic status, physical, mental, or language limitations, or lack of previous education.  Many students who lack confidence refuse to try anything because they are afraid of failure - they choose to take a zero grade rather than face the possibility of failure on an assignment.  Once a student tastes success in any form, they are more willing to try harder in all their subjects.  This moves from school to real life situations.  I see a real and tangible opportunity to keep our kids off the streets and away from drugs.  Clay!

column1: Every year, I have approximately 200 new art students.  The few times I have brought clay into the studio, every single kid was completely absorbed, looked forward to coming to class, and did not want to leave after the bell.  I have students coming into my room Mon.-Fri. beginning at 7am, during lunch, and staying after school until I kick them out at 6:30pm.  I LOVE my kids and with your help we can give them so much more!
<h3>What We Need &amp

We are looking to finance $22,000 which will allow us to renovate an old mechanical room (my current art room) into a ceramics studio.  We need pottery wheels (I would like to start with 8), a slab roller, particle boards for wedging the clay, HardieBacker board to reclaiming clay, shelving to store the greenware, bisque, and current projects.  We need a pugger so none of our clay is wasted, and a clay sink so we don't ruin the plumbing.  We need sponges, mops, glazes, buckets, garbage cans, a hose, bats, extrusion dies, and CLAY!  As we receive donations, we will begin with the basic materials, then add the wheels and other goodies until we have the most spectacular studio in the area. We would love to thank you by making you a piece of pottery, so make sure we know who you are!!!
Other Ways You Can Help

Will you please get the word out and make some noise about our program campaign?  We can reach a LOT of people if everyone Facebooks, Twitters, etc.  I see a real and tangible opportunity to keep our kids off the streets and away from drugs.  Clay!

Help kids build a kid's city..we need some cash and we could also use some volunteers.
<span style=""font-size: 9pt
collaboration between several students at Quest2Learn public school, and  a group of high-school age students of a
graffiti art class at the Educational Alliance in the Lower East Side, a  miniature, interactive silver city and skate
park made from recycled wood with graffiti mini-murals on its walls and lit from within, will be
designed , built and rebuilt, and decorated and played with by kids who visit
FIGMENT on Fridays, Saturdays, and Sundays from May 27th -September 25th on Governor’s
Island . The Quest2Learn students are designing most of the structures and the
skate park while the youth from the graffiti art class will be working to create the foundations of the city and begin to

decorate it as well as the skate park.  The youth will be engaged to consider and plan how to share a city, and to be conscious of what role graffiti would/could/should have. All art contributing to the life of this city is welcome.

<h4 class=""MsoNormal"">
<span style=""font-size: 9pt
column3: >Since many of the materials are recycled, we are conservatively asking for 1500.00

column1: art materials, lights, and to replenish wood and parts

so the city can evolve throughout the summer and every child who wants to gets to build, or paint the city. We will simply scale down the number of workshops and simplify the mediums used to paint the city if we do not reach our funding goal, or scale them up if we exceed it.

","Help kids build a kid's city..we need some cash and we could also use some volunteers.
In a
collaboration between several students at Quest2Learn public school, and  a group of high-school age students of a
graffiti art class at the Educational Alliance in the Lower East Side, a  miniature, interactive silver city and skate
park made from recycled wood with graffiti mini-murals on its walls and lit from within, will be
designed , built and rebuilt, and decorated and played with by kids who visit
FIGMENT on Fridays, Saturdays, and Sundays from May 27th -September 25th on Governor’s
Island . The Quest2Learn students are designing most of the structures and the
skate park while the youth from the graffiti art class will be working to create the foundations of the city and begin to

decorate it as well as the skate park.  The youth will be engaged to consider and plan how to share a city, and to be conscious of what role graffiti would/could/should have. All art contributing to the life of this city is welcome.
Kids who visit the project can reconfigure parts of the city, build with wood blocks, and paint and play with components that will be provided throughout the

summer. On several weekend days throughout the summer, NYC graffiti artists who make some measure of their living  from graffiti will teach or otherwise lead a presentation about their craft.  We will be making a video archive of these as a way to document the

legacy of these artists and their contribution to future generations of youth.  With the potential dissolution of 5Pointz in Long Island City http://5ptz.com/graff/about/ , we believe it's crucial to find any and all ways to preserve legal spaces to paint and the positive impact this community can have .
As this city is meant to be shared place, we encourage everyone to come (with your kids) and contribute or play in  the city. We
will be doing additional programming with guest artists, and educators on
additional week-end spots TBA. If you have any interest contact us!
A final workshop (with details to follow)  will be held the weekend of October 1-2nd
where kids will be part of the de-installation and will be able to take home
their own individual miniature buildings,helping to bring MICROTOPIA to a sustainable conclusion.
Since many of the materials are recycled, we are conservatively asking for 1500.00 for the
art materials, lights, and to replenish wood and parts

so the city can evolve throughout the summer and every child who wants to gets to build, or paint the city. We will simply scale down the number of workshops and simplify the mediums used to paint the city if we do not reach our funding goal, or scale them up if we exceed it.
Please get the word out or let us know if you want to be involved with this public project in some way! barriecline@earthlink.net",0.0,0,"2 Campaigns

column3: >Festival participation (for both audience and performers) is free, and it is run locally on a voluntary basis.  ARTtractions receives no financial funding and limited logistical support (lighting, printing, etc.) from the local town hall, Comune di Noepoli.

column1: <span class=""Apple-style-span"" style=""font-weight: normal
Open air Children's Art Workshop with US Artist Delflina J. Piretti, Aug '09

Through the joint working efforts of the Associazione di Promozione Sociale ARTtractions and Palazzo Rinaldi, the Festival has now become a well-established part of the local summer calendar and a social aggregator with tailor made events for all ages.
CurtainCall International Theatre Group performs in the Piazza, Jul '10

The Artists in Residence visiting Noepoli from every part of the world rely on the Festival framework to preview and present their creative works to a local audience- often for the first time, and as a catalyst for communication. The rural local area on the other hand, geographically cut off the contemporary art world, is delivered exciting and enriching works on its doorstep and is able to directly interact and communicate with its creators, providing unforgettable moments of dialogue.   You can read more here: http://www.palazzorinaldi.com/Artists_Interacti...

You will be sent every spring a yearly Festival programme with details of live streaming performances, plus your name will be added to the book printed at the end of every Festival season.  In addition Palazzo Rinaldi Artists' Residency is also providing some perks to entice you further...
Other Ways You Can Help
Please share this campaign spreading the word by email or on your social media pages.
Grazie mille!
We are grateful for your time and support and look forward to bringing you some inspiring artistic and cultural events live from Noepoli, wherever you may be.

","ARTtractions/ ARTtrazioni is a yearly no-profit arts & culture Festival that takes place in the hilltop village of Noepoli, in the South of Italy.  The Festival showcases the talents of the International artists in residency at Palazzo Rinaldi, and promotes their interaction and creative exchange with the local community.
Above: Tebby T.W. Ramasike (South Africa) and Cristina Benedita (Portugal) in the site-specific dance performance 'The Song of the Earth', Sept '09

Now in its 3rd season, the Festival has so far presented over 30 events ranging from visual arts exhibitions and performances to arts and crafts workshops, screenings and more.  Residents who have performed in the Festival have come from as far as Iran, South Africa and Mexico, also with a strong European and American presence.
Canadian Artist Lynne Heller (centre) teaching a Decal Art Workshop in Noepoli, Jun '10

Festival participation (for both audience and performers) is free, and it is run locally on a voluntary basis.  ARTtractions receives no financial funding and limited logistical support (lighting, printing, etc.) from the local town hall, Comune di Noepoli.
The Impact
Open air Children's Art Workshop with US Artist Delflina J. Piretti, Aug '09

Through the joint working efforts of the Associazione di Promozione Sociale ARTtractions and Palazzo Rinaldi, the Festival has now become a well-established part of the local summer calendar and a social aggregator with tailor made events for all ages.
CurtainCall International Theatre Group performs in the Piazza, Jul '10

The Artists in Residence visiting Noepoli from every part of the world rely on the Festival framework to preview and present their creative works to a local audience- often for the first time, and as a catalyst for communication. The rural local area on the other hand, geographically cut off the contemporary art world, is delivered exciting and enriching works on its doorstep and is able to directly interact and communicate with its creators, providing unforgettable moments of dialogue.   You can read more here: http://www.palazzorinaldi.com/Artists_Interacti...
Temporary Permancies: paper art exhibition by Josefina Temìn (Mexico), Sept '09
What We Need & What You Get

Up to this point, due to lack of financial funding, we have only been able to create a photographic archive of the events.  Many times, particularly in the case of music and theatre, we felt this was not enough.

With more events already lined up we are increasingly feeling the need to start diffusing the unique artistic creations and exchanges that take place in this location via live stream around the world, and to build up a professional archive.
In order to do so, the ARTtractions Festival asks for your support in acquiring a semi-professional HD video camera for this purpose.

Donors will be actively helping to preserve all the events that take place as part of the Festival, and for this reason will receive the gratitude of everyone involved in it, from volunteers and performers to the local community and wider internet audience, who will always have permanent records to look back on. You will be sent every spring a yearly Festival programme with details of live streaming performances, plus your name will be added to the book printed at the end of every Festival season.  In addition Palazzo Rinaldi Artists' Residency is also providing some perks to entice you further...
Other Ways You Can Help
Please share this campaign spreading the word by email or on your social media pages.
Grazie mille!
We are grateful for your time and support and look forward to bringing you some inspiring artistic and cultural events live from Noepoli, wherever you may be.",6.0,0,"1 Campaign

Short Summary

In the spring of 2015, Emma Arrick, BRAT Production's 2014-15 Resident Artist will curate and direct Plant Me Here a multidisciplinary immersive experience based on the poetry of Philadelphia playwright Jason Rosenberg. Plant Me Here will be a culmination of a creative exploration conducted by artists from various disciplines, curated by Arrick, working as ensemble to interpret Rosenberg's poetry. Plant Me Here is an evening of sloppy magical realism that asks the viewer to vilify the body and find the beauty in horror. Plant Me Here is the result of open studio cross disciplinary collaboration. Right now it feels like when you put your hand in a bowl of spaghetti in a haunted house and for half a second you think that maybe it really is guts. Maybe later it will feel like something else. The piece is changing daily.
BRAT Productions’ Resident Artist Program

BRAT’s Resident Artist program was created to give emerging artists with bold and unapologetic visions the opportunity to produce original work. The Resident Artist program is unique in that gives an artist the opportunity to have both total creative ownership of an idea and access to BRAT’s years of producing experience to make that vision come to life. By offering the combination of creative ownership and producorial mentoring, BRAT is supporting the true “emerging artist,” and empowering the next generation of theater makers in Philadelphia.
Emma Arrick

Emma Arrick is a 2014 graduate of the University of the Arts with a degree in Theatre and a focus in Interdisciplinary Collaboration and Physical Theatre. She is the co-founder of Cursed Church Art Collective, with whom she has played many roles including performer, stage manager, director, screenwriter, casting director and producer. Over the past several years Emma has allied herself with local experimental film company, Zimbo Films, Philadelphia based multi-disciplinary showcase series 5x7 Space Showing, BRAT Productions as well as individual artists spanning all mediums. She believes in collaboration and communication. Emma is interested in the hybridization of art forms, the malleability of structure, and the concept of producing work with a strictly aesthetic agenda. Her work asks the audience to project meaning, rather than being driven by a message or.
Jason Rosenberg

Jason Rosenberg is playwright, poet, and actor based in Philadelphia. He is currently a senior at the University of the Arts with a focus in Playwriting. He is the co-founder and resident playwright for Cursed Church and the development intern for BRAT Productions. His writing asks, “How can we be happy if we’re going to die?” and explores this idea through the interplay of poetic visuals and sparse, emotionally disarming language. He hopes that through his work in Plant Me Here, he can contribute to the ongoing conversation about the relationship between playwrights and devised theater.
Cursed Mission Statement

The Cursed Church Artist Collective is a group of multidisciplinary artists dedicated to the creation of visceral, innovative works of theater and film and anything that can be loosely categorized within those perimeters. We are a group of young artists based in Philadelphia. Our artistic pursuits range from the staging of original poetic and movement centric theater to long form improv comedy to experimental filmmaking to rock musicals. Our aesthetic interests are always changing. When a member of our ensemble has an idea for a project they are interested in working on under the umbrella of our company, we make it happen. We have found that the best way to ask a question is shamelessly and the best way to answer it is with as many voices as possible. We are 8 people lucky enough to be surrounded by people who want to help us continue to do what we love. We are spooky and funny mostly.
What We Need &

The first phase of this process is complete. We spent 3 weeks in open studio collaboration at Shiloh Baptist Church. 4 actors, 2 composers and a slew of guest collaborators, spanning all mediums, built a stand alone piece of theatre that will be used as the primary informant for the continuation of the building of this piece. BRAT supplied stipends for the artists involved as well as space rental for rehearsal and three work in progress showings at vastly different venues around Philadelphia.

But the piece does not end here. We need funds to pay a team of designers to interpret the piece and transform it into an installation. We need materials for the construction of sets and interactive sculpture. We need funds for the second round of stipends for the actors and composers when they revisit the piece in rehearsal this spring. We need to rent a projector. We need to make posters. We need all sorts of fun stuff that we don't even know WHAT yet, because this piece is changing and growing every day.
Check out our sweet perks!
From what we can tell, no one makes work quite like this.

The way we have been operating is new, innovative and the entire process is open to the public. There has been an overwhelmingly positive response from the artists who have come to make with us during our first phase. Keeping the doors between artists of differing mediums open and creating a common vocabulary across disciplines has been of the utmost importance to this process and the budding careers of all the young artists involved.  With your help. we can keep building an open, inclusive, nurturing artistic community, and make art in new, challenging, invigorating ways.

Other Ways You Can Help

Keep up to date with additional programming for Plant Me Here on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/pages/Plant-Me-Here/1573697292849908
Contact Emma Arrick about lending your talents, feedback and vision to the Plant Me Here process.
emmaarrick@gmail.com

","CuatroH seeks to create a dialogue between the established and the experimental, the present and the future, in an environment that is responsive to the issues of contemporary art. That contemporary art originated in the exploration of the ideals and interests generated in the new artistic traditions of today. Involved in all forms of visual expression, including painting and sculpture, drawings, prints and illustrated books, photography, architecture and design, and film and video, as well as new forms yet to be developed or understood, that reflect and explore the artistic issues of this era. That these forms of visual expression are an open-ended series of arguments and counter arguments that can be explored through exhibitions and installations and are reflected in CuatroH. Also to affirm the importance of contemporary art and artists in Bushwick to remain vital and engaged with the present.
We are opening this campaign to assist the initial growth of CuatroH as a cultural space.
Your contribution will allow us to achieve our goals, which includes:
Establishing an Art space for Contemporary Art exhibitions.
Studio Residencies.
Art lectures.
Film screenings.
Materials.
Interviews.
So far, we have held three exhibitions since we've opened last October.
CuatroH Opening / October 18th
Sophie Kitching I More than half less than full / November 7th - 12th
Group Show I United Colors of Benetton / November 14th - 17th
With your help we can keep running the space.
Even if you cannot contribute economically, you can always help CuatroH by spreading the word.  And that's all there is to it.",4.0,1,"1 Campaign
